151240281.review:
If you're scrolling through Steam looking for a game that truly immerses you in the nitty-gritty of medieval life, then "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" is your Holy Grail. Here's why:

Realism at Its Finest: This isn't your typical RPG where you start off as a chosen hero. You're Henry, a blacksmith's son, and trust me, the game makes sure you feel every bit the commoner you are. The attention to historical accuracy and detail is mind-blowing. From the architecture to the costumes, every aspect feels like a time machine to 15th-century Bohemia.

Learning Curve Steeper Than a Castle Wall: This game doesn’t hold your hand. Combat is tough, survival is tougher. You'll have to learn to read, fight, and even haggle like a true medieval peasant. It's frustrating at first, but incredibly rewarding once you get the hang of it.

Graphics That'll Make You Weep Medieval Tears: The landscapes are gorgeous. Sunsets in this game make you want to grab a lute and compose a ballad. Character models, lighting, and the overall environment are stunningly realistic.

Bugs? More Like Authentic Medieval Pests: Yes, there are bugs. Some hilarious, some annoying, but it is not that much that would ruin your gameplay.

Deep and Engaging Story-line: The narrative is compelling. You're not just on a quest; you're living a life in a turbulent and fascinating period. The quests are as varied as medieval life itself – some epic, some mundane, but all interesting in their own right.

In Short: Kingdom Come: Deliverance is not for the faint of heart. It's a game for those who appreciate historical accuracy, challenging game-play, and deep storytelling. If that sounds like you, then prepare to lose yourself in the Middle Ages.

Would recommend to: History buffs, RPG enthusiasts, and anyone who's ever wanted to live in a world without zippers.

Hours Played: Just enough to know I still have a lot to learn about medieval pick pocketing.

In the first few hours of the game, the game will push you towards Theresa as the main love interest. She is independent, pretty, and is very caring towards the player character Henry. She is also the wrong choice.

Captain Bernard is the real partner for Henry. While Theresa gives you bandages and snacks, Bernard will hold you in his hairy, muscular arms and through the arena teach you how to survive, fight, and kill in the Roman Empire. Through Bernard's training, you will ascend to godhood, and become and unstoppable killing machine. None shall stand in your way, Bernard's nurturing warmth is the only companion you need.

150645463.review:
This game is not for everyone. But if you approach it with an open mind and some determination, you are bound to fall in love with this game. Henry, the character you play as, is a blacksmith's boy. He doesn't really have any skills when you start out. It's up to you to decide what he should focus on to improve. You have to keep working at it to ensure that Henry learns and improves, and I frankly LOVE that aspect of this game. I love the power fantasies of Skyrim and other games, but being a little peasant boy who works up the ranks and becomes a hardened knight is so ungodly satisfying.

If you are a medieval history buff like me, you'll find that Kingdom Come Deliverance scratches that itch for an enjoyable singleplayer medieval experience. And hell, you'll learn stuff about real world history, too! KCD is rooted in the very real events of 1400's Bohemia and the work Warhorse has done to bring it to life really shows.

This game does have its issues. It can be buggy. It's not the best optimized game out there. Some mechanics can be frustrating. But these are all issues that can be dealt with, and in my experience, rarely ever take away from the game. I'd say it's similar to Oblivion in its charming janky-ness. The DLCs can be a bit underwhelming, but I am begging you, PLEASE play A Woman's Lot. That shit hurted. That DLC is heartwrenching and just so well done. 

Over all, I'd say give this game a shot. Don't let the high barrier of entry at the beginning discourage you. Take a moment to watch a few videos about this game if you're on the fence. But I assure you, if you give this game a chance, it will be well worth it. I've played this game a total of three times between PC and Xbox, and it has to be one of my favorite gaming experiences in recent memory.

Oh, and lastly, the soundtrack slaps. That is all.

150548740.review:
[b]-- GAMEPLAY --[/b]
KC:D is a true, hardcore medieval reality simulator. This reflects on the gameplay, especially in combat. And it makes it really hard and time consuming. Just to be able to, not die instantly you have to train for multiple in game weeks, with a trainer, to learn to fight with both swords. You need to raise both your and your character's skill level this way. But unlike in other games, the level of realism makes it fun and challangeing. You have access to a wide range of weapons, each with their stregnhts and weaknesses. My biggest beef here though, that we can't use halbeards and spears, even though they would be perfect weapons for this game. And the vision limit.
Since GOT, we know, that you should wear a helmet, right? The problem is, in rela life it limits your vision. And in this game. I mean, i understand they added it for realism, but it takes away a big part of the enjoyment of the game, actually seeing the combat.
And no, stealth archer is not as viable here as in other games. Archery is hard as f#&@ and you have no crosshairs. And stealth, well, it is as realistic as possible here too.
But, i mean, medieval life is suffering, so the game should be like that too.
[b]Jesus Christ be praised![/b]
[b]10/8[/b]

[b]-- GRAPHICS --[/b]
For a 2018 game, it looks really great. Even in 2023 it looks nice.
[b]10/7[/b]

[b]-- SOUNDS --[/b]
Voice acting and sounds are generally good, but i speak hungarian. So i understand what the cumans are saying. And that part, is really bad. They shout cringeworthy things and they choose terrible voice actors for any cuman role. For non hungraian speakers, this will not be a problem, but for us who do, it will ruin the immersion.
[b]10/7[/b]

[b]-- STORY --[/b]
The story is pretty great. I don't know how historically accurate some of the events, but there are a lot that it is.
[b]10/6[/b]

[b]-- CHARACTERS --[/b]
We have some great multi dimensional characters here, whom will make you more immersed in the game.
[b]10/7[/b]

[b]-- WORLD && WORLDBUILDING --[/b]
This part is amazing. Everything in this world, as historically accurate as it could be. Just the amount of reshearch work they must have put in is just another level. 
[b]Jesus Christ be praised![/b]
[b]10/10[/b]

[b]-- REPLAYABILITY --[/b]
There is not much. Mostly for achievments, or just to play the game on hardcore mode.
[b]10/4[/b]

[b]--TL;DR--[/b]
KC:D is an amazing game. It recreates medievel life as accurate as possible, from a video game's perspective, and let's the players lose themselves in it, with a great story and fun game mechanics. It takes some time to learn, but well worth the time. 
[b]Jesus Christ be praised![/b]
[b]10/8[/b]

150509607.review:
A Medieval Masterpiece.

As an avid fan of simulation games like Arma and DCS, and with a deep interest in military and medieval history, Kingdom Come Deliverance has been a remarkable journey for me. It's not just a game; it's a portal to another universe, one that meticulously reconstructs the medieval era with an immersive authenticity.

The combat system is a standout feature. With some basic understanding of historical swordsmanship, I was thrilled to see how the game attempts to replicate these techniques. It's not just about swinging a sword; it's about the art and skill of medieval combat, making every encounter both challenging and rewarding.

The narrative is another aspect where Kingdom Come truly shines. The storyline is gripping, weaving the personal journey of our hero with the intricate politics of nobility in a way that is both engaging and enlightening. It captures the essence of the medieval period, not just in grand battles but in the nuanced struggles of daily life.

One element I appreciated particularly is the game's portrayal of the difficulties of medieval life, integrated into its survival mechanics. However, I feel there's room for a more intense survival experience, pushing the boundaries of what it's like to live in such a harsh and unforgiving era.

A feature I missed in the game was jousting. Including this could have further enriched the depiction of knighthood and the era's martial culture. Looking forward to Kingdom Come 2, I'm hopeful for a bigger map, 

Kingdom Come Deliverance is a masterclass in historical simulation and storytelling, a game that not only entertains but educates and immerses its players in the depth and complexity of medieval life.

The user experience, is somehow even worse than the quest design. Complete unintuitive controls, at least for a PC user, it never seems like the button I'd expect to do what I want actually does it, and it bugs out entirely consistently. The map is even pretty much useless, you can't zoom in to see the icons properly to be able to mark anything out for navigation. And all of this comes before we even get to the bugs. Not being able to open my inventory, journal, map, etc; having to restart the same quest multiple times because it's bugged out (npc's not spawning where they should, dialog bugging out, etc). 150449062.review:
Having immersed myself in the captivating world of Kingdom Come: Deliverance since its release, I find myself compelled to share the enduring appeal of this historical RPG masterpiece. Through countless playthroughs, the game continues to stand as a testament to its exceptional qualities, with two aspects in particular standing out – the enchanting musical score and the unparalleled ability to lose oneself in its meticulously crafted environment and realism.

From the first notes of the haunting melodies that accompany the journey, Kingdom Come: Deliverance's music is nothing short of magical. After numerous playthroughs, the soundtrack remains a poignant companion, underscoring the historical authenticity of the game. Whether galloping through vast landscapes or engaging in intense battles, the music consistently adds a layer of emotional depth, breathing life into every moment.

The game's ability to transport players to 15th-century Bohemia extends beyond the auditory experience. With each playthrough, I continue to be enthralled by the attention to detail in the environment. Every stone in the cobblestone streets, every building, and every piece of attire contributes to a world that feels not just historically accurate but lived-in and authentic. The dedication to realism not only educates players about the past but also allows them to actively participate in a meticulously recreated medieval realm.

Having traversed the landscapes multiple times, the realism in Kingdom Come: Deliverance remains unparalleled. The combat system, challenging and nuanced, demands a mastery of swordplay, archery, and strategic thinking. With each encounter, the consequences of my decisions echo through the game world, shaping the destiny of my character in profound ways. It's a level of immersion that keeps me returning, eager to experience the consequences of different choices and strategies.

In summary, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is not just a game but a timeless classic that has stood the test of time since its release. Having played through it numerous times, the enchanting music and the unparalleled sense of realism in its environment continue to make each playthrough a fresh and captivating experience. If you've been on this journey since the beginning or are considering stepping into the shoes of medieval Bohemia for the first time, Kingdom Come: Deliverance remains a shining example of historical RPG excellence.

150427876.review:
This game is fun, not really as an RPG but more as a sneak peek into medieval life. 

You're completely railroaded into playing a defined character which is meh, and there's really not much in the way of choice. You're playing out the defined character's typical rags to richest story instead of your own. There's some flavor choices you can make along the way, but mostly it just changes a few lines of dialogue, and the story plays out the same way no matter what you do.

The combat is also straight up a**. Like alot of people have said, the main problem is target lock on + the parry system. 

Lock on makes fighting multiple enemies a chore, since the whole game is mandatory first person, which means your field of view is really narrow. Your character automatically tunnels onto one enemy, meanwhile two others are wailing on you from behind and the camera is shaky and janky and hard to figure out what's going on or who's where, as you constantly get stuck in forced animations. 

The parry system is timed blocks, which sometimes result in RNG "master strikes." The problem is everyone can do them, and the enemy master strike RNG is 100%. Low level enemies can master strike. High level enemies can master strike. Bathhouse wenches can master strike. So...you'll be a plate armor wearing knight, armed to the teeth with a heavy warhammer and shield, highly skilled in a variety of weapons, max warfare and strength stats, riding proud on your warhorse, that's also armored to the teeth and looking fabulous in noble finery... then get taken down by two Jedi peasants dressed in rags wielding sticks. 

You can win those fights, but the cheese for combat is literally kiting in a backwards circle, the whole time spamming block and waiting for master strike RNG. As long as you never actually attack you can win pretty much every fight no matter the odds, which as soon as you figure that out makes combat really tedious and dumb. It would take alot of attacks to defeat a armored knight...or just one face stab master strike. That's all there is to it.

So why recommend it? Mainly because the world is interesting enough that I put 70 hours into it, which is worth the cost. I didn't finish the main quest but who cares, it's pretty boring and turns into fast travel across the whole map fetch quests by the end anyways. The scenery is also great to just roam around the countryside exploring, and by far the side quests and DLCs were way more interesting than the main quest and are the only content with actual consequences.

There's just not many games out there nowadays that take creative risks. This game is a pretty unflinching view of medieval times and social hierarchies, and it really focuses on the mundane stuff which makes even the smallest village feel alive, NPCs have daily routines etc. There's no way a AAA studio would have the b***s to make this game.

150332977.review:
Honestly this game is very interesting and has a lot of fun systems. Literally just going hunting can be cool, or making potions, interacting with NPCs. The story isnt that awful, the main issue is that the game has a humongous flaw in one of its main systems - Combat.

The main issue with combat in KC:D is the introduction of the "Master Strike" system, aka parrying. The issue, mainly, is that every single enemy in the game can do it. Peasants, bandits, farmers, man-at-arms, everyone. For being a "master" skill, its very ubiquitous. Why is parrying an issue, and enemies being able to do it an issue, you might ask? Because they can, and will, master strike/parry every single attack you throw. Doesn't matter what direction, whats happening, they hit the input and now you're put into an animation where you loser all player agency and are forced to receive damage because the game said you had to.

The secondary issue of this, it completely removes any amount of "skill" from the combat, or tactics, because an enemy can literally be facing away from you, but if you attack them and theyre aware, theyll master strike, stab you in the gut and send you falling forward. So how do we handle this? The main way is to ONLY master strike your opponent. So you sit there, staring at one another, waiting. Occasionally your enemy will "clinch" you, think boxers hugging. 9 times out of 10 they win and push you around and open you up to an attack and since you're in an animation of falling around, you cant parry. Glorious.

If youre determined to participate in the rock paper scissors match of combat this game has, I recommend wearing no armor and just using a shield and warhammer. Hit them in the head, warhammers have a chance to automatically knock someone out if you hit them in the head, and theres a perk that increases this chance.

Good luck, have fun, but i really cant recommend a game that constantly breaks up its somewhat interesting story with some of the most frustrating combat ive ever experienced.

150277404.review:
This game is a really good game in MOST aspects.
Story, setting, VA, Music, all that is absolutely fantastic. I really enjoyed exploring the world and going on random sidequests and trying to find the best outcome etc. The story is really fun, and the DLC ones too, I highly recommend them. Graphics are beautiful. Inventory UI isn't the best i've seen, feels really old, but it still works. The atmosphere is nice and feels alive.
This makes me recommend the game.

HOWEVER
The combat system is complete jank. Like i've never been more frustrated in a combat system in my life. I genuinely have more fun going around doing fetch quests than fighting someone. A lot of it is due to the bad stats system, which in fairness does make some sense, but like even when you're near max level with some of the best gear, some random bandit will still block like all your attacks. Half the time, your attacks just miss (especially on uneven terrain) while theirs connect. The other half of the time where you are lucky to connect, you barely do damage, like why. The combos are stupidly hard to pull off because the enemy needs to stand still for all the attacks. A single dodge and F you lmao start again (also lining up that middle one, fuck that). You can actually spend like a full minute or two trading perfect parry and riposte over and over. And that doesn't even touch fighting when outnumbered, my god. The targeting system is awful. When facing multiple opponents, it just keeps changing, making focusing a single target really hard. You can also only really properly defend against the guy you're locked onto, even with a shield. 
Tbh it may just be a skill issue, but when i swing like 8 times at a guy for him to block/dodge them only for him to hit me with an unblockable counter/animation that only they can do, then hit me through my shield, it gets frustrating fast.

After suffering through 103 hours of this train wreck, the game decided that Bernard and everyone at the main quest location wanted to kill me. So I resolved to use cheats and kill them all to ease my indescribable amount of nerd rage. Then I discovered that the game will simply not let me attack Bernard, and no amount of cheats would sooth my seething anger.

Story and VA is 10/10, very lovely setting and game world. Mechanics are for the truly self loathing and masochistic, complete garbage gameplay every step of the way. Difficulty in this game is not based on how skilled you are, how well timed your parry and riposte is, or how high you raise any of your weapon skills. Every swing, every block, every arrow is essentially RNG. Any fight you find yourself in without your weapon already drawn and fully ready for combat is a near guaranteed loss.

Do not put yourself through this like I did. Over a hundred hours of my life wasted. I'm off to youtube to watch the cutscenes and see how Henry's story unfolds.

150197019.review:
KC: Deliverance stands out as one of the most unique games I've experienced. In a gaming landscape where most RPGs tend to blend together, KC diverges by innovating with bold, original ideas. Its greatest strength lies in its realism and grounded gameplay. Things like magic, dragons, necromancers, mages, and other regular fantasy stuff are absent in this game. Instead, you immerse yourself in the role of a blacksmith's son who initially struggles to even wield a sword.

As the game progresses, you learn and improve in combat alongside Henry, the protagonist. This learning curve isn't just about skill points; it's about genuinely mastering in-game techniques. While some later-game mechanics can be exploited for ease, it is not like you have to use them.

The game's heart is its realistically rendered world, a diverse cast of characters, and a storyline that's simple yet captivating. Unfortunately, the story doesn't conclude in this installment, leaving me eager for KC2. Despite this, what the game offers is thoroughly enjoyable.

There are some downsides, like demanding hardware optimization, occasional bugs, (some) clunky combat moments, some side quests that drag out, and occasional stiff animations. However, these issues don't overshadow the game's overall quality. I highly recommend it to anyone seeking a fresh and different gaming experience.

150077273.review:
So for a long time I held off purchasing KCD because I simply didn't know what the game was or what made it interesting. I wish I had purchased it earlier though because it stands as the best rpg I have ever played. So I'll start with some pros/cons and if you don't understand what makes the game special you can scroll below.
Pros:
-Very Unique Systems (not just combat, but potion brewing, gambling, hunting, repairing, ext)
-Very Realistic in Both How it Plays and its World
-Unique Setting
-Good story (believable enough to be real, but epic enough to be interesting)
-Interesting Characters
-Constant Sense of Growth
~100 Hours of Gameplay
-Immersive
-Skill System Similar to Elder Scrolls
- Great Saving System
-Choices affect the world

Cons
-Extremely Difficult Early On
-Combat System Clunky with Multiple Opponents
-Ends on Cliffhanger
-Mediocre DLC

So to give a brief synopsis you play Henry a black smith's son in the Holy Roman Empire the country is on the verge of civil war and as a consequence your village is burned and you must go on a quest to avenge your family and reclaim your father's sword. The game is a very realistic depiction of medieval times and is very realistic in how it plays. The sword play is very in depth and requires a good deal of skill, but makes every fight interesting. What sets KCD apart from its competition is the uniqueness of every single system.  For instance brewing potions is not a matter of getting ingrediants and pressing a brew button. No, instead you have to actually get a recipe and go through the process of making the potion in the correct order and time to produce your product. The gambling mini game isn't raw luck, but also skill and the ability to use weighted dice, which was super enjoyable. Overall every part of the game felt both realistic, immersive, and enjoyable. I will warn because the game is so realistic it comes off as kind of life simmy (you need to get food, keep yourself clean, ext.) so if you don't like those mechanics it may not be for you. Also it is extremely difficult early on you are poor with no skills and almost no save potions (you can still save at beds and the beginning of missions). This is exacerbated by the fact the game has you do more difficult tasks as a tutorial like hunting rabbits to learn to use a bow (which are the hardest animal to hunt including people) and fight cumans who are a decent bit better than your basic bandit. However, if you can get through that initial hurdle the games difficulty drops to a manageable level where everything still has challenge, but not spine shatteringly so. I will also throw out there the DLC are okay-ish. None were bad, but they are very compartmentalized and didn't add a lot. Also their rewards vary from useless garbage to the best items in the game which render all other equipment pointless and there's no real in between. In the end if you love historical dramas and are tired of bland flavorless rpgs where you walk up to enemies and press the one key to hit them slightly harder then KCD is for you.

This is an incredible game that tries it's hardest to make sure you don't have any fun. It's frustrating, the combat is janky despite being very deep and interesting, and the pacing is very slow. The world building is incredible, and if you like learning about mediaeval history and experiencing it, it's great.

My second language is German so I play it in that language and the voice acting and text is excellent. The translation is localised for that time period just enough for it to be believable while still being comprehensible, and imo the German VA for Henry is way cooler than the English one. 

Very frustrating game, but a game so good and endearing that its strengths make it worth while.

149870972.review:
天国拯救是一款可以进入我个人游戏排名前5的游戏，也很难想象这是一款2018年发售的游戏，那是个神作云集的那一年，既有大表哥2，战神4这些重量级的选手，也有黑魂1重制，蔚蓝，底特律, 刺客信条, 蜘蛛侠等等各类佳作，但让我觉得更神奇的是天国拯救发售于2018年2月份，比大表哥2的10月份早了近大半年，而天国拯救与大表哥2的体验却有着如此相似熟悉的味道，以写实为基调的游戏体验，富有生活气息的世界设计，丰富多样的细节内容，实在让我很惊讶天国拯救竟然比大表哥2更早地出现，同时天国拯救也很遗憾地在2018年沦为这些优秀游戏的背景板。

而它与大表哥2也同样有着让人诟病的地方，非常漫长的上手期，复杂的交互设计，基于写实需要而导致充满大量生活仪式性的重复内容，以及天国拯救独有且十分劝退的战斗。对于这些问题的看法，我个人觉得一款以写实为基调的RPG游戏，其核心体验必然需要玩家投入大量的时间(这个时间标准也是因玩家而异，而且最好是连续的)，才能充分让玩家主动地去感受到自身成长和兴趣点所在，同时对这个世界中的人与物有了自己熟悉的认识，以及对主角的遭遇和经历产生足够的情感，当然还有最重要的前提是这个游戏能否做到这些，对我来说天国拯救确实做到了，而且做得很好。

这里就从天国拯救写实有趣且十分劝退的战斗来说明，天国拯救是如何能让我从劝退边缘到享受的体验变化。

[b]游戏时间2小时，我刚认识愣头青亨利时，和他一起举起长剑，既陌生又兴奋，学了半路子教程后，村里马上寻个卫兵比划两下，好家伙，不是我甩锅，亨利你怕是有先天性小儿麻痹，剑都挥不利落，你这耐力条又是啥情况，嘎嘎掉，而卫兵左一挥，右一刺，笑收人头。[/b]
[b]游戏时间20小时，我路遇一群流寇内讧，让亨利二话不说搭弓上箭，在这么抖的手上射8中2，难能可贵，近半小时拉扯中，终于为民除害，拾掇拾掇一下，策马而去。[/b]
[b]游戏时间40小时，拉泰比武大赛，决赛上，我紧盯着对手那身上随时变化的UI转盘图标，在对手凌厉攻势下，丝毫不差地连续按下数次Q键后，亨利还以漂亮招架后，顺势反击。[/b]
[b]游戏时间60小时，我虽为拉泰比武冠军，亨利又一身板甲加持，但是被一帮农民群殴就是不讲武德，莫怪我外乡人卑鄙。[/b]

而天国拯救的整体体验，可以简单地总结为低配版大表哥2的第一人称RPG，这里的低配更多只是指游戏体量，画面表现和叙事手法上的内容，但天国拯救的游戏内容深度和重复可玩性上，绝对是超过大表哥2以线性为主导的章节型游戏体验，甚至可以与上古卷轴相媲美，同时采用地图迷雾的探索设计，让天国拯救的罐头味近乎可以忽略。

除此之外，天国拯救让我最为赞叹的是，追求写实的设计理念，它有着最贴近现实的中世纪城堡和乡镇，而非那些过于戏剧化的迪士尼式城堡或者恶魔城式城堡，直观生动地将中世纪晚期动荡的欧洲社会和波西米亚的人文生活表现得生动多彩，并附有优秀的剧本故事所展现主线和支线任务，更是将一段历史（好的与不好的）鲜活地展现给玩家去品味，加上各种有趣的活动（比如骰子游戏），极大丰富了玩家的游戏体验。

最后游戏中这两首 [b]Till Our Heads Turn White[/b] 和 [b]Poverty and Famine[/b] 歌曲更是将中世纪的欧洲男人味表现得如此美妙真切，让我难以忘怀这趟中世纪的捷克之旅。

——————分割线——————Dividing Line—————

Kingdom Come is a game that would be in my personal top 5 games, and it's hard to imagine that it's a game released in 2018, which was a year full of all sorts of great games,  God Tier like Red Dead Redemption 2, God of War 4, and good stuff such as Dark Souls 1 remake, Celeste, Detroit: Become Human, Assassin's Creed, and more, but what's even more amazing to me is that Kingdom Come was released in February 2018, nearly half a year earlier than Red Dead Redemption 2's October, and the gameplay experience of Kingdom Come and Red Dead Redemption 2 has such a similar feel to it, such as realistic setting of the gameplay experience, content presentation with a sense of life, and a wealth of interesting and detailed content, it’s really surprised me that Kingdom Come appeared before Red Dead Redemption 2, while Kingdom Come has unfortunately become a foil to these great games in 2018.

Also Kingdom Come shares the same criticisms as Red Dead Redemption 2, with very long early stage, complex interaction content, repetitive content filled with a lot of daily routines based on the design for realism, and Kingdom Come’s the unique and difficult to learn combat. For my opinion on these issues, I personally feel that the core experience of an RPG with a realistic setting inevitably requires the player to invest a significant amount of time (and this time standard varies from player to player, and preferably consecutively) in order to adequately allow the player to actively feel where their own growth and points of interest lie, as well as gain their own familiarity with the people and objects of the world, as well as develop enough emotion for the protagonist's encounters and experiences, and then of course there's also the most important premise of whether or not the game can do all that, and for me Kingdom Come did, and did it well.

Here's a look at how Kingdom Come's realistic, fun and very difficult combat was able to change the experience from the edge of giving up to enjoyment for me.

[i]2 hours of play time, I just met Henry, a hothead young feller, and we raised the longsword together, both strange and exciting, than we half-assed our way to combat tutorials, immediately in the village looking for guards to fight, MY DEAR GOD, not that I blame you, Henry, you are afraid of a congenital handicap, the sword can't even be swung sharply, and what is wrong with your stamina bar, instantly exhausted, and the guards left swing, right stab, game over.[/i]
[i]20 hours of play time, encountered a group of bandits infighting on the way, I let Henry immediately took out the bow, 2 out of 8 with such shaky hands, NICE JOB Henry. Nearly half an hour of hard fighting, defeated all bandits, after a short rest, ride our horse and leave.[/i]
[i]40 hours of play time, Rattay tourney, the final, I keep a close eye on my opponent's shifting UI icons, and after pressing the Q button several times in a row flawlessly under my opponent's harsh attack, Henry returned the favor with a perfect parry and then counterattacked in the right direction.[/i]
[i]60 hours of play time, though I am the champion of the Rattay tournament, and Henry is armed with plate armor, how unfair it is to be swarmed with a bunch of peasants, so don't blame me for sneaky play.[/i]

The overall experience of Kingdom Come can be simply summarized as a budget version of Red Dead Redemption 2's first-person RPG, where budget version refers more just to the size of the game, the graphic performance and the narrative approach to the content, but Kingdom Come's depth of gameplay content and replayability is definitely more than Red Dead Redemption 2's linear, chapter-based gameplay experience, and can even be compared to The Elder Scrolls, while applying the map fog design to make Kingdom Come's exploration less Ubisoft-like.

In addition, what I admire most about Kingdom Come is the pursuit of realistic design concepts, which has the most realistic medieval castles and towns, rather than those overly flashy Disney-style castles or Castlevania-style castles in video game, directly and vividly expresses the turbulent European society and Bohemian folklife in Late Medieval Period in a vivid and colorful way, coupled with the excellent story presented in the main and side quests to show a piece of history (both good and bad) to the player to enjoy, as well as a variety of interesting activities (like dice games), which greatly enriched the player's experience.

In the end, the two songs in the game, [b]Till Our Heads Turn White[/b] and [b]Poverty and Famine[/b], are such a wonderful and lovely expression of medieval European masculinity that made my Kingdom Come’s adventure with Henry even more unforgettable.

149855170.review:
This is THE most immersive game I have ever played. This is a game where I actually had to go to the training ring for many hours a practice my swordplay. Instead of a scaling system where you play and level and get better toys and older stuff becomes irrelevant, this is a game that requires you as the controller to actually learn and improve. Even things as simple as making potions becomes an involved process. The story isn't anything insane and grand, but I personally believe that is because this game sets out to be as realistic as possible and in so doing, provides a straight forward narrative. I still enter this world in my dreams and just walk around. While Skyrim would reward you with a dungeon or treasure by exploring the map, this game just rewards you with something beautiful or a simple and subtle tale to be told. 

And of all things... the map!! Pure bliss. If you are someone who likes maps then it is worth getting this game to just stare at its very original and unique map and enjoy. 

This will forever be a top 10 game for me and easily number one in the immersion category. If you are looking for action and a game that scales, this is not it. If you're looking to be completely transported back in time and live out your dream of being a night, this is it.

149792036.review:
Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a game that tries to be as realistic as possible in its depiction of medieval Bohemia. It is not a typical fantasy RPG with magic, dragons, and elves, but rather a historical simulation with a rich story, immersive gameplay, and stunning graphics. The game is set in the year 1403, during a civil war between the half-brothers King Wenceslas IV and King Sigismund of Hungary. You play as Henry, a young blacksmith who survives a brutal attack on his village and joins the resistance against Sigismund’s army. Along the way, you will meet many interesting characters, face moral dilemmas, and shape the course of history.

The game’s main strength is its attention to detail and authenticity. The game world is huge and full of life, with realistic landscapes, architecture, clothing, weapons, and combat. The game also features a complex system of skills, perks, reputation, and dialogue choices that affect your interactions with the world and its inhabitants. The game does not hold your hand or guide you through a linear path, but rather lets you explore and discover things at your own pace. You can choose to follow the main story, or branch out into various side quests, activities, and mini-games. You can also customize your character’s appearance, equipment, and playstyle, whether you want to be a noble knight, a cunning rogue, or a charismatic bard.

The game’s main weakness is its technical issues and bugs. The game is very demanding on your hardware, and may suffer from performance problems, crashes, glitches, and save corruption. The game also has a steep learning curve, and may frustrate some players with its realistic and challenging mechanics, such as hunger, thirst, sleep, injuries, diseases, and limited saves. The game’s combat system is also very complex and realistic, requiring you to master different weapons, stances, strikes, blocks, and counters. The game does not have a difficulty setting, and some enemies may be too hard or too easy for you depending on your level and equipment. The game also has a lot of historical and cultural references, and some players may find it hard to follow or understand the story and the characters without some prior knowledge or research.

Overall, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a game that offers a unique and immersive experience for those who love history, realism, and role-playing. It is not a game for everyone, and it may require a lot of patience, dedication, and tolerance for its flaws. But if you are looking for a game that will transport you to another time and place, and let you live out your own medieval adventure, then Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a game that you should definitely try.

149690522.review:
I’m playing in Hardcore Mode on my first attempt so my experience may differ from others.  Here's what I take away from the game.  Note I am not using any mods.

1st  Hardcore mode:  I recommend this mode for a more real/immersive feel.  From the start you have to pick at least two "negative perks" for your play thru.  Depending on what you pick, will depend on when and how they'll activate.  Cool concept.  I went with Nightmares and Sleep walking.  So randomly when I sleep, I wake up scared sheetless and sometimes I have absolutely no clue where I am when this happens.  It sucks and it's fun at the same time.  Nothing is guaranteed in this game it seems.  No compass so I have to rely on landmarks, rivers, roads, stars, the sun to find my way around, compare to map.  It’s not a big deal, after a while, you learn the roads.  I really enjoy this game with no compass even when in a vast forested area searching for something at night time.  I'm not being sarcastic, it's a blast cause you know immersion.  No fast travel is no big deal.  Things cost more, and sell for less, but money becomes a non issue after a while.
2nd Combat:  It’s a bish.  Again nothings guaranteed it seems.  I fought against 4 guys at the same time and won, and I’ve gone against 3 guys and lost.  Some ppl will not like the combat.  It’s a dance in this game and not a mash attack button and receive loot.  It’s hard, but if you approach it with caution, take your time, use terrain to aid you, you’ll have a better chance.  In normal mode they have this icon on the enemy, not in HC mode.  You just have to watch the enemies’ attacks and react.  The target lock can suck with multiple enemies, there’s a mod for it I understand.  I recommend using all the weapon types as well.  The bow really sucks till you’re like around I want to say lvl 7 in it.  Combat is a game breaker for some.  Dogs are OP, fear the dogs.  You can't outrun them either so don't try.  Just let them gnaw on your arm, get beat down by 4 others, and cry, then reload.   Hopefully they're not still there when you come back.
3rd Graphics:  I have to run it on the third to highest setting for a avg of 50fps.  My computer is like 2018 that I built.  It's starting to get dated I see from this game.  Ryzen 5 2600X, GTX 1660 Ti running Gforce thru monitor to get the 140hz refresh rate.  It's nice but yeah dated.  If I choose the second to highest graphics setting my FPS is 35-40.  Even still on the 3rd to highest graphics settings I picked, I get sometimes 5fps cutscene hiccups.  I bare thru it, voice is fine but graphics lag.  I'll just mention here that I did have a few game breaking bugs.  One where I was just crouching thru the forest on a slope and clipped thru the ground, broke both my ankles, like an invisible hole and no way to get out.  Other was Closing a door, and game crash.  Sometimes alt tabbing too much does this too.  Gotta be checking that wiki sometimes.  Game breaking bugs wouldn't be so bad, but playing hardcore mode I can only save by finding a bed that allows me to sleep and save, not just sleep, and/or potion.  Potions are freaking heavy and I don't save often via pot unless absolutely necessary cause I only carry 3 on me at a given time.  
4th.  Gameplay.  Doesn't matter who you're fighting, what weapon they have (if any), it's always intense.  I had a bandit, unarmed, almost beat me down.   Dueled a guy in the woods for 5 min straight, both of us with short sword and shield, and it was epic.  I won that battle. Most epic moment was, go into woods, wolf charges at me, I pull back on bow, release arrow right as wolf is at my feet, I missed, then my dog attacks the wolf, I draw back on bow, give myself 6 feet of distance, the dogs are rolling on the ground, I released the arrow right as my dog got off the wolf, and I shot that poor bastard wolf right in the head, and it slumped over and died.  Amazing.  The game doesn’t hold your hand, well not really.  You’ll be given a task but it’s up to you on how you pull it off.  That’s not always the case.  Often there’s a quest perimeter that you’ll need to be in to find what you’re looking for.  

5th My complaints:  1. Mutt!!!  Howls too much, bumps into me too much, I’ve beaten that dog a few times cause he aggravated me so much.  I’ve learned to tell him to stay if I’m doing anything important.  2. Stolen items.  I can steal whatever I want, and as soon as I do, I can move it to my horse’s inventory and now I don’t have to worry about getting caught.  It’s broken imo.  Horse can be across the map too and you’ll still have access to its inventory.  3. Lockpicking.  My only complaint is the difficulty gap between hard and very hard locks.  Currently, majority of very hard locks I can’t even attempt to open.  What’s the point of going back to these chests anyway?  By the time I do, I won’t need to for money.  I’ll just go jump some bandits and take everything they have.  4. Perks.  I hate perks.  At least in this game, in HC mode, I feel many are too OP.  The game is so much better not taking some of these perks.  There’s a lot of perk points I have just sitting there that I won’t apply, ever.  I like getting better using a weapon sure, unlocking combos is cool.  Some are just broken like, Master Strike for example.  5. Armor.  Yes!  Why use anything other than Dark stuff.  Also, it doesn’t take long to get the best armor set, so everything else is just vendor candy.  6.  You get dirty way too quickly.  There’s a mod for this though.  7. Fighting like more than two ppl is most certainly going to mean you’re going to die.  That’s okay cause feels that’s what would happen in RL.  It’s that darn target lock.  I think there’s a mod for this too.  I’m making the case for some mods.  8. This double sided.  The Rain at night time.  When this happens, I just crouch in the forest and cry cause I can’t see a thing.  I have to wait for it to stop.  Slows me down, but ehh I just look at it as more realism.  9. When a perk activates at night time.  I don't ever usually use a torch unless I'm playing this game in the day time in RL.  10. Time. Hurry up you stupid tailor of Rattay and open the shop already OMG!!!

6th My Praises:  1. Henry.  Dude is a trip.  I did a fetch quest, went to turn it in, and Henry was like.. I got all the F’n stuff!!  I died laughing cause that’s how I felt too.  2. The story.  That’s all I’m gonna say about that.  3. The dialogues are great and some of these quests are not how I expected things to go.  4. The world map.  This is a really good map.  There’s no zones.  It can be dangerous anywhere.  5. I’m going to say combat cause it’s so intense and not guaranteed I’m going to win.  6.  Multiple ways to complete most quests.  How you do it is up to you.  7. How they did their best to make this based on real history.  I'm looking forward to see what other titles this developer comes out with.  8. The game is pretty and music is great too.   I give this game a 7/10,  Game crashing bugs, the feeling like I'm becoming a god over the world doesn't make sense for a realism game.  It has a lot going for it though which is why I'll be beating this game.  Can't say I'll do another play thru though.

149653652.review:
"Kingdom Come: Deliverance" tears open the player's heart, drawing them into an era replete with grandeur and strife. It's an ode to meticulous storytelling, forging a profound connection between the player and the game. The landscapes are like paintings come to life, with every meadow, forest, and village crafted by the developers' hands to create a world that breathes and beats.

Emotionality flows from every aspect of the game, whether through the poignant fates of its characters or the dramatic twists of its main story. The player is not just an observer but a living part of the narrative, with choices that carry weight and consequences that can alter the course of history.

The graphics are a feast for the eyes, capturing medieval Bohemia with stunning attention to detail. The changing times of day and weather conditions do more than beautify—they affect gameplay and interactions.

However, the control scheme can be a challenge; it's complex and requires acclimatization. The combat system, though deep and rewarding strategic thinking, can initially be off-putting, especially for those expecting an easily accessible action RPG.

The dialogues in the game are carefully crafted, full of historical references and a language usage faithful to the 15th century. They're not just informative but also emotionally charged, contributing significantly to the atmosphere and immersion.

Yet, "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" is not without fault. Its ambitious nature leads to technical issues, from bugs to occasional performance dips. The save system, which relies on "Saviour Schnapps," is an innovative but controversial design choice that can make the game unnecessarily punishing. These flaws can break immersion and test patience.

Overall, "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" is an emotionally stirring, visually stunning, and narratively deep game that carves a unique niche in the world of role-playing games. It's not just a game, but a time machine that transports one to a bygone world, and despite its faults, remains a gem for those willing to engage with its demanding yet rewarding experience.

Possibly my favourite Medieval era/style RPG ever (to date). 

The game play is absorbing and in depth, the characters are well written and the historical context is engaging. 
My one criticism would be that the tutorial/Prologue is very 'light' on some of the more crucial aspects of the game mechanics and the 'learning curve' can be very steep at times.
But once you get past the beginner stage as a player, this is an absolute gem of a game and still very playable some 5 years after it was first released.

The language, and some of the themes and cut scenes in the game, make in very NOT suitable for children.

I really hope that a KCD 2 is in the pipeline but Warhorse Studios are keeping very tight lipped about what they are working on and there has been no confirmation that they are even considering a KCD 2 - BUT they are working on something and there have been no announcements or hints as to what it is - so we can hope!

149482152.review:
Gameplay (9/10):
Kingdom Come: Deliverance sets itself apart by striving for a high level of historical accuracy. You won't find dragons, or fantastical creatures here. Instead, you play as Henry, a blacksmith's son caught in a whirlwind of political intrigue, war, and personal growth. The game's melee combat system is perhaps its most notable feature. It eschews traditional hack-and-slash mechanics for a more methodical, skill-based approach that demands precision and timing. While it can be frustrating to learn, once mastered, it's deeply satisfying and rewarding.

The game also excels in its quest design and world-building. The story is well-written and engaging, with morally gray choices that impact the outcome. The open-world nature of the game allows you to approach quests in multiple ways, making each playthrough feel unique.  However, there are some minor bugs and inconsistencies, which can occasionally disrupt the immersion. Additionally, the save system, which relies on checkpoints and a limited-use save potion, can be frustrating for players.

Immersion and Realism (10/10):
The level of realism in Kingdom Come: Deliverance is truly remarkable. The game pays meticulous attention to historical details, from clothing and architecture to the way people spoke and behaved in the 15th century. This commitment to authenticity contributes to a deep sense of immersion, making you feel like you've stepped into a time machine.

The day-night cycle, dynamic weather, and the need to eat, sleep, and maintain personal hygiene add to the realism. Combat injuries and weapon degradation are also a constant reminder of the harsh realities of the period.

Overall (9/10):
Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a unique and captivating experience for those seeking a historically accurate, immersive RPG set in a beautifully realized medieval world. While it has its share of technical hiccups, its deep storytelling, challenging combat, and commitment to realism make it a must-play for fans of open-world RPGs and history buffs. It's a game that will transport you to a different time and keep you engaged for hours on end.

149293659.review:
Timeline by Michael Crichton is one of my favorite books. No, it's not literary gold, but it's a rollicking adventure that really put me in the place of someone going back in time to medieval France. When I read there was a video game based on it I was excited, but couldn't get my hands on a copy. 

Ten years later I built a gaming PC and wanted the first game I played as an adult to be something awesome, and this game delivered beyond my expectations. I know it's nothing about time travel, so the connection with Timeline is really just that it gave me the same feeling of adventure and immersion. 

I know the combat turns people off, but for me it was one of the best parts. Combat is FRUSTRATING, and you suck at it, mug like a blacksmiths son would in real life without training. And even after being decently well trained multi-person combat is rough. You don't walk through enemies, you learn how to poison, sneak, and bide your time. 

I can't describe everything that made this game great for me, but I hope anyone who yearns for that adventure in a time and land apart from our own will give it a try. That being said, two hours (the cutoff for a noquestionsasked refund I think) isn't enough to decide. I was 12ish hours in before I knew I was hooked. The lock picking and haggling really really confused me, when a buddy told me those mechanics are common in games I figured I was just being an idiot and redoubled my efforts. 

Also the time on here is wrong for reasons. I took about 180 hours for my first playthrough.

More of a "life of a medival peasant simulator," this game will start you with nothing and no abilities, and literally everyone will beat the shit out of you. There's very little hand-holding and nothing stopping you from taking on enemies WAY above your level, so if you like tough games you may appreciate this game. This game is very difficult, so you need to pick your fights very carefully. To improve fun I recommend getting an "infinite quicksaves" mod to ensure that you don't end up having to keep re-doing huge journeys when you get murdered by angry peasants.

Where this game shines is the side-quests, many of which are hillarious. It's also good to do side quests since if you rush the main campaign you'll run into overlevelled guys really fast.

149087604.review:
TLDR: Is this the perfect game with flawless systems that everyone will love? No it isn't. It is a game that has conceptually amazing systems that only seem to have been half-baked. Despite this, I still think it is worth picking up when it is on sale because there are many gems hidden in the pile of bugs, crashes, jank, and design problems.

I have a big love/hate relationship with this game. Having followed its development since 2012, you can imagine my disappointment with the game's buggy launch. I had to refund the game because I couldn't get past the first few quests in Skalitz without either crashing or encountering a game breaking bug that would prevent me from progressing at all. I bought the game again about a year later and had almost the exact same experience I had before, so I refunded the game once again. About another year after that, I decided to give the game another shot because it was on sale for $15. I played it again and actually made it a little bit through the story, only to have my save get corrupted. It sat in my steam library for another year until one of my friends started to play it, so I decided to give it another shot.

I'm glad that I kept trying to play this game after all these years because when it shines, its very bright. There are so many cool and unique concepts and moments in this game that are well worth your time investment if you can make it past all of the garbage. The story is generally pretty good and it weaves in actual history pretty well. Most of the quests and NPC interactions are fantastic, and I really enjoyed a lot of the characters. How could you not like discovering that the local pastor is actually a former soldier, only to get shit-faced drunk with him and raise hell in the town, just to get dragged into having to give his morning sermon for him because he was too hungover? Interactions like that are what make this game worth playing despite all of its faults.

The RPG mechanics are done fairly well, but I believe the game could have benefited much from having a much larger perk selection. Towards higher levels I found that after taking all of the perks I wanted for my play-style that the only perks I could choose from anymore were actually just worse than if I didn't take them at all. Certain skills like hunting feel absolutely pointless, while skills like speech are almost essential. Alchemy is very cool and I would like to see more games implement this system in the future, but it has a very big problem: you don't have to use it, at all. Why would I brew my own potions when every bandit I come across has 2-3 of the really good potions on them?

Combat skills suffer from the combat system itself. At first glance you might think this game has in depth combat, but you would be mistaken. You start the game as a peasant that can hardly hold a sword, but you can quickly gain more strength/agility/warfare/defense/weapon skills and perks that add more depth to fighting. The progression feels really good to start because there is a noticeable difference after only a couple of hours of playing with how you can dominate fights that earlier would have killed you. Then you notice that the enemies are scaling with you. Those cool combos that you unlocked for your weapon of choice no longer work because the enemy just master strikes or perfect blocks you every other hit. Then you start waiting for enemies to attack you so that you can master strike and it just turns into a waiting game. Or you can just clinch an enemy to death in a corner. The combat starts out feeling really good, but then just devolves into every bandit you fight being a master combatant in plate armor. Some people in this game's community will try to say that different weapon types perform different jobs such as swords being very good against unarmored targets while maces are only good against armor. I would like to disagree very much, seeing as how I could 1-3 shot most enemies wearing plate armor with my longsword from halfway through the game till the end. If you want to breeze through the game's combat even more easy, just use a bow. Archery is so mind-boggingly easy and overpowered that if you are in any way accurate, you can 1 shot any enemy in the game from the very beginning. I think the combat in this game has a lot of potential, but it just doesn't fully deliver on any aspect and I can only assume was rushed in production.

Sneaking and thieving are very under powered, until they aren't. For some reason there is a weird wall right at the beginning of level up sneaking where you can't hide from anybody, and then you level up a couple of times and all of a sudden you are Batman. Some missions that require sneaking or stealing are made completely trivial by having a decently leveled sneaking and lockpicking skill because for some reason after a certain level, people can't see you at all anymore when you are crouched. Many times I was able to knock out/stealth kill/pickpocket NPCs right in front of others and they wouldn't react or would just walk away. Combine this with having near infinite wealth from lockpicking stores and you can break the game's economy very early and easily. That being said, you can break this game's economy just by walking on the road right outside of town and killing the 6 bandits wearing full Milanese plate, put their gear on your horse and then go back to town and selling it for more groschen than the lords make in a year.

My next point is mostly just a nitpick, but sometimes it really frustrated the hell out of me. Why can Henry take a bath and get his clothes laundered, just to walk 20 feet down the street and be absolutely covered in dirt? Take a bath, immediately get on your horse after you leave the time skip screen so you don't have to touch the ground and ride directly to the spot you need to go and dismount so you can interact or talk with someone. Did you touch the dirt on the side of the road when you got off the horse? Instantly covered in shit, piss, and blood. Everyone comments on how much you stink and look like you got the piss beat out of you. With that being said, the layered clothing/armor system in this game is a really good system I hope carries over into more games. Being able to wear a gambeson underneath mail which is in turn underneath plate is cool and I've always been a big fan of games that implement it.

This all leads me to the biggest problem I have with this game: constant crashing and game breaking bugs. They still exist, and they still suck. I finished my first and last playthrough with 102.2 hours recorded on steam. In game my save only has 72.8 hours on it. I'll admit that I save scummed a little bit in this game, so we'll be generous and say that I lost 8 hours of game time due to restarting when things went wrong. That still leaves a whopping 21.4 hours of game time that I lost completely due to the game crashing or bugging out before I could save again. This wouldn't be a problem in most other games because of things like auto-saving or just being able to save on the fly, but the only way you can do that in this game is by using an in-game item called Savior Schnapps, or by exiting the game completely which will save it. Alternatively, you can save the game by sleeping in certain beds. I can only guess how many times I finished a quest and wanted to save afterward, but had already used all of my Savior Schnapps and didn't want to have to exit the game completely to save. All of that progress only to be on the way to a merchant to buy more schnapps or to a bed to sleep just for my game to crash, rendering everything I had just done void. Please for the love of God just let me save when I want to in KCD2.

149008219.review:
In September 2023 I knew almost nothing about this game. I’d been mentally tuning it out since first hearing about it because someone complained about the lack of American-style skin-colour diversity in 1400s Bohemia and the gamergate-loving lead designer, instead of responding with the appropriate “lol”, went full toxic ape and as a result the alt-reich gaming crew took up this game as one of their champions in racial purity. I’ve no idea if they continued to love and pedestal this game – I’ve tuned it and, by extension, them  :)

But then I saw an interesting map, so looked up some youtube videos (Sawman UK, Neon Knight, Knight Arcade), and boy was I INTERESTED. Looking around, it turns out to be highly praised and constantly recommended. I would say it’s a shame I didn’t pay attention to this on release, but it seems like it was full of game breaking bugs and didn't even have the ability to save on exit on release, so I’m kind of glad I’ve only just encountered it and only had mildly annoying bugs. (Plus, my PC back then would have melted when playing it)

Since September I've spent 181 hours completing this game, and aside from a bit of a sag and lull at the end, it was well worth it. I think the devs should definitely have cut some fat and concentrated on the main quest line, and I don't think it really needs the DLCs. 

181 hours is how long it took me to fully complete the game, including all the side quests, in a single non-hardcore run. I almost never used fast-travel, because it wastes times and galloping around the countryside is fun. I would occasionally reload to try different conversation options or ways of solving quests etc. I also hoarded way too many bits of enemies kit and amassed a fortune I didn't need. But not-doing that might only shave a few hours off. The rest of the time was spent mauling bandits and interrogating filthy peasants, as the  game intended.

After 181 hours it's surprisingly hard to write a review of the game. Infact, due to the sheer amount of content, it's easy to have a massive list of bugs, jank, problems etc. The game is full of eastern european B-grade game dev jank, so it's impossible to avoid any when playing. You just have to skim over it to get to the amazing game underneath. It's very easy to ignore when the game is as entertaining as this. So I'll start with the positives:

* Playing as a bumbling teenage son of a blacksmith who can barely hold a sword, can't read, can't hold his booze, and doesn't know what to usefully say to anyone is a great place to start the game. Then watching/controlling Henry as he starts to piece his life together and grow in skill and aptitude is very satisfying. It wears a tiny bit thin by the end, as it's a game after all and you end up godlike, but at the start it's a very interesting situation to be in.

* The music is amazing and extremely moving, even when divorced of the context in the game. I rarely listen to game soundtracks outside of a game, but KCD's has made it into my rotation. 

* The save system is annoying at first (especially after a crash!) but after a while you begin to see its genius. Especially that the non-bed saves making you slightly drunk, as being drunk messes up a lot of the stealth capabilities (ignoring the late game skill), so saving RIGHT before doing something risky can actually make it worse. They're really trying to force you to "live with your actions" etc. Eventually though the RPG part catches up and saving becomes easy and often, breaking the tension.

* The game has some beautiful vista and landscapes. I think the last time I enjoyed stopping and looking out to the distance was Far Cry 2. And once you know the lay of the land there's something magical about spotting the town in the distance and knowing that's where you're heading. Traversing the landscape isn't a chore in this game (except near the end, where you have to ping pong about the place) and so it's very easy to ignore the fast travel and just take it all in, navigating down the roads. 

* The exploration of the map works really well. It's not just that they have the fog-of-war on the paper map, but also that they stage early encounters to make it seem like exploration is as dangerous as it "should be".

* If you let the main story line drag you along in its course then it's quite the thrill ride, and it's very engaging. The writing and plotting is done very well and it's on par with some TV series, despite most game narratives being absolute babified nonsense.

* The voice acting for most of the major characters is great. The supporting cast is pretty good, if not clearly the same few actors. There are some real stinkers though. 

Then onto my most major and important gripe: They messed the start up.

There's an amazing open world RPG awaiting you here, but you'll be hard pressed to find it because the game tries its hardest to scare you off. I know that there's only so much time to go around, but pro-tip for Warhorse studios: POLISH THE FUCK OUT OF THE START OF THE GAME.

The first NPC you talk to -- it's literally forced on you by the game -- is Henry's mother. She's the worst voiced character in the game, and she's the most poorly animated. I had to pause the first conversation and go into the settings to figure out if my game is broken, because her face wasn't even moving when she was speaking. After numerous attempts I just watched a few Let's Plays and nope, everyone's game is like this. Now, after playing the entire game it turns out that almost all of lip syncing and cinematic animation is terrible at times. It goes way beyond uncanny valley into Team American levels of puppet flapping. Frankly, I learnt to read the subtitles and ignore the wobbly faces. But this is the VERY FIRST INTERACTION. Polish it! Hardcode it. Make it GOOD.

And then, after a very, very long introduction / tutorial chapter (literally hours long), you're tasked with running away from trouble, first on foot, then on horse. This is an emergent, time-sensitive situation. It's desperate. The mechanics of the game make YOU feel as desperate s Henry is. So how does this jank fest deal with that situation? In the worst way possible: stupid pop-up boxes full of text that you have to read, whilst learning the controls and mechanics, and trying to avoid getting your head caved in. And then when it makes you get a horse in a desperate escape more text text text is there to tell you how a horse works, WHILST THE GAME IS RUNNING. You're far too busy trying to make this stupid horse gallop properly or figure out why it's tired to read this text properly, assuming you read it in time. And then it gets worse: As you're escaping there's all these spam pop up boxes about camps and conciliatory crosses and town names and other pure nonsense that has no place being in a life-or-death horse-chase. The game trains you to read these boxes because they're vital, and then immediately punishes you by spamming that area with irrelevant, distracting noise. They should have deactivated that system until the introduction finishes. It diminishes the thrill-ride that the story is trying to show you.

The solution is obvious: Just introduce whistling and horses before you need them. There's plenty in the village, task Henry with taking one for a joyride or something.

I thought it might just be me, playing this years after release, with DLC installed etc so I hit up youtube and nope, once again not only is it everyone but it's like this on release. Agonisingly stupid. I can understand why a lot of people never get past the intro. Had I not watched those youtube videos I never would have carried on.

So honestly, stick with the game until you get the first intro chapter done. That's when the main game starts and it really opens up and you're left with a beautiful pearl of a game.


I had a large list of minor gripes, but this Steam review can only be so-long!

148939146.review: Es un mal juego de principio a fin. Me lo compre por nostalgia para jugarlo con los DLCs y no lo devuelvo por que me lo pille por 10€ en otra pagina. Su sistema de combate es "interesante", pero solo en un combate 1 vs 1 contra un enemigo mas débil que tu, en cualquier otro caso, es aburrido y frustrante, aburrido por que no te da ningún tipo satisfacción y frustrante por que por mucho que lleves una armadura de buen nivel y un arma de mucho daño, si te hacen un sangrado antes de terminar el combate, se acabó, o te mueres durante la pelea o te mueres a lo poco. Además, de que es un sistema que no funciona, he tenido este juego en consola y recuerdo no poder luchar, por que pasaba de un lado al otro del cursor en cuanto se te movía el joystick un segundo, pero es que en pc lo que ocurre es que tienes que estar pendiente del click derecho, del izquierdo, de la q y del alt, a la vez que tienes que recordar los combos, los cuales dudo que alguien pueda hacer contra un verdadero enemigo, por que la realidad es que por muy bien que te vaya en el combate, en cuanto tu enemigo te haga un agarre parece que se tira un dado para ver quien empuja a quien. Saliendo del tema del combate esta el "realismo", ese realismo que hace que tengas que estar pendiente de la dureza de las armas, armaduras y del grado de descomposición de la comida, a la vez que hace que después de robar una espada de 1'2k en el armero esperes un par de días y a nadie le importe, o que por algún motivo en esta Bohemia medieval a nadie le importa que el hijo del herrero escape de un castillo en el que un noble le ha dicho que se quede o le meta una paliza al señor de una ciudad, que por mucho que sea joven seria un alto noble. En definitiva, es un quiero y no puedo de campeonato, sinceramente, para la mierda que han acabado haciendo, que hubiesen metido un motor para la workshop y así al menos podríamos ver un juego interesante cuando los modders le metieran mano, pero como este juego ya tiene mas años que la tos y parece que los developpers tienen una visión tan purista de su juego que ni siquiera tienes acceso total a la consola de comandos, dudo que estuviese en sus planes.

148895784.review:
Kingdom Come Deliverance is a game that immerses you in a realistic and brutal medieval world. You play as Henry, a blacksmith's son who survives a massacre and joins a lord's army to seek revenge. You will explore a vast open world, interact with historical characters, and influence the outcome of a civil war.

The game is a hardcore RPG, with a deep and complex system that governs everything. You have to manage your hunger, thirst, sleep, and health. You have to wear appropriate clothes, weapons, and armor for different situations. You have to learn how to fight, read, ride, and craft through practice and training. You have to deal with the consequences of your choices and actions, which can affect the story and the world.

The game's story is engaging and well-written, with a lot of historical accuracy and detail. The game features a rich and diverse cast of characters, each with their own personality, background, and agenda. The game has a lot of quests, both main and side, that offer a variety of challenges and rewards. The game's dialogue is witty and realistic, with a lot of options and outcomes.

The game's presentation is impressive, with a stunning and detailed world that looks and feels alive. The game's graphics are beautiful, with realistic lighting, shadows, and weather effects. The game's sound is immersive, with authentic voice acting, music, and sound effects. The game's animations are smooth and realistic, with a dynamic and responsive combat system.

Kingdom Come Deliverance is a game that offers a unique and satisfying experience that is both challenging and rewarding. It is a game that transports you to a different time and place, and makes you feel like you are living in it. It is a game that will captivate you, test you, and move you. It is a game that you should not miss.

148886616.review:
Un amigo que estudia arte una vez me dijo que no hay nada peor que aquellos artistas que intentan hacer algo tan "realista" con sus cuadros que la cuestión deja de ser arte y pasa a ser la copia de una fotografía. Este es el ejemplo mas acertado para definir a este juego, si es que se lo puede llamar así. 

Entiendo y aplaudo la idea de los creadores de hacer que el juego fuese "realista", sin embargo, esta forma de hacer video juegos que ya muchos conocemos en otros títulos como RDR2, puede convertirse en un arma de doble filo cuando en pos de querer demostrar "lo realista", se vuelve algo soso y aburrido. 

El sistema de combate es por lejos "lo mejor y lo peor" que he jugado jamás. Lo mejor porque cuando tienes un duelo 1vs1 contra un NPC la experiencia es absolutamente magistral. Sientes la adrenalina y la necesidad de planear una estrategia en tiempo real para vencerlo y aunque la dificultad es grande con el tiempo te acostumbras a enfrentar el desafío. El problema es que el juego constantemente intenta ser "REALISTA", y en cierto punto te embarcas en una quest gastando 40 minutos de tu tiempo para que de manera random te embosquen 6 soldados de nivel muchísimo mas alto que el tuyo y terminen acabando contigo sin que puedas hacer nada, mandando esos 40 minutos de tiempo invertido a la basura, porque el juego no cuenta con autoguardado, dado que para hacer eso lo tienes que pagar. 

Dejen que me explaye aún mas sobre el punto anterior. Cuando te enfrentas a uno o a dos NPCS enemigos, siendo nivel bajo, el juego se vuelve dificil, pero con la estrategia adecuada puedes salir victorioso. El problema es cuando te emboscan 4 arqueros, 2 lanceros y 2 espadachines de nivel superior. Agrega eso que te atacan por puntos ciegos los cuales el sistema de combate no te permite detectar, haciendo que mueras sin siquiera tener chance de reaccionar. Es una dificultad artificial e injusta al punto que deja de ser disfrutable. No es como en los soulslike donde mueres mil veces pero en cierta forma reconoces que fue tu culpa por no saber encarar al boss. Aquí la curva de aprendizaje es inexistente, vas a morir porque si y ya, haciéndote perder el tiempo invertido sin siquiera aprender nada, porque injustamente, nada puedes hacer.

Y quiero aclarar algo para finalizar, porque de seguro muchos fanboys del juego te dirán que el título no te gusta porque no sabes jugar. Me fascinan los juegos difíciles, he vivido horas maravillosa con la saga Dark Souls e incluso con la saga God of War en dificultad superior, justamente porque son juegos que entienden que tanto la curva de aprendizaje, como el reconocimiento al tiempo invertido son importantes. Pero aquí con esta auto felada de pene que hacen los desarrolladores para mostrarte, "LO REALISTA" que es el juego, echan por la borda las ganas de recorrerlo. 

Por todo ésto y mas, si sos una persona que gusta de probar simuladores de lo que sea y no te molesta echarte horas haciendo una quest para que de la nada el juego te ponga un desafío cuasi imposible que te haga empezar de cero sin que ni siquiera entiendas que hiciste mal, aventúrate y juzgalo en base a tu experiencia. Pero si eres como yo, una persona que luego de trabajar/estudiar solo quieres sentarte a vivir una experiencia entretenida y sentir que te escapas del mundo un rato, no te lo recomiendo para nada. Mejor dale una oportunidad a los Souls o a Mount & Blade y huye de la tentación de jugarlo. No vale la pena sabiendo la cantidad de otros títulos del mismo estilo con los que la vas a pasar mucho mejor.

148724239.review:
One of my favorite games ever.
I have never played a game that's this immersive, i fell in love with this game. Granted the combat is a bit clunky, but it's SO good once you get the hang of it and you can honestly look past it. 
The voice acting, is amazing.
The story is great.
The sound design is phenomenal.
The sheer amount of historic accuracy when it comes to church designs, the villages, environment, it still blows my mind.
The amount of quests that will give you different outcomes depending on what you choose to do in some of them. You can easily get 50-60 hours in your first play through. I personally managed to get 102 hours out of this game, but i squeezed it near the end, because i didn't want the game to be over.

It's realistic in the fact that you are not overpowered, if say, you're jumped by 3 or more enemies with good armor, that knows how to handle their weapons you won't stand a chance unless you've trained hard enough and not even that may be enough to take them on. (yes, it can get frustrating, but if you were jumped back then by 3 people, they'd kick you around and pummel you to death.)

I will give this game a 9.5/10 rating, the only thing i wish they did better was the targeting system, it can get a bit frustrating. Even then It's a phenomenal game, and i can't wait for KC:D2.

148600296.review:
If you're wondering if you should get this game, buy ONLY the base game on a huge sale, Do not bother with the royal edition. ALL the DLCs ARE GARBAGE, BORING, TERRIBLY DESIGNED.

The base game is amazing, in a very unique way. This game has the most frustrating first 10 hours i've seen in any video game in my life and mastering that frustration requires immense patience and skill.

 You also need a bunch of mods, google "kingdom come deliverance must use mods and use all of them, trust me, this game does not allow you to save anywhere you want without mods and if you cant save anywhere you want you are going to suffer. Also get the brown wooden inventory mod because the base game one is flashy and terrible.

All that aside, this game begins you as a literal peasant who cant do anything, LITERALLY, you HAVE TO LEARN EVERYTHING. From sword fighting to all the way to READING. It's really satisfying towards the end of the game when you've done all that and see a super overpowered knight on your screen.

This game has the most realistic medieval settings, armor, world design and weapons i've seen in like ever. The best and the worst thing about this game is the amount of freedom it gives you as a player. You can do anything, you can also get into super frustrating situations if you don't do as the game wanted you to do, and the game barely tells you what to do so it's very easy to end in frustrating situations. This is why the unlimited saves mod is necessary. The game will also randomly decide to spawn 6 enemies on you while your fast travelling, which you can avoid or end up not avoiding and die. This is also why the mod is necessary.

The most fun i've had in this game wasn't the gameplay or the story, it was the messing around with the mechanics of the game to do the most goofiest things possible, what's that? you have to play medieval dice with this one guy and win to get the quest item? SCREW THAT, KILL EVERYONE, SURVIVE WITH 1 HP? YEAHH

The base game was amazing, and the story was actually pretty good, the world was beautiful, one of the best medieval games ever made. It REALLY needs a sequel, because the story ended on a to be continued.

Remember, if you get easily frustrated, want to play a game that works really well and doesn't break every 10 minutes, do NOT play this. You will regret your hours, if you do enjoy beating the frustration and figuring out the games engine yourself for hours on end and then be satisfied, because watching broken stuff work makes you happy, buy it on sale, You'll have a great time, figuring out how the game works is really rewarding.

9/10, Best medieval RPG out there, Needs a sequel.

A rare breed of game that focuses on realism and slow buildup and progression into what ultimately ends up being a rewarding and memorable experience.

The fighting is clunky, at first, but that makes it feel like you really are Henry struggling to fight until you get some real training under your belt. You get into a fight early on that you just can't win, because you have no idea how to fight properly. Despite this, combat is *not* the main focus of this game. It's diplomacy and investigation. I've spent more time running around between local towns figuring out where a pack of baddies are, trying to decipher the ramblings of a madman, and having fun with the local lords, negotiating alliances and gathering allies, trying to root out a bandit hiding in a monastery, than I did actually fighting enemies. One of the best games I've played. Especially if you want something different from what's out there these days but still close enough that you won't feel totally lost.
