148482339.review:
Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

Kingdom Come: Deliverance, the medieval RPG developed by Warhorse Studios, is a breath of fresh air in the gaming landscape, offering a unique and unapologetically immersive experience. After 6.6 hours spent wandering through the unforgiving medieval world of Bohemia, it's clear that this game is a labor of love for history enthusiasts and fans of deep, complex RPGs.

At the heart of Kingdom Come: Deliverance is its commitment to historical realism. The game transports players to 15th-century Bohemia, and it does so with meticulous attention to detail. The world feels lived-in, with realistic depictions of architecture, clothing, and daily life, immersing you in a time and place rarely explored in the gaming world.

The game's narrative centers around the tale of Henry, a blacksmith's son whose world is upended by war and political intrigue. The story unfolds with a sense of authenticity, eschewing fantasy elements in favor of a more grounded and historically plausible plot. While it may not be as grandiose or fantastical as some other RPGs, it succeeds in bringing a genuine sense of medieval life to the player.

Gameplay in Kingdom Come: Deliverance is similarly rooted in reality. Combat, for instance, is challenging and skill-based, eschewing the superhuman abilities often found in fantasy RPGs. It can be daunting at first, but as you hone your skills, it becomes deeply satisfying and rewarding. The same goes for other aspects of gameplay, such as hunting, lockpicking, and alchemy, which require patience and practice.

The game's attention to detail extends to the character interactions and choices you make. The reputation system can influence how NPCs react to you, and your dialogue choices carry weight, leading to meaningful consequences. The world feels dynamic and reactive, which adds a layer of complexity and authenticity to the experience.

While Kingdom Come: Deliverance excels in historical realism, this very feature can be a double-edged sword. Some players may find the game's steep learning curve and lack of hand-holding frustrating. The slow start and the initial difficulty curve in combat and other mechanics can be intimidating, requiring a certain degree of patience and perseverance.

Graphically, the game is impressive, especially considering its indie roots. The landscapes and environments are beautifully rendered, with attention to lighting and atmospheric effects. The character models, while not as impressive as some AAA titles, are nevertheless quite convincing.

In conclusion, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a refreshingly unique take on the RPG genre, offering a meticulously crafted historical world and gameplay that demands skill and dedication. With 6.6 hours played, you've had a glimpse into the game's immersive world and complex mechanics. While its steep learning curve and the realism might not be for everyone, those willing to invest time and effort will find a rich, rewarding experience that stands as a testament to the potential for historical authenticity in video games. It's a must-try for history buffs and RPG aficionados looking for something different.

Forewarning, I have yet to complete the main story. However, I am very much enjoying a lot of the game's mechanics. All of it seems to work well for the historical setting. It can be easy to get lost in the game absorbed in the ambiance. I will say that some of the NPC dialogue and cadence can be odd at times but it usually fits well with what is going on in the moment. But you will hear the regular reuse of actor voices and shared dialogue that doesn't feel so natural when encountered in a short span of time and space. That aside, the game can be quite entertaining.
Best of all is the learning curb for various activities, particularly combat and strategy. There seems to be a fair blend of character sheet skill progression, the player's improving skill in combat and situational awareness, and the quality of gear that rewards - or at times can punish - the combatant. Don't expect to just run into a group of NPCs and expect to survive in a "fair" one verse multiple assailants. At least not without improving on aspects of the aforementioned "trinity" that is Kingdom Come: Deliverance's combat system.

148442993.review:
Having sunk 460 hours into this game and completed all 82/82 achievements, I cant recommend this game enough.

As a big fan of the Elder Scrolls/Fallout series, i think this takes what those games offer and brings it to a whole new level. 
The story is excellent, the historical accuracy is refreshing and the skills system is thorough and rewarding.

The added realism can be very punishing but also very rewarding. Having read some of the negative reviews the combat system seems to be peoples main gripe, and whilst I admit it does take effort to learn even the basics, it is something you can master with a bit of patience and practice (Don't worry, after you finish the prologue you get some proper training)

The combat is another thing that they have made quite realistic, if you are in a fight and its 1v2, you are at a proper disadvantage, no matter how good your gear or skills are, if its 1v3 or 1v4 then you are forced to use the environment to your advantage, get good with a bow or be sneaky. Even when you are in the best armor with the best weapons the game has to offer. If a group of 5 or 6 unarmoured peasants with clubs descend on you, you should be able to slash them all down (and you usually will), but.... you just need to take one lucky blow to the back of your head for it to all start going south - REALISM!

The way you save in this game is by sleeping or drinking something called "Savior Schnapps" which is fairly common but not completely abundant in the early game. This is probably to prevent the people who save every 10 seconds so that nothing in the game has a consequence. However, its something quite commonly used to level alchemy, and the ingredients are very easy to get, so its going to be common for people to have hundreds of the laying around in the mid-late game.

The only thing I honestly don't like about this game is that there is no sequel announced yet. 10/10 from me - I think this is probably the most under-rated game on steam.

148300430.review:
Lo recomiendo con muchos 'peros' porque es un RPG peculiar. Si esperas un Skirym, ojo porque te puede llevar un chasco. Es un juego medieval histórico centrado en el realismo, por lo que tiene componentes de survival. 

Teniendo en cuenta que no ha sido desarrollado por un gran estudio, el resultado es impresionante. Pero tiene carencias y características que tienes que conocer antes de comprarlo. 

QUÉ DEBE SABER:

No es un mata-mata. Los combates son complicados y tienen consecuencias graves porque el equipo se desgasta y no te curas con pociones como en en un RPG normal. Aunque ganes acabarás con la ropa hecha jirones, parte del equipo destruido y lesiones que tardarán días en curarse. Eso si no tienes una hemorragia y no tienes nada a mano para hacerte un torniquete. Tienes que valorar qué combates merece la pena librar.

Hay que comer, beber y dormir con frecuencia. No hacerlo tiene consecuencias graduales cuanto más tiempo lleves sin hacerlo. Además, la comida se pudre, por lo que tienes que cuadrar los tiempos para no quedarte sin comida.

El guardado de partida está limitado. Solo puedes guardar partida durmiendo en una cama o utilzando una poción específica que no es muy abundante. Esto significa que tendrás repetir cosas si te matan, a no ser que hayas utilizado una poción.

El sistema de combate puede llegar a desesperar. La idea es buena, está inspirada en el sistema de FOR HONOR. Puedes lanzar ataques en diferentes direcciones, pero la ejecución no está muy pulida. El sistema parece estar roto, aunque impactes no sabes muy bien cuando haces daño y cuando no.

El sistema de aprendizaje de habilidades es similar a Skyrim, pero llevado un paso más allá. Al principio eres un completo inutil y tendrás que practicar mucho para ser competente en combate, sobretodo con el arco, que no tiene punto de mira.

Aunque el juego te de opciones para resolver las cosas por la via diplomática o el sigilo, hay partes donde tendrás que ganar un combate para avanzar en la historia principal, así que no puedes descuidar tus habilidades de combate.



QUÉ ME HA GUSTADO:

Las decisiones importan. No solo influyen tus decisiones en la historia, si no que además hay ciertas misiones que debes cumplirlas en un tiempo determinado o ya no podrás hacerlas.

El inventario y las estats son complejas. Hay varias capas de ropa y armadura y estas influyen en tu carisma y en tu capacidad de sigilo.

Generalmente el juego te da diferentes vías para hacer una misión en función de tus habilidades. 



LO QUE NO ME HA GUSTADO:

Tiene bugs importantes.

El control del caballo es terrible, sobre todo cuando va despacio.

El sistema de combate hace aguas cuando luchas contra más de un oponente. 

El combate no está muy pulido.

La necesidad de comer, beber y dormir se te puede hacer pesada.

148234440.review:
TLDR: Time-consuming RPG that will make you truly feel like a peasant boy->turn into a knight.

Pros: 
- Extremely believable game world; seemingly massive at first.  After 20-30 hours, the map will begin to feel small as you realize content never changes in towns (merchants always sell the exact same goods etc)
- Incredible graphics...can be a beast to get running smoothly at times
- Unique combat sets a rough early impression, but becomes more enjoyable as your character levels up in specific combat traits

Cons:
- Not respectful of the players' time.  The game features countless back-tracking fetch quests and frequent LENGTHY/DRY cutscenes 
- Inconsistent story quality.... you'll care at times, and fall asleep at others
- Instability...the game is plagued with quest-breaking bugs and occasional crashes

Overall, a great RPG... but it could've been 50 hours shorter.

148055979.review:
Here are some individual rankings

Combat: 
While the system is rather detailed it is very difficult to master or even be really good at. The issue I had with it is regardless of how good Henry was with defense or a particular weapon if you the player sucked at the combat system Henry also sucked at combat. I hope they improve this for the second game

Quests: 
In general the quests were good with indicators of where you needed to go next, however some times they were a bit vague. The main quest was better though.

Story:
I really enjoyed the story, it was pretty well done and I found myself caring for the characters as "people" and wanted them to thrive. Without spoiling anything there was one character in particular that I got a rather unhappy ending for in their quest and actually redid a large portion of the quest to try and get a better result

Romance:
This seemed to be tossed in as an after thought without is really amounting to anything other than a single tumble in the hay and the occasional gift when talking to them after. It would have been really nice if the relationship could have continued to grow or even if current events could be discussed later in the game instead of the same old ones each time

Dice Mini Game:
Loved it, enough said. It was fun to take all of someone's money in dice and I enjoyed stealing the special dice from people after I saw them use.

Save System:
Unique in that you had to drink a special drink to perform a Hard Save along with sleeping in an "owned" bed as kind of a "Quick Save". It would have been nice to have a few more save points. Such as after completing a fast travel having the game save because there is nothing worth than accomplishing a lot and then suddenly die because you run into a couple bandits and suck at the combat system.

I would rate this game a 7 out of 10 and cant wait for the second one to continue the story

147931815.review:
A Medieval Masterpiece!

I recently embarked on an epic journey through the beautifully crafted world of "Kingdom Come: Deliverance," and I can't help but sing its praises. This game has truly redefined my expectations for open-world RPGs, and I'm delighted to share my positive thoughts about it.

First and foremost, the attention to historical detail is nothing short of astonishing. From the meticulously recreated landscapes of 15th century Bohemia to the period-accurate clothing and architecture, "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" immerses you in a bygone era like no other game before. The dedication of the developers to recreate a historically accurate world is truly commendable.

One of the standout features of this game is its realism. The combat system, in particular, is a refreshing departure from the typical hack-and-slash approach seen in many RPGs. You truly feel like a medieval warrior, with each swing of your sword requiring precision and timing. The depth of the combat mechanics adds a layer of immersion that few games can match.

The story of "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" is equally engrossing. It's a tale of revenge, intrigue, and personal growth that keeps you invested from start to finish. The well-written characters and the moral choices you must make along the way add depth and complexity to the narrative, making it one of the most engaging RPG stories I've experienced.

The game's open-world design is a joy to explore. The lush forests, bustling towns, and sprawling countryside are teeming with life and detail. Whether you're hunting in the woods, engaging in medieval combat, or simply conversing with the locals, every aspect of the world feels alive and authentic.

Furthermore, the dedication of the development team to improving the game post-launch is admirable. They've actively listened to player feedback and released patches and updates that have enhanced the overall experience, demonstrating a commitment to their fanbase.

In conclusion, "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" is a triumph of historical accuracy, storytelling, and gameplay. It's a game that transports you to a fascinating period in history and allows you to experience it like never before. If you're a fan of RPGs and are looking for a truly unique and immersive gaming experience, do yourself a favor and dive into this medieval masterpiece. You won't be disappointed!

147707612.review:
Was having a boring day so I sat looking at my steam library for a while, scrolling up and down, see what would pop up among the mostly white noise of senseless purchases, most of which only makes sense under the lens of some sale stitched up in the hope of some future playday. And then I saw this again. It had happened before, and the sight of this game's name always brings the same feeling. I grin, looking at the letters, and the memories flood in. I get lost in reverie. 

Difficult to put it into words. Very rarely have I been so immersed, so invested in a role to play in, and been rewarded with so much fun. In that aspect, and having in mind that although this game is huge in every way, it's still a story driven game, I could compare it to game's like Skyrim, New Vegas, but there is something else in here. Maybe the historical setting, maybe the realism of the characters and their relationships, maybe the world-building and all the ways you can interact with it, how it feels like a huge accomplishment when you start getting a hang on the mechanics and develop some skills and you feel that effort and progression reflected in the way your "Henry" interacts with his world. I can imagine people complaining about this game, and probably if the setting doesn't pull you and keep you in, you'll never stick with it long enough to start reaping the rewards of your early effort. But this game, to me, really was something else.

If there is ONE game I could erase from my memory and play it all over again, it would be this one.

I'm neutral on this game.  Not really positive or negative.  If this is your thing, get it.  If it's not then don't.  I'm not recommending it because of the save system.

The game is fun.  The world is extremely well crafted.

However, the save system is absolute crap.  You have to craft items to save.  The game will auto save when finishing a mission.  There is no timed autosave.

That's a problem.  I like to spend a lot of time just exploring the world.  At one point I lost 2 hours worth of skilling up and farming because I got killed in an ambush.  

I quit for a while.  

When I came back I went to skill up archery doing the contests.  After about 30 minutes the game froze and I lost all my progress.

It's the only time the game has frozen or crashed on me.  But it happened when I was already pissed that there was no 10 minute autosave feature.

I don't really give a fuck what the developer thought they were doing by restricting saves.  I don't have time for this shit.  This game is aimed at adults with jobs and families.  I strongly suspect most of them don't.

Edit:  The save system in this game is absolutely shit.  I just lost 4 hours of playtime because of a crash.  I hadn't saved because I was just skilling up with the guard.  Four hours of progress gone in an instant...

Seriously.  Any Developer that thinks not having an autosave system is a good idea is a fucking moron that should spend the rest of their lives working for McDonalds.

Edit 2:  I've been running into more CTDs and have also been having trouble launching the game.  I often have to kill the process using the task manager because the process is hanging and unresponsive.  It usually launches the second time.

I would guess that I have lost 10+ hours of progress now due to the combination of CTDs and no autosave.  The largest chunck of that was a single 4 hour session that I had spent skilling up with the captain of the guard...  I hadn't saved because I had not yet run into many CTDs and wasn't going anywhere I might run into a lethal enemy.

For those who enjoy suffering.

147621024.review:
This is my third playthrough. My previous two were on PS4 (one in normal and another in hardcore). What to say? It's perhaps the first of its kind. A historical RPG with a wealth of possibilities. A very ambitious project with results far beyond expectations.

Is it perfect? No. Combat mechanics has its flaws, in particular with the camera and the flow of fights themselves (after a certain point all you do - specially versus multiple foes - is to move around and hit 'Q'). Also, there are still a few persistent bugs and clunky mechanics on character movement, environment, and NPCs.

Nonetheless, is it still a gorgeous game and worth every minute? Definitely. 

Building such a game was definitely no easy feat, and its beauty certainly surpasses its flaws. The immersive experience, the storyline, characters, and soundtrack justify giving it a shot by far and large.

For now, all I hope is that Warhorse will continue this promising genre (doesn't even have to be a sequel honestly) improving from KCD's experience and living up to its potential.

147440063.review:
Note: I've done a 60h playthrough on a pirated copy at launch before getting it on Steam.

I'd say this is borderline not recommended just because it's not for everyone. The strong suits of KC:D are the writing and the immersiveness but the combat is ungodly levels of unappealing. You get used to it after a while but at no point will anyone with a sane mind say it's anything short of bad. The saving system is kinda weird and will be sure to make you either stop playing (temporarily or not) or download mods to save at will. The stealth system isn't always reliable and you're kinda clueless as to when you're seen or not, sometimes NPC's will even see you commit a crime through walls. Aside from those major gripes,  it's a cool game. The immersion/RP possibilities (i.e.: feeling like you're living in medieval times) is sublime, the dialogue and side-stories are rich, the skills/stats are fun to progress, the weather is well-done and the views you can see in some parts of the map are just breathtakingly immersive. I also love the zero-to-hero approach they took, you can sorta feel Henry get smarter and stronger as you level up. I'd say a mix of the niche genre and the combat is what stopped this game from being a cult classic, with most people having sadly forgotten about this game less than 12 months after its release.

147438542.review:
Do you want to be a peasant turned knight adventuring in the medieval ages? You're a human being therefore the answer is obviously yes.

KCD gives you a grounded, historic and dare I say realistic medieval setting for you to journey through and enjoy as you please. However, this is not your story, this is Henry's, and often times you'll be disappointed and dissatisfied with the linear way it'll develop.

You may want to play through this rather relaxing game at a slower pace, but following the main story, even sporadically, will catapult you forward not only in time, but also in the social ranks, which is a big deal if you know anything about how society was in those times. It goes even as far as to have the typical Rockstar games' flaws of forcing you to do very specific things in only one way or face a Mission Failed. You'll groan as you fail side objectives for no reason, are forced into nonsensically paced missions with strict time and behavior requirements, and you may find yourself getting frustrated with how you may be tossed around.

Still, KCD delivers on its promise wholeheartedly. And you'll truly feel immersed in its detailed and lovely crafted world. Don't let the jank and the inconsistencies get to you, this is a fine and dandy medieval simulator with a less generic, more traditional, story told in a believable yet still engaging way.

Ps: if you tend to get sick playing first person games because of the character's height and all the bobbing, you will get so playing this one, and I don't think there's enough configuration settings to make it better. Using a console command to set the FOV to 90 solved the issue for me.

Addendum: The MOD that disables Master Strikes entirely is *MANDATORY* to get any enjoyment out of this game's combat. It is that bad, and I've played a lot of really janky and trashy games in my life. This is the worst combat system of them all.

147288693.review:
Spent so much time in this game already and I don't even think i'm halfway done. I did get the royal version or whatever it's called, the one with all DLC, so that probably added quite a lot of content to the base game, but still, one of the best RPGs I have played in recent memory. 
I really didn't expect such immersion, I do like some roleplaying myself, but this game really made me act as if I was there. Currently I have a thief/ rogue kinda play style, but I am excited for a future playthrough as a righteous knight. Most of the buildings look so good, beautifully painted insides, the church frescos especially made me wanna visit different churches and chapels  in-game, like Henry might have wanted to do when seeing them I suppose. Long story short, it's beautiful where it needs to be.  
A lot of the quests do not hold your hand, they give you clues on where, who, or what to investigate, maybe a very wide area on the map is marked, but no exact waypoints most of the time, which I really like. What you do, if you steal, get caught, lie, or if the NPCs are suspicious of you actually matters.  Armour and weapons again, look really nice, and you feel a sense of progression, learning how to fight better and how to approach different enemies based on their own outfits. I do feel that fighting more than, let's say, 3 enemies at once, is a real struggle. Not necessarily because of the combat difficulty, because based on how you choose to play, you can take quite a beating based on your armour, but because of the lock-on camera. Also the dogs, hate the armour-ignoring dogs that stun you for a few seconds. I chose to be more stealthy, so I didn't have to fight that much face-to-face let's say, but pulling out a combo or just an normal hit seems impossible sometimes. I suppose it's trying to replicate enemy skill levels, but being able to hit opponents with master strokes or counters only  transforms some of the encounters into a game of waiting, staring at each other until one of you attacks first and is inevitably countered. Again, might just be my inexperience in heads-on fights, but it did feel that way.

All-in-all, EXCEPTIONAL game,  I was so surprised after I bought it, I knew it was highly regarded, but I didn't expect to like it this much. With the exception of some little things, I do think it is a good play for any RPG enjoyers, and if you like medieval  stuff, then it becomes a must.  Warhorse clearly put a lot of love and dedication into this title, and I am looking forward to a potential sequel as well.

Most singleplayer, open-world, RPGs are extremely easy, hold your hand, type of games that offer no depth or challenge.  KCD stands out as it gives you very little tutorial and puts you in a dangerous, yet decorative, world.  You won't be forced to fight difficult enemies all on your own, but typically in this game you've got 2 choices.  Either fight enemies that you'll probably die to, or find a creative solution to your problem.  The combat may be clunky sometimes, but that improves the experience of struggling to improve your combat skills.  The RPG element to this game is also insanely in-depth, well made, and understandable once you give it time.  Lastly, I'd like to comment on just how good the sound design and music is.  I found myself really enjoying traveling as pleasant music played and I could hear every little thing happening around me whether it's my footsteps, the clanging from my armor, the chirping of birds, the muttering of bandits in camps, or the water rushing by me.  This is an insanely immersive game.  As for the story, while I have not completed the main quest yet, I'm really enjoying it as this is not your typical underdog bestowed with great powers or mighty knight with innate abilities.  KCD's story is about an unskilled peasant who struggles to find his place in the world motivated only by vengeance.  You are thrown into a difficult game just as Henry (the protagonist) is thrown into a difficult world and despite the progress you make, NPCs will still give you a hard time.

146996898.review:
Kingdom Come: Deliverance is one of the best games I've ever played. I recently watched the documentary about how they consulted with master fencers and swordsmen to make sure the combat was realistic and playable, and as someone who fences, it was fascinating and awesome! The way combat is approached in KC:D is ingenious, and I've never played anything like it before. But fear not, it's not incredibly difficult either, which is something I worried about upon first learning of this game. Even as someone who is relatively new to playing video games and usually stresses out about combat, the mechanics of KC:D were easy to learn. And again, they managed to make playing the game really feel like wielding a sword. I was very impressed and reminded of fencing techniques I'd forgotten about since being out of practice. 
The sheer amount of research the developers put into this game is worthy of praise. Combat aside, the game includes a historical "Codex," which has probably taught me more about medieval Bohemia than any history class I've ever taken or will ever take. Real locations, real people, and real events are included in this codex. Information about life in this era and all the details about any curiosities you may have while playing are presented in such a captivating and convenient fashion. So if you're a fan of learning history, this game has tons to offer! Honestly I feel like I was provided access to a graduate level textbook that just so happened to come in a game! Of course, if you're not too into reading or learning history, you can also just completely ignore the codex, and you aren't forced to read a bunch or learn anything you're not interested in.
My final point is that the story itself is amazingly well-written. I loved all of the DLCs too! I've seldom felt as emotionally moved by any form of media as this game has made me feel. It wasn't hard to grow attached to the protagonist, Henry, and before I knew it I was fully invested in his character and his story. I'm sure most people would feel the same as they follow him through this adventurous and touching tale of loss, hope, overcoming adversity, and finding redemption. There are also some wild plot twists that left me speechless, all while still seeming plausible and overall piecing everything together so well! 
I've gone on far too long already, but I'll finish by saying this: My only gripe with this game is that the sequel hasn't been released yet! I can hardly wait. Warhorse Studios, "may God be with you!"

146942682.review:
[h1]Steam needs a "meh" option[/h1]
At its core this is a pretty fun adventure RPG however that core is covered with clunky mechanics, bugs, and poor controls.

The good.
Story: It's a pretty standard hero's journey but well written, the nobles are not comically stuck up like most medieval stories. ++ on trope avoidance.

RPG level system: It's just unique enough to be different while following enough standard RPG styles to be easy to understand without reading a guide. 

Theme/Style/Xfactor: I don't really know how to describe this but when nothing is going wrong the game is extremely enjoyable. Wandering around town or going about on different quests always feels good. Even some jobs that are pretty tedious in other games like hunting are very fun, It's always a good sign when you can spend 1 hour IRL playing medieval hunting simulator and not notice how much time has gone by.

Combat: Combat is at its core a great idea with SOME pretty good mechanics BUT (read "the bad).


The bad:
Direction: This game is REALLY bad at telling you what's going on or what you SHOULD be doing. You have to do a lot of wiki/guide reading to have an enjoyable experience. You know in Elden Ring how there are no real quest markers and the like? Well it works in Elden Ring because the Devs knew how to drip feed you info on what you needed to know. In KCD you can game ruin without even knowing it by advancing to fast in the main story without doing certain side quests/training first. Also some mechanics are straight up hidden from you until you grind certain skills enough (particularly combat skills) 

Bugs/broken quests: It's very easy to break quest lines by picking the wrong dialogue option when talking to NPC's (i'm not talking about failing a quest btw) I currently cannot do the millers quest because I accidentally started a section of the quest that I already completed, so now I can't do anything since the quest giver wants me to pick up an item I already gave him. 

Movement: This game makes moving around ANY obstacle an absolute disaster, A dog standing in front of a door will act as an invisible wall, bushes in the wilderness will trap your horse forever...... Ok lets address the horse in detail, on one of the first missions in the game you need to get on a horse and run away. I found
 a horse but it was on a SLIGHT incline, however because the terrain was bad enough my horse refused to turn or do anything but run straight into a cliff until it got stuck and I got killed. I was about to return the game at 110 minutes because I just died on a tutorial 8 times because if your horse touches a rock or a bush or a tree they'll not just stop but get stuck on said object. Actually this applies to movement on foot also so basically you have to stay on the straight and narrow path at all times or you're fucked.

Combat: Alright this is the main sticking point in the game. From doing some reading the devs made the combat system a lot worse a few years back so I have no context for how it was originally.
The basics of combat work for the most part, strike/block your standard fare directional melee combat ala granddaddy M&B/age of chivalry. The intermediate options consist of timing elements for "perfect blocks' and ripostes which make it easier (read 'possible') to land strikes. Then advanced items are called "master strikes" and your generic fight move combos (left, right, stab = better hit ect.).
Alright now for the problems.
MASTER STRIKES: unless you talk to the 2nd guy to teach you sword training AGAIN you will be unaware of the existence of master strikes, they're mentioned briefly in the advanced tutorial page but you have to grind weapon skill to learn them. Also pretty much every bandit knows at least 1 master strike so it would probably help the player to be taught how they work by the game, as it was extremely frustrating to get bopped in the head constantly with no option to block and thinking it was a bug.
COMBAT SKILLS: 1/2 the combat system doesn't work, this is not a bug, Henry (the MC) is not skilled enough to use these combat features, the game doesn't tell you this so when you're waiting for an option to parry a strike and it seems impossible this isn't a bug its you not grinding your skills enough. 
MULTIPLE ENEMIES: One of the realistic aspects of the game is that fighting 2+ people at the same time is damn hard, like 2 unarmed dudes in their pajamas will almost take you down. Which would be fine if the game didn't make you fight 2-6 enemies ALL THE FUCKING TIME, fast travelling down a road? Here's 6 bandits to fight. Just wandering in the woods with your boss? Well he's useless so defeat these 2 armored bandits by yourself, BTW one of them can master strike so you had best kill the other one before he chops you to ribbons (man having done the stealth tutorial in game would have been nice for that mission too bad its part of a sidequest). The solution to multi-fights is to not use the lock-on system and run in circles stabbing the cluster of opponents, basically you have to exploit the combat AI to win.
PERSPECTIVE: This is all done from first person perspective which is fine, but the game loses sync between combatants all the time so that you can't tell if you're hitting or parrying or connecting with hits at all. I've had several times where I can see my sword mid swing clipping through my opponent while I am at the same time parrying their stab, then my sword teleports above me for the overhand swing I was asking for to follow up the parry. This happens to my opponents also where the audible sound of me deflecting a hit does not match with the visual of their sword clipping into my screen which implies I just got hit in the face.

I had to come back and explain combos because I forgot they existed.
COMBOS: They're useless the AI will always block/parry in the middle of one, in 17 hours I never landed a combo outside the tutorial.

Not many other games really make you feel like you've evolved during gameplay; going from a peasant who struggles against a duo of bandits, to a master swordsman who cuts through cuman camps like butter. KCD isn't a game for everyone, but if you have the time for it's slow pace and an appreciation for a realistic medieval setting, you should give this stellar game a chance.

The setting is cool, but every aspect of the actual gameplay is tedious and I didn't find it worth the investment to try to figure the systems out or figure out what mod I need to "fix" it. I already started the game with like 6 recommended mods just to fix things about the game I know I wouldn't like. Yes, I did do everything recommended to make combat better such as training with some guy and learning how feinting and master strikes work. Didn't fix the tedium of the other aspects of the game and didn't fix the mess that is fighting multiple enemies.

When you complain about aspects of the game the fans will breathlessly explain to you the exact contrived things you need to do to make it good - you have to install all these mods and then you have to completely ignore the main quest as soon as you get a chance and go find treasure to get the best armor in the game then you have to get the best saddlebags and loot everything you can so you have money to fund armor repairs, etc...I guess they just have invested so many hours into it they overlook the obvious issues with this sort of thing.

A realistic medieval setting is cool, but as someone who has played lots of games, I need some seriously enjoyable and polished gameplay to keep engaged in that setting. Wandering around a nicely modeled medieval area alone doesn't do it for me. The various systems in this game just aren't fun to engage with either. I feel too much fun was sacrificed in the name of "realism". At the end of the day, I'm playing a game. I'm not there. When an aspect of gameplay isn't fun to engage with, it takes me out of the immersion, no matter how "realistic" it tries to be. Especially when every single moment of gameply is this way.

I guess I'm just not able to lower my expectations enough to be able to enjoy it, coming from having played plenty of other games that have actually fun moment-to-moment gameplay. I get the sense that people who enjoy the game are just able to look past its faults enough or maybe just don't know what better things are out there. For someone who has a large library of stuff to play, I just can't justify playing it.

Not good for those prone to motion sickness either, especially the horse riding.

Don't bother with this.
Overall the game if fine on the surface, but as soon as you get below that it is just painful.
Combat 90% of the time is being kicked the shit out of as enemies gang up on you, or have perfect blocks and attacks. Oh almost forgot to mention, THERE IS NOT A AIMING RETICLE FOR ARCHERY, which makes it ungodly difficult and almost useless most of the time. The A.I. also can see fine in the dark, where the player can't see at all, as there isn't even a brightness setting. Enemies have unlimited stamina it seems like in combat, skills that mention they affect opponent's stamina do nothing.
The world is nice, it does look great at times, but still has issues. If you have played this game you know that it can be difficult moving around areas, and I won't even talk about stairs...
Overall the A.I. is just a pain. When trying to do stealth they will often auto detect you from a while away, or constantly follow you around making sure you can't do anything.
When I first saw this game, and what I mainly bought it for, was a crafting system. There is none, you can cook and brew alchemy and that is it. Everything else is just a inventory item, or trying to use a grindstone.

Edit after beating this game again.
Playing through it once again, and doing as much as the game had to offer, I still stand by my complaints. To make the game "Somewhat" more enjoyable I had to download several mods, I even HAD to download the cheat mod just to do the main quest since I got stuck in a black loading screen. This issue was reported and talked about nearly FIVE years ago, and is still in the game.
I have most of the DLCs, other then Woman's lot and the Hans one, and man. I think they were a bit of a let down. Ashes was okay, it isn't as broken as the main game, but I feel like it could use more. The fact that you are building a town, but then you don't even get to build half of the trades in your village. The DLC adds some new things that are really good, BUT you have to choose what you would have instead, so you completely lock out the other. One thing that really upset me about this is during one of the final quests you have to get supplies for Talmberg, you can choose to have a brewery in your village but then you can't use that for Talmberg. You can't use your garrison if you built a guards house. Bandits still camp right outside. A big note about this DLC, if you completed it and asked Divish to finish the building process it breaks a quest, the bug I mentioned earlier that i HAD to get a Cheat mod for.
Now for Band of Bastards... This one is just... Wow. It is bad. It is mainly just go here, kill that. However then you get "Choices" that mean nothing, even if you have that stats for it. The only good thing I got from this was a Armor set, most of which isn't good enough to be a late game set. Other then the arms for some reason.
A smaller note, there are several special items, but they are not marked at all. So if you are mass selling gear, like I do a lot at least, you can easily sell the wrong thing and if you didn't realize fast enough welp, hope you didn't want it.

I have had this game since it launched, I made the mistake of pre-ordering this even. I would not recommend this game.

146772073.review:
A nivel general, es un buen juego, inmersivo, me agradó ese contexto medieval que vimos en muchísimos juegos (Dark Souls, Draon Age, Shadow of Mordor, etc) pero sin monstruos, magia, milagros, hechizos, etc, hace todo mucho más real y, por ende, más difícil.
La verdad que uno empieza el juego siendo lo más inútil que existe, no puede encarar una pelea ni con un niño, no sabe usar armas, no tiene una moneda en el bolsillo, y a corto plazo no hay manera de mejorar eso, hay que avanzar bastante en el juego para que las cosas empiecen a "facilitarte", pero casi siempre es cuesta arriba.

Los bueno:
- Juego hecho con amor por los desarrolladores.
- Muchas manera de pelear contra alguien (ir de bruto, arco y flecha sobre el caballo, sigilo, etc).
- Si uno le pone ganas, puede puede subir rápido de nivel e ir consiguiendo dinero, pero hay que "trabajar mucho".
- Historia fiel a los acontecimientos que los libros cuentan lo ocurrido a principios del siglo XV.
- Muchas side quest para hacer.

Lo malo:
- Los gráficos y las animaciones son un poco toscas (personalmente no me importó)
- Si peleas con espada, este juego tiene uno de los peores sistema de lucha que vi en mi vida.
- Quizás se extiende más de lo necesario en lo largo que es el juego.
- La historia del personaje no es muy épica que digamos, y muchas veces se vuelve confuso cuando los personajes secundarios tratan de explicar el contexto.
- Algunos bugs menores, pero lo grave es el mal diseño de side quest e incluso el DLC completo "Band of Bastards, en los cuales algunos personajes que interfieren para avanzar, a determinado momento del juego principal, ya no se tiene acceso, por lo tanto dichas misiones quedan abiertas y sin posibilidad de continuar.

Conclusión: Si te interesa experimentar un contexto medieval en el cual tenés que preocuparte por comer, bañarte, administrar los recursos, y, como la vida misma, sufrir un poco, compralo en rebaja. Si tenés poco tiempo porque trabajás y/o estudiás, aconsejo agregar un mod para poder guardar el juego (tiene un sistema de guardado muy particular y poco versátil para alguien con falta de tiempo). Es una buena experiencia, pero no es un juego que vaya a quedar en la memoria.

146764464.review: THIS GAME IS GOOD AND IT MAKES ME FEEL GOOD

146759843.review:
[h1] This Game's Combat Is Total Bullshit [/h1]

I love the game's story, setting, everything; except for the combat. This game has the worst combat system I have ever seen in a game. The combat slings more bullshit at the player than any other game I have played, and I have 500+ hours on Escape From Tarkov. I'll try to split up my problems with it into categories.


[u] The Jank: [/u]
I'll put it plainly first: shit just doesn't work half of the time. It's not an uncommon occurrence for you to get a hit, combo, or clinch off on an enemy just for the game to have a fucking aneurysm for a second.

The combat UI will unlock from the enemy you're targeting and any inputs you make regarding an attack will only trigger the animation and depletion of stamina, but the attack will not register and will not affect the enemy at all, giving them a perfect opportunity to completely ass-fuck you while you flail about and your sword phases right through them.


[u] 1v2+ Combat: [/u]
This shit isn't even jank because it was designed like this on purpose for some reason. The targeting system is completely incapable of handling more than one opponent at a time. I personally have had a problem where my "switch target enemy" inputs do not work at all, so maybe this isn't as much of a problem for other people if it does work for them, but for me I have to resort to trying other methods to target the enemy I want to.

The problem is that there is no other method. You can have target lock turned off but still get hard locked on that enemy. You could crank your DPI up to the maximum and swing your mouse across the table and you'd only have a 50/50% chance of actually changing your targeting focus to a different enemy.

On the flip-side, the game will decide seemingly at random that you told it to change targets - whether or not you actually tried to or even wanted to. All these things, the punishing nature of the combat, and the camera tracking your target even when not locked onto them creates an incredibly disorienting experience where you literally cannot tell what the hell is happening a [b] majority [/b] of the time.

Overall, being forced to target someone out of your range of melee while you're getting ganked by 3 of his friends at the same time is infuriating to say the least.


[u] It's Actually Unfair: [/u]
Don't get me wrong, I'm perfectly fine with punishing combat most of the time, and even like it if it's implemented well. When I say this game is unfair, I mean the game actively places a bias in favor of the AI when doing anything combat related. Anything and everything you attempt will be overruled by whatever bullshit the AI decides to pull.

For instance, you get a clinch off on Captain Bernard and he gets "stunned". You go in to strike him while he's [strike] stunned [/strike] prepared to perfectly riposte and stun you and then he ripostes your attack and stuns you.

The character you play is heavily restricted in what he can do by what position he is in, his momentum, what he's preparing to do, etc.. If you're trying to block an attack and you miss that perfect block opportunity indicated by a green shield at the center of your combat reticle you're going to be completely fucked if you aren't lucky enough for the game to decide that your shield is, indeed, in the correct position to block a strike (regardless of if it actually is or not). However, this does not apply to the AI at all. You clinched your enemy and now their weapon and shield are only protecting one half of the available areas to attack them, with their back being completely exposed? Well, unbeknownst to you, these AI are Super Saiyans that can change their posture faster than light and put themselves in the perfect position to block you and do one of those special counters that stuns you on top of that. This is a long-winded way of saying that posture is a major factor in combat for the player, but the AI doesn't need it at all and just ignores any restrictions imposed by various game mechanics surrounding posture.

Combos are almost completely pointless, as they can easily be interrupted by the enemy before you get them off and essentially puts you at the mercy of whatever the AI decides to do to you. But, as is the theme in this section, there is a double standard. If an AI lands a strike on you, there's extremely little you can do to stop the AI from having their way with you. Sure, you might get lucky and land a perfect block during their flurry of attacks or at the end of it; but as previously stated, any time you stun the enemy, it's essentially worth the amount of stamina you can get back in the time you aren't spending getting hit, because the enemy can simply decide to ignore the stun effect.


[u] Conclusion: [/u]
Am I currently angry at the game for doing these things to me just before writing this review? Yes, I am. The thing is that it's occurred often enough that it has severely tarnished my experience with this otherwise amazing game. On multiple occasions these problems were so prevalent that I was on the verge of going rabid. It's not like facing these problems is a rare occurrence - in fact it's almost guaranteed that you will face at least one of these problems at any given moment you find yourself in combat or even just practicing combat. Sure, most of the times it's tolerable to a degree, but when the game has its moments, it is infuriating to the Nth degree. It is also not helped that you have to have a special resource that's somewhat expensive for a good portion of the game in order to save your game manually, and that's in normal mode. I imagine that I would experience internal hemorrhaging from how high my blood pressure would get if I were to play hardcore mode.

146685778.review:
As someone deeply fascinated by medieval settings, I must say that Kingdom Come: Deliverance has left an indelible mark on my gaming heart. From a game design perspective, Warhorse Studios has managed to craft an intricately detailed and expansive world that truly feels alive.

The characters in this game are not just mere NPCs standing idly in a corner, waiting for the player's interaction. Instead, they have their own lifecycles—working, eating, sleeping, and engaging with the environment and the people around them. This kind of depth and attention to detail allows the world to feel incredibly organic and dynamic. You're not just wandering through a static medieval playground; you're in a living, breathing, medieval society.

Graphically, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a visual treat. The sweeping landscapes, the meticulous designs of the settlements, and the nuanced character models all stand testament to the capabilities of modern gaming tech combined with passionate artistry. Yes, the game can be a tad buggy at times, but these minor glitches are far overshadowed by the immersive experience it offers.

One of the standout features is the palpable weight of decision-making. It's thrilling to see the tangible effects your choices bring to the game world, lending a sense of realism and gravity to every action, every word spoken. This isn't just a story you're told; it's a story you shape.

As I delved deeper into the heart of Bohemia, I couldn't help but feel completely enraptured by the world around me, genuinely caring for its inhabitants and eager to witness the next twist in the tale. This sentiment only grows stronger as I await, with bated breath and immense excitement, for Warhorse Studios' next masterpiece. Highly recommended!

146635422.review:
Bought on GOG, played around 30h.
The next sale, bought it again on Steam.
My previous save worked on the new install and I was able to continue from where I left off.
The game is pretty realistic as advertised, the combat is kinda wonky at first but you eventually get the hang of it. It's really hard if you don't level combat related perks, don't think you'll kill a guard as an talentless analphabet peasant.
After checking guides online, I started a new game in which I murdered every killable NPC before even completing the first mission just for fun, then went back to my other saved game.
Personally, what really sold the game was the ability to look down and see your legs. Totally immersive.
What I found annoying was the save system. You need a consumable item to save the game. Early game, it's quite expensive but later it's possible to craft it at alchemy benches.
Also, there's a lot of head bobbing, especially while riding horses. I had to install a mod in order to mitigate it.
Overall, the game is great, however it has a steep learning curve when it comes to combat and mechanics. Once you learn everything you need to know, it turns into a banger.

10/10 would murder every NPC in my village again

146576725.review:
This is, apart from more drawing-styled things like "the pillars of the earth" just about the most historically correct medieval game; set in the year 1403 in Bohemia. It still manages to accumulate quite some historical inaccuracies, from plate armour that is 60 years in the future, to talk of burning witches (to even believe in witches was considered heresy until 1486) up to the most egregious one, the lockpicking-game which is modelled on locks that only appear several hundred years later, and incidentally, is brutally difficult (medieval locks are vastly diverse in type and generally a lot easier to pick).

The setting, with all the landscapes, rivers, woods, hamlets, people going about their business is crazy good. Including the flow of time, different things happen at different times in a day. I'd buy it for that alone. 

The story itself is done nicely, pulls you in. Has some immersion-breaking 3rd-person cut-scenes (the worst one with picking herbs) some of which however help you get a feel for the character, like in movies.

In terms of game mechanics, the progression feels to be done quite well, nice pacing. Some of the mini-games are extremely difficult, especially in the beginning with no skills and perks.

And for all other game-developers: If you ever do a game set in the middle ages: This is the new baseline. Don't be lesser historically accurate, or admit your game is a fantasy-game and stop pretending. 

In any case, highly recommended.

146550955.review:
Welcome to Kingdom Come: Deliverance. So you wanna be an unstoppable knight in shining armor? A chosen "hero" killing everything that moves like the murder hobo you are, mirroring your demigod on Skyrim after 1189,78 hours?

[b]Well, too bad. You're playing as Henry.[/b] A peasant that can barely hold a sword, dies in 3-4 hits, sleeps too much, is literally bad at everything, and has no idea how the world works. Neither do you.

But you want to change that, you say? You've played hard games before, you know how this works. Okay, fair enough. Then [b]start training.[/b] Everyone in this world is better than you in one way or another. Perhaps they can teach you a thing or two. But the road won't be easy.  The game doesn't know anything about you and it doesn't care; You're just a peasant. So talk to people who know how to use a sword. Learn to read. Learn to ride a horse.  Spend more and more time building up this boy with a dream into a proper page. Remember to stay clean and eat well. People will notice how you dress and talk. Why attack or kill anyone when everyone is not only useful, but better than you in some way or another?

Next, a squire. You start understanding what you're doing. You're taking less hits, you're actually landing some. You're getting smart. Every bruise is a lesson. People are starting to talk.

Finally, you get the hang of it. You start overpowering your mentors. You're fluent in latin. You can sneak into a bandit camp, poison their stew and bring them down in their weakness. Your armor is stalwart, gleaming in the sun like god has blessed you himself.

Then, and [b]ONLY THEN,[/b], will you become the protagonist of your own story. Only then, will you EARN the game's respect. THAT, is Kingdom Come: Deliverance.

146521179.review:
Henry is doing well. His life is not heavy with the burden of responsibility. Although he would like to look beyond the threshing floor one day, he is currently a blacksmith's son under his father's apprenticeship. He hangs around the bar in the pub, performs alotrium with his friends, helps with the blacksmith's bellows and secretly tries to learn swordsmanship from the mercenaries. But then the banners of Sigismund's troops bloom on the horizon. It's nothing personal, the Hungarian king just needs the silver from the Skalitz mines to keep paying the army, but Henry's life will change once and for all under the boots of the invaders.

The skeleton of the story could be called, with a not too ecstatic expression, a strongly classic tale of revenge with a twist, which you will guess after about thirteen seconds of the game - that is, if you haven't already read it somewhere before. In the end, unfortunately, the plot does not avoid even a bit of pathos, which was not needed. However, even an average story can be entertaining if it is skillfully presented. Here, on the other hand, Kingdom Come saves itself, because the writing skill is evident in the dialogues and excellently designed cutscenes.
Relatively soon, period power schemes are added to the banal point, which improves the overall impression of the story. One of the greatest advantages of the entire game can already be recognized here, i.e. the disarming enthusiasm and zeal for the theme. The game is not afraid to explain the relations between the nobility, the motivations of the lords for their actions and the like. Everything down to the smallest detail. If you are also interested in history, you will also find an extensive encyclopedia of several hundred pages with records of medieval customs, notable figures, events and places. An enthusiast can spend several pleasant hours reading it.

Kingdom Come is definitely not a perfect experience. But at the same time he is exceptional. Its calm onset and slow gradation allow you to immerse yourself in a breathtaking and incredibly authentic atmosphere in a way that one would not expect from a more dynamic title. You have to adapt to the game, adhere to its rules, because it will not make concessions to you. But if you succeed, you'll see and experience one of the best renderings of the Middle Ages you'll ever play. [b] 85% [/b]

146519518.review:
Played hardcore mode, the most immersive game I've ever played. Turned me into a medieval history fan. The open world has a tremendous amount of attention to detail mixed in with whimsical renaissance fair style charm. You can truly get lost in this game as if you were living a second life.

People complain about the combat and jank but real life actions aren't so easy either. If you're accustomed to "quality of life" features and instant gratification then you will most likely head into this game feeling frustrated. *the combat- the combat in this game can be fun and definitely feel satisfying at times, however... there are many problems, significant problems... first issue is when multiple people attack you, I know you should try to run, but sometimes you can't (elaborating more later) and when they attack you, they just glitch into and around you and sometimes stun lock you in grab/shove moves as the other bonk you. 146499073.review:
The game is incredibly detailed, from little things for realism, to complete accuracy for history, buildings, and medieval combat. 

The combat system is detailed as well, though not well suited for 1vX due to lack of options for AOE and zoning, which is most fights in this game. Combat can be janky and repetitive at times due to every enemy having the same movesets depending on weapon type, constant pushing, and how strong pushing and masterstrikes are compared to everything else. There are a lot of quests and activities, many of them can end in different ways depending on the player's choice, though some side quests are very basic like kill 3 boars or collect flowers.

World building is incredible, the world and npcs feels consistent, npcs feels more alive than other games due to them having their own routine, personality, and memory instead of just being background characters. The map is vast and travelling the world actually feels like travelling due to how stamina and day night cycles are handled. It's very interesting to see a world based so much off of real life history with some changes by the devs, not as in WWII fps games or most other history based games, where historical events happens while you're there, kingdom come deliverance feels like you're actually partaking in the event, and you wouldn't know exactly what will happen next either due to some alterations from the devs.

Without spoilers, plot pacing for the main story does feel kind of rushed, and the ending was somewhat anti-climatic, the main story battles doesn't feel as epic as it was expected to be either due to the game hyping up some of the antagonist just for the fight to either be average, or it just doesn't happen at all. majority of my hours were spent on side quests and other activities.

There are a lot of content, but there are also a lot of cut content, thus despite the game being detailed, some parts of the game will still feel incomplete. For example, there's houndmaster skills in the stats, but houndmaster skills aren't actually a thing in the game, and you'll never get a dog companion.

Basically, the game has a lot of features, very realistic, and great world building, combat system is ok, and level design is subpar, 6.5/10

146359914.review:
Kingdom Come: Deliverance presents a grounded setting that charmed me with its historical accuracy and perfectly sized open world. The story, and especially a few selected quests, are quite delightful and unique, proving that exciting stories can be told in a mundane environment. I never got overly enthusiastic about Henry, but there are some interesting side characters that fit in very well with the believable and coherent world.

Combat is a bit too slow-paced for me, but did feel visceral in certain 1 on 1 situations. The skill system isn’t overly complex or intriguing, but I still always enjoyed assigning my next perk point. The game gives you a considerable amount of freedom regarding your approach to the resolution of quests, but doesn’t always provide an option to follow through with your unique ideas.

Immersion comes by very quickly through the need to feed yourself and sleep regularly as well as following both local and historical customs. I maintain my assertion that this is as much of a simulation as it is an RPG. Aesthetically, the world passes as realistic to my eyes and has its moments where it manages to please visually, especially when the lighting falls just right.

Its shortcomings in game design manage to drag down a promising foundation into an often frustrating experience that doesn’t cease to annoy with an unfathomably stupid saving mechanic and the feeling of being set up to fail instead of to succeed. Its technical bugs are still glaring and frequent, but the worst part is that the game sometimes feels so broken that you’re left unsure whether something is bugged or intended, essentially making you unable to play the game the way it was meant to.

This game can polarize like few others. If you’re looking for an authentic medieval experience and bring the necessary patience to truly immerse yourself in it, as well as a leniency towards technical issues, this could well become your favourite game of all time. As more of a variety gamer myself, I could not see past its bugs and cumbersome design, and therefore got frustrated more often than I got delighted. I like the idea behind this game, but ultimately cannot recommend it.

[b]Rating: 51/100[/b]

I have over 500 hours between Steam and Xbox. This is one of the best fantasy RPGs made in a very long time. Some of the mechanics are clunky but but they get easier as you level Henry up.

In this game you play as Henry, a blacksmith's son in medieval Bohemia. Henry slowly works his way from a lowly peasant to the go-to man for his Lord. The story is absolutely worth the price of this game, but there is so much more to do. Several story DLCs, side quests all over the map, and just living in medieval Europe. The game requires you to sleep and eat, making it a more realism simulator than other games in the genre. It's not like other fantasy settings like Skyrim or Witcher, it's Europe. There's no health potions or magic. If you get hurt you're limping home to rest.

The world they created is amazing and realistic - definitely feels lived in. While playing you feel like you're there in medieval Europe. This game is worth it for nothing else than to just roam and explore a wonderful recreation of our past. But the story is great too. And the DLC. And the side quests.

Craptastically unbalanced game that places you right in the thick of things before you can skill-up. 
Stilted, repetitive dialogue that often has no relevance to the action taking place.
Thank god I bought it on special because this is a total failure of a 'game'.
Games should have an "objective, challenge, reward" structure - this game has vague objectives, totally unbalanced challenges, and hence no reward - why play the 'game' when you are set up to die over and over again from the get-go?
You are told to run, but cannot run away. You are told to rescue someone, but do not have the skills. Enemy NPCs multiply and attack you by the scores and you have barely left your village. What is the point?
No, it is not mimicking "real life" - it is a pathetically unbalanced game. Games should be enjoyable - no point having a 'strong narrative' if you cannot make out of your first location.
And trying to 'ride' a horse is a completed disaster - the 'very positive' reviews must be a total sham.

This game is really cool and unique and I highly recommend it.

There are definitely some things wrong with it. The combat isn't that great. There are some other annoying aspects and some parts are a bit janky. But there's nothing else really like it.

At the moment it's on sale for $7.50, which represents incredible value for money. Normally, I would say that the DLC for this game isn't all that appealing and that maybe you should skip it and stick to the main game. But on the other hand you can currently buy it with all DLC for $10, and at that price you might as well get it, since you might like one of the DLCs. At the current price, basically anyone should try it and see if they like it.

This game has several parts which are very special. For example, there's a quest (I don't want to spoil anything, but it's called "A Needle in a Haystack") which is the most interesting story contextualization for a stealth section that I've ever seen in any game. On the other hand, the section itself is also a little buggy and can be frustrating, so it's not perfect. But almost every modern game has bits that are buggy and frustrating. Almost no games have a section which is as interesting as this quest. The ways this game is good are special and unique. This is why (especially at the current price) it's really worth trying the game to see if you don't mind the ways that the game isn't great, because the payoff could be massive.

146123924.review:
This game is just built different man.

After playing BG3, I was reminded of this game because of how freeing both of the games were. Freeing in the sense that the game doesn't always railroad you into solutions of various quests. In fact, it's important to not focus too much on markers, as sometimes the solution lies in the dialogue, surroundings or texts that you find, and not just "go there, do that". I love most of the quests that this game presents.

The combat in this game suffers from a players' overfixation on UI, in my opinion. If you find the combat boring or slow, try either installing a mod that speeds up the animations or disable the UI. In that way, you'll find yourself less fixated on that green shield and be able to focus more on your opponents' actions. When I did so, it made me much better at one vs many situations, and I've enjoyed beating camps by proudly striding up to them rather than poisoning their food or using a bow. But beating the main mission camps is still very fun in stealth too.

The story, while basic, is good and in my opinion fits the style and theme of the game well. The intrigue and pretty good character development are what makes it fairly enjoyable for me.

The DLCs are great, as long as you treat them as just extra side quests rather than full-on expansions (save for one of them), and it wasn't much of an issue for me as I bought the game together with them pretty cheaply.

I am going to replay the game again now on hardcore, with those super difficult combat mods, and make use of alchemy and poisons a lot more :p

146114022.review:
Honestly, I don't know whether this is a yes or no.
The game COULD have been brilliant, it is however, really, seriously, bug-ridden - in questlines especially, both major and side quests. I don't know if they didn't test it or just couldn't be bothered to fix it.
I am not using mods and have run 2 playthroughs - the second was better than the first but the combat is horrible - yes, the pundits can scream 'realism' - yeah, that's just janky for bad mechanics. I've played with mace and shield and then longsword - all levelled to max and it's still wickedly bad when you are faced with more than one foe, and yes, I had the proper perks.
The bows are horrible, here's a hint, just go kill sheep at the top gate of Rattay at night, once you have free roam there - rinse and repeat, I think this took maybe 4?nights work. Do this pretty much before you do anything else, cook the stolen meat and sell it each day. When you can finally get your hands on the Yew Longbow, it actually does some damage- the rest are as useful as a sunroof in a submarine.
The story in and of itself is not bad with some surprising twists; and getting Henry to grow in stature and learn to read etc wasn't too bad.
Note on Nighthawk potions - if it's raining you can't see a damned thing.
Worst quest imo - The Monastery; but if you don't do it right it affects rep stats.
A really major quest - scouting the cuman/bandit camp - oh man, save save save - it's sooooooo buggy.
The map, the markers are unreliable - if you turn your head, stoop to pick herbs - you need to pull the map up again, you can be waaaay off course.
The save system - well frankly, it's garbage. The game autosaves, I can assure you, not anywhere you want it to - save potions are expensive, so try and find a 'sleep and save'; in some areas where those are not available and you can't use your inventory I had to use 'save and quit'. There are very few save files, you need to delete them as you go otherwise you are overwriting all the time - too bad if you need to go back a couple of hours.
The DLC's are 'meh' at best, the first part of "A Woman's Lot' - quite interesting storywise, a bit too long in the dark...never played part 2 as I simply don't care what happens to Johanka.
Did I care about the characters? Some of them sure, the bad guys ARE bad guys, that was amusing.
The ending is very weak, but I guess they did that so there's a Part 2 - I did not want to be forced however, into a silly dlc 2 minutes before you can ride off.
Oh and the dog - it's a nuisance most of the time - always in the doorways, here's a hint - tell it to 'stay' whenever you have to stop at an Inn or go inside a building, it's permanently standing in the doorway so you can't exit, that also stops the nightly howling. Trying to full stealth a bandit camp? Dog's howling/barking whatever......if I play thru for a 3rd run for some extra achievements, I doubt I'd pick it up, or make it stay at the mill permanently.
One last thing; I filled the chest in my parents home in Skalitz during the prologue - this is supposed to be a global chest - it is NOT - I had to sneak back something like 10 times to empty it and place the stuff at Rattay Mill.
6/10 - bugs, bad combat, some very tedious 'activities'; don't buy the dlc's unless it comes in a sale as a package

146054546.review:
This is honestly probably one of the most immersive games I've ever played. It helps to be a huge nerd, but this game is genuinely great. I'm hesitant to give anything a 10/10, because nothing's perfect, but Kingdom Come gets really close.

Pros, and this is by no means an exhaustive list:

- Very immersive.

- Your character doesn't feel like he's the main character right off the bat, and you will have to put in a good amount of work to make him strong enough to take on particularly powerful enemies and/or multiple enemies.

- You don't need the best gear if you're decent with the combat system, which does have a few shortcomings.

- There's a decent amount of quality of life mods, and also some that restore cut systems (polearm skills, unarmed skills) or add a fair amount of perks (perkaholic).

Cons, also certainly not exhaustive, and these are gonna be wordy than the pros:

- A lot of people say the combat system is awkward or janky, and I really can't fault them for it. It's good, in my opinion, but it's definitely a little clunky. Leg armor is not necessary because NPCs can't target your legs and will almost never hit them. You also can't target the legs of your enemies. Combos are good, but also totally unnecessary if you just wait for a master stroke which can one-tap or seriously injure enemies with exposed faces, because a common master stroke with one-handed weapons is just an uppercut directly to the face.

- The saving system is pretty immersive, but I feel the schnapps/sleeping and quest autosaves should be reserved for hardcore where you're already playing it very safe and making sure to save. You can, and I have, lost hours of progress due to being mobbed and obliterated by 4 heavily armed and armored bandits early in your run. Thankfully, there is a mod to let you save anywhere, anytime if you're not into the vanilla game's system.

- Texture LOD issues are common sometimes, but there's a modded config to fix it. Still, you might see ugly low-res textures or textures that pop out when they shouldn't.

Overall, I think the game is great and there's not really a system that just outright has no use. Here's to hoping the sequel fixes at least most of the game's problems, because I'd love to see what could really be done with this setting.

146052977.review:
It is an interesting concept, a game in a medieval setting that strives to be as realistic as possible for a video game and happily, it largely succeeds but it has a few downsides. The main story starts strongly and leaves you wanting to find out more but the closer it gets to the end, the worse it becomes. the game's finale is hardly memorable and leaves a lot to be desired. 
The world however, is created beautifully, the graphics (apart from facial features) are stunning. The soundtrack is nice and pleasant for the ear, too. Combat is controversial but once mastered it feels impactful and really rewarding when the course of battle is in your favour. The main character is likeable but rather mediocre although that's possibly a deliberate choice. Side quests are alright and may occassionally end up with a smile on your face. Definitely worth trying for yourself.

Where do I begin.

This game is a masterpiece. I have learnt so much of medieval society thanks to it, it has a realistic and epic storyline, well written and executed. Every activity or sidequest is treated with utmost respect, to a degree that some feel like main quests. The NPCs are ALIVE, they have a routine and patterns that change depending on the day, the game doesn't feel like it's there for you. You are just a part of its world.

It is far from a perfect game, sometimes (rarely) buggy, the end is slightly disappointing (although people forget that it screams KCD 2 IS COMING). Oh, and there's the fact that it will consume your life because all you will want to do is play it.

This game is a work of art. The music, cutscenes, the visuals, landscapes, even historical accuracy (to a degree) all make it a game I will never forget, and it has a place in my heart just like the games of my childhood. 

PLAY THIS FUCKING GAME

- You cannot smith in the game even though you are the son of a blacksmith
- The ending is a massive cliff hanger
- No crosshair when using a bow makes aiming at a target more than 20 yards away very difficult (this can be fixed with the console command I have memorized at this point: wh_pl_showfirecursor 1)

Other than those things, I love everything about the game... yes, even the combat. When you start this game you have to understand that you suck at everything. You're the son of a blacksmith. You don't know how to use a weapon, you don't know how to ride a horse, you don't know how to read, you don't know any of these things. You have to learn and get better. You cannot expect to just walk into a bandit camp and kill 5+ bandits when you first start the game. This isn't Skyrim, it's real. Even late in the game it is very difficult to fight more than 3 people at once, which makes sense because, again, this game is real. It doesn't matter how good you are, if you get surrounded by 3+ people who at least vaguely know what they're doing, you are going to get your ass handed to you. It is definitely possible to fight 3+ people at once, but you are going to be beat up afterwards.

If you are having trouble with the combat, you have to just git gud. In other words, play through the main story until you meet a man named Captain Bernard and keep playing until you are able to train with him. You will be able to train with him after completing the quest "Ginger in a Pickle" (I can't remember exactly, but I think you'll finish this quest about 4 hours into the game if you just focus on the main quests). Exhaust all the dialog options with this man until he teaches you everything he knows. Once you know how to master strike, feint, clinch, and perform combos, the combat will be MUCH easier than at the beginning of the game. Before you are able to train with Bernard, do not even attempt to fight more than 2 people, especially if they are armored. Just run. Remember: you start the game off sucking at everything.

In addition to learning to fight with Bernard, you need to be more creative about clearing out bandit camps other than just running in there like a dumbass. Kill as many as you can from a distance with a bow. Stealth kill some of them. Lure some away from the camp. Attack at night when most of them are sleeping. Do anything to reduce their numbers before you pull out your sword/mace/axe. Even killing just 1 bandit before the fight begins will make the fight much easier.

Another common complaint about this game is the save system. You can't save whenever you want, the game only saves when you complete a quest or sleep in an owned bed, or drink a savior schnapps (which is hard to get early on). There is a mod that allows you to save whenever you want, but I strongly suggest not getting this mod. I hated the saving system at first, but I grew to love it. It forces you to really think about the choices you make and forces you to be very careful when you try something risky or illegal. When you pull off that risky thing, it is so much more satisfying than in other games where you can just quicksave 1 second before you go on a killing spree or thieving spree.

TL;DR: train with Captain Bernard and git gud.
