146011027.review: Kingdom? yeah.... this is my kingdom cum

146010019.review:
I bought this to look at the castles and other architecture. It's really the best product for that purpose. The world and the buildings are incredibly believable and no other game has ever had that much effort put into its assets and level design.

However, this alone doesn't qualify as a game in my book. 

The character progression, one of, if not the core element of rpgs, has absolutely misguided pacing and is easily exploitable. Even without trying it takes only 10 to 20 hours to max out combat stats and equipment, while the game itself is said to last 100+ hours. Personally it took less than 10 hours to max my melee stats and get some plate armor, as well as some high quality weapon, but I meta- and powergame anyway, while spending the first few hours looking for way to break the systems. You can become a master fighter without ever having had a single lesson or real fight, as killing farm animals is plenty of training. Now I am just looking at the assets in the game, which are great, but also not flawless. The rest of the game doesn't really do anything either to compel the player to continue playing for that long. It's definitely one of the worst possible progression systems, just one step above the atrocity called Elex. Even the most basic progression systems that you can see in browser or flash games are more entertaining.

The combat system controls very poorly, has too many random, non skill based elements and fights tend to be either almost impossible to win with regular, non cheese attacks or a walk in the park. Most of the time, results in combat aren't the result of the player doing the rights things with the right timing in the right location, but simply the result of a calculation, whether your stats allow you to actually land an attack after the RNG rolled through the chance to evade, the chance of the npc to parry, the chance to do no damage, the chance of the npcs to do some special move etc. You can't even aim stab attacks and they will just hit a random part. If you get hit, you get the most ridiculous hit stun and camera shake imagineable and completely lose control for a second, likely getting comboed to death. On the other hand, the player can already one or twoshot most enemies in plate armor while only being halfway through the lackluster character progression. Towards the end, it's almost exclusively walking up to enemies and then oneshotting them. No need to bypass the enemies defences, as that is solved by RNG and the probability of them being able to defend is close to 0 when your stats are maxed out. 
At not point does it feel that you win or lose a fight because of your ability. Compared to other games, like mount & blade or dark souls, the combat in kingdom come really has no redeeming qualities at all. 
There is not enough space to explain everything in detail here, but there are videos that show everything that is wrong with the combat, which is especially noticeable when you compare it to the other games I have mentioned. Mount & Blade combat is just working way better in every regard and it's 100 % skill based. 
The mount & blade single player loop is just repeating the same thing for dozens and hundreds of hours, but both the progression and the combat are so much fun it's a joy to do that. If you would replace that with the kingdom come progression and combat, I would quit the game after a couple of hours.
The solutions in kingdom come are inacceptable. 
Also, combat is definitely not the focus in this product. It can take one to two hours between finding encounters, even while actively searching for fights. That's very polarizing by itself. 

The exploration of the huge but effectivly empty world is tedious and unrewarding. The poor progression system also doesn't incite any wish to explore further. As stated before, visually it looks great and it's enjoyable to look at the castles, villages and all the other, believable assets they have created with great detail - but that is not exactly a game and more of a walkable model then.

The story is an overbearing prison of cutscenes with very little player agency and the plot is just your typical "chosen ones hometown destroyed by evil" trope. But that is highly subjective, as some people either have never seen that before, or enjoy the handholding and predictable plot. There are even some nice touches, allowing you to solve quests in different ways, but that also gets overshadowed by the quest pop ups and map marker gameplay that always tries to push the player in a certain direction, despite other options being possible. This lazy and uninspired system quest system sabotaged their own quest creators creative work. The story prison can be broken with some searching, which is punished by the game's save system and ultimately is of no consequence, because the plot is still on rails with no meaningful deviation.
Outside of all the logic errors and the constant ludonarrative dissonance, it's possible to enjoy this as a cute interactive story. Again, not exactly a game. so another fail here. 

Everything you do in the game is slow and tedious. Picking plants takes forever. Entering dialogues has a black loading screen. Saving the game takes up resources and you will end up losing anywhere between 15 minutes to 2 or 3 hours of progress, simply because you were not allowed to save more often and the devs think it's okay to waste, in sum, hours of your time. The carry limit is sensible for this type of game, but effectively all it does is make you waste hours sifting through containers that are 95% pointless, yet might contain something you need. At least you can stop doing that after around 20 hours, because by then you almost don't need anything outside of quest items. But that is also one of the major reasons, why the exploration in this game is so unrewarding. 
At the time of writing this, I have about 25 hours of actual gameplay in this playthrough. Spent quite a few hours looking at the architecture, but also lost a lot of hours to the save/load system in the beginning and also many many hours of trying to explore but finding nothing of value. My character is set for the rest of the game. Maybe there are some slightly better plate armors or so down the road and a weapon that oneshots enemies even harder, but really all that is left is a marathon of overly long conversations, cutscenes and handholding quests to ultimately take revenge for a bunch of npcs I have known for a few minutes and don't care about, yet are forced to play as if I do. 

There are many more minor issues, but those are hardly worth mentioning in light of the fact, that in summary kingdom come fails thoroughly in all of the major aspects of an rpg: progression, combat, story and exploration.

145905156.review:
I love this game. I got it for free on Epic and played through it once and then bought the royal edition again here on steam and am currently halfway through my second playthrough.

Pros:
- Believable and immersive world. You are the son of a smith, so you are not skilled in combat and such. You even have to learn to read. 
- Interesting and accurate historical setting
- Great and challenging combat, if it is a 1v1
- Great characters (Hans & Peshek are my favourites, Pater Godwin, Hanush and Theresa are also all amazing)
- Survival Elements that are immersive and don't force you to watch your vitals every couple of minutes, it is simply a tool to enhance immersion (needing food, rest, etc.)
- Fun mini games like playing dice or tournaments
- Good voice acting (both in german & english)
- Mostly good story (I'll expand on that below)

Cons:
- Combat against more than 1 opponent. You either have to resort to cheesing the fight or simply legging it. This is mainly due to the lock on camera, which doesn't work particularly well in this game
- Combat Dogs are annoying as hell. Okay, great you manage to actually have the upper hand against 4 bandits, which is a challenge already. How about we throw a dog in a mix that completely stuns you for several seconds while fully depleting your stamina leaving you open to attacks from said bandits? Sounds fun, right? Oh you are wearing plate armour? Well, no problem for terminator dog over here.
- Animations in dialogues are stiff, you basically see the same 4 to 5 animations all the time, lip sync is also often out of sync.
- The saving system is not great. The game is already challenging and that is good! But having to drink a potion to save is just bad game design imo and doesn't add a fun challenge. I gain nothing by having to skip through dialogue again and rushing back to the same spot I was in, just because I didn't have enough saving potions. Fortunately, there is a mod that gives you unlimited saving.
- The game has some jank like getting stuck in trees or your horse getting stuck on a tiny ledge
- The story ends rather abruptly and the last 25% or so leave a lot to be desired

Although the cons are a nuisance, they can either be fixed with some mods or aren't too gamebreaking that they take away too much from my enjoyment of the game. I appreciate the vision warhorse had and am looking forward to KC: D 2. I also hope that more developers will take the "risk" to develop a realistic RPG that isn't a fantasy RPG. There is so much interesting stuff in real world history and KC: D shows that it is absolutely possible to make a great game from that.

145882643.review: If Skyrim's main character was a peasant boy with no skills rather than the chosen one. Really immersive, I've never seen such attention to detail or historical accuracy from a game. The world building is incredible. Even the artwork for the map is thematic and incredible. A truly engaging experience for anyone looking to throw themselves into the middle of the Medieval Age of Europe, filled with interesting storylines and characters that feel in depth and, if you can believe it, even change over the course of the game in realistic ways. I should also mention the visuals: the detail in story and accuracy follows in the detail in artwork and cutscenes. Some truly beautiful scenes. The combat can be difficult to learn, and its VERY unforgiving. But if you can grit your teeth and overcome the obstacles it poses you with some skill, preparedness or clever tricks, this game is a masterpiece you can sink your teeth into. 8/10.

145765207.review:
[b]Overall Rating[/b]	
[h1]81%[/h1]	
	
[b]Price[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Fair Price
Take in to account that my ratings for price reflect the price at the time of review, and not necessarily the current cost or the price at the time I purchased the game.	
	
[b]Game Length[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Long
	
[b]System Requirements[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Very High
	
[b]Bugs[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Minor
For a game made by a relatively inexperienced and independent development team this game is an absolutely remarkable achievement. Nevertheless, there’s a significant amount of jank that you need to accept to really enjoy it. I did not experience any game-breaking bugs, only minor inconveniences.	
	
[b]Difficulty[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Casual
The combat system is unique and innovative. It takes some getting used to and can be brutally punishing at times. Very likely it could be a make or break dichotomy for you.	
	
[b]Audience[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Mature (Graphic & Sexual)
	
[b]Story[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Memorable
Set in medieval Bohemia it mixes an original story with historical settings and characters. There is an absolute wealth of information and historical accuracy that will delight anyone with an interest in such things but also has a lot to offer for the casual player.	
	
[b]Replay Value[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Low
You could sink quite a lot of time in to a single playthrough, and/or simply enjoy the medieval sandbox but one playthough is satisfying. I had little desire to do it all over again attempting a different build. There are only limited deviations possible from the main storyline.	
	
[b]Aesthetics[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Beautiful
This game has possibly the most beautiful forest and countryside depictions of any game ever. Coupled with historically accurate town and castle designs there was never a point that I couldn’t stop and stare in awe.	
	
[b]Audio Design[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Strong
I would only criticise the lack of diversity in the combat music. There was no difference in soundscape between fighting a random bandit and the major battles in the climax of the game.	
	
[b]Graphics Options[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Extensive
	
[b]Accessibility[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	None
There are subtitles but no basic options like removing head-bobbing. Occasionally incorrect subtitles will display or no sound will play during dialogue which can be an issue with subtitles turned off. There are no colourblind options but they are not really needed. Certain situations in combat can induce motion sickness, and there is a bug which turns you around when exiting the map screen which is disorienting.	
	
[b]FoV[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Good Adjustment
FPS FoV has a good amount of adjustment in the in-game menus	
	
[b]Settings Customisation[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Poor
Keys can be rebound.	
	
[b]Mod Support[/b]	
[i]Rating:[/i]	Some
Mods are available but are primarily minor quality of life changes.

One of the best games of all time. Has an indie feel, but tells a great story in a beautiful world - by which i mean its looks and the attention to detail by which they have built it; I won't say that a world where foreign invaders, corrupt officials and lawless roads is a good one haha. 

I joke but what i am serious about is this being one of the best games of all time. It took me 200 hours of gameplay (plus the 100 or more on xbox - yes i bought it twice!) to think of a suitably glowing review and i still can't think of the words. 

This is a game by an indie studio, done right. Its an rpg done right (your character starts out as a clueless peasant and you can, if you're careful, end up being the biggest badass in bohemia. Everything feels realistic and while there are some things that could have been done better, this kind of game is what we deserve. 

even the DLC is worthy! I'll say no more... buy this game. be like me, buy it twice haha

145679705.review:
Este ha sido para mí uno de los juegos más esperados desde que anunció su campaña en Kickstarter (aunque no he podido jugarlo hasta ahora por falta de tiempo), por ello me duele tantísimo no poder recomendarlo a todo el mundo. 

Siendo justos, no todo en el juego es malo, e intentaré desgranar primero las características positivas sobre el mismo y, más tarde, las puntiagudas aristas jugables que, a mi juicio, necesitan de un mayor pulido por parte de Warhorse Studios. 

ASPECTOS POSITIVOS: 
- Los gráficos son buenos gracias al Cry Engine. 
- El diseño artístico es impecable. 
- La recreación histórica está muy bien lograda. 
- La alquimia es genial y muy realista. 
- El tiro con arco transmite muy bien la sensación de tensar la cuerda y dejar ir la flecha. 
- El hecho de tener que aprender a leer para poder descifrar el contenido de los libros.

ASPECTOS NEGATIVOS:
- Las expresiones faciales son inexistentes, dotando a los personajes de un aspecto hierático durante las conversaciones. 
- Los movimientos corporales no se corresponden en absoluto con las expresiones faciales. 
- El sistema de combate, aunque muchos lo defiendan por su realismo, es demasiado tosco a mi juicio: el puntero en forma de estrella y el hecho de escoger dónde defender y atacar (teniendo en cuenta la escasa estamina con la que cuenta nuestro protagonista) parecen más un juego de piedra, papel y tijeras que un combate de esgrima medieval. A pesar de los combos que se introducen, es demasiado tosco y lo cierto es que hubiese preferido un combate similar al de Skyrim que, aunque no sea lo más realista del mundo, no se asemeja tanto a un juego de ventajas como antes he comentado. Ha habido combates en los que he tardado media hora en derrotar a un oponente que no se debilitaba a penas dado que iba bien pertrechado con una generosa armadura. 
- El excesivo realismo a la hora de ir de un punto A a un punto B hacen que se convierta en un juego de progresión muy lenta. Está bien apostar por el realismo pero no por ello hay que aburrir al jugador. En relación a esto, está muy bien que haya que comer (vigilando el estado de la comida), beber, dormir, etcétera; pero, por muy realista que aparente ser este juego, y por mucha carne seca que he comido, no he contraído la enfermedad de la gota. 
- La historia me parece insulsa y con un final abrupto: parece que se quedaron sin presupuesto para plantear un mejor final. Además, aunque el trasfondo histórico es bueno, no deja de ser la historia de siempre: gobernantes estúpidos toman decisiones estúpidas que desembocan en guerras estúpidas. 
- Los DLCs no aportan nada al conjunto global y hubiese sido mejor que Warhorse hubiese dedicado el presupuesto de estas expansiones a pulir los detalles anteriormente citados. 
- El downgrade que se aprecia respecto a la beta del juego. 

Por estas cuestiones no puedo recomendar este juego a todo el mundo.

145585708.review:
This is a game FOR those who want to: 
Have a life changing experience that is not afraid to throw the weight of the world onto you and your emotions. 
Immerse yourself in the world of medieval Bohemia. 
Understand that you are the equivalent of any side character or even NPC - until you make yourself the main character.
Embrace your character and take full responsibility for training every bit of him and sculpting to your play style. 
Practice skills and obtain satisfaction in working your way up from nothing. 
Want to navigate combat in a complicated manner that involves more than just brainless left clicking.
Get lost in another world and another time where life was simpler... yet still just as complex. 
Notice small details and world building that is true to real life - whether it is geographical location or medieval living. 
For those who can suspend their disbelief regarding some of janky nature of NPC's that come with a developers first game. (Although I must say they did an amazing job nonetheless). 
For those who enjoy the world for what it is, rather than just speeding through the main story as fast as possible. 
For those who can take a look at the layout of a village and see everything from the layout of the village, distribution of classes, all the way to the strategically placed compost piles. 
For those who want to choose whether they are a respectful and honorable character, or an absolute psychopath (with many grey lines in between). 
For those who appreciate nature (the woods) and also appreciate historical accuracy regarding buildings, they depth of wilderness in terms of elevation changes and vast distances. 
For those who would rather travel the world and journey on foot or by horse and experience the world firsthand and all of the benefits that come with it.  
For those who do not mind the welcome embrace of living life through a set of medieval eyes - not special in any regard - only as special as you are and you make it to be. No superpowers, no advantages upon other characters other than those that you choose to earn while you play. 
For those who enjoy and find comedy and humor in Life. 
For those who like to see hidden subtle references to other great games. 

This game is NOT for those who: 
Are not strong-willed and determined. 
Have a weak heart. 
Like to fast travel around the world every three seconds - missing all the beauty within it. (although fast travel is an option). 
Want to immediately be all powerful and twirl the world around their finger. 
Want to have everything handed to them on a silver platter without earning it. 
Want a short and shallow storytelling movie. 
Want a short high action packed match (like COD match or similar). 
Want a far fetched fantasy experience (unrealistic magic... creatures, blah blah blah). 


In summary: 
You may obtain this masterpiece, play a little bit, and put it down. You may be hooked for good right away. 
Either way - WHEN you come back to it - you will have accepted that you are choosing to go back to a time and place - an escape - where you can ensure to be lost in a beautiful yet unrelenting world. A world that does not go to great fantastical lengths to overemphasize the horrors of war and what it brings - it just hits the nail on the head. The bloodiest battle can rage on the most beautiful fields and forests you have ever seen. You will not escape the feeling of horror and awe watching thousands of flame bound torches leeching over the hills as towns burn and people scream. 

All in all - definitely recommend this one to anyone who does not mind getting lost in another world for hours - not even considering the many side quests, main story quests, world activities, and DLC quests and activities.  

Support these devs - hopefully they make another one just like this one. ;)

145559959.review:
Immerse yourself in medieval Bohemia.

First person open world CRPG which plays similar to an elder scrolls game in its structure but which in my opinion improves in almost every game mechanic. Imagine taking the game Oblivion but removing all magic and fantasy elements so it feels a lot more realistic with a focus on historically accurate content.

Combat is similar to Mount and Blade but even more satisfying, weapons and strikes feel very sturdy and are based on medieval techniques, you have to approach encounters with multiple enemies with caution because blocking is very important.

The presentation is resplendent from the inventory to the look of the hand drawn medieval maps. The landscape/map is based on a real world location. 

Fast travel is handled cleverly using the system where you have to watch yourself travel across the map screen and makes me feel grounded in the world.

The story is engaging, voice acting is topnotch with British voices and I found the protagonist very likeable.

The only part of the game that is lacking compared to skyrim for example is that there aren't any dungeons to explore, the whole game is played in the overworld apart from a handful caves/mines which are very barren inside.

PERFORMANCE on RTX 4070 Ti: Runs flawlessly I get 100+ FPS on Ultra 1080p although you do get a few dips in town centres down to 55ish fps

The detailed and beautiful world (especially the landscapes, nature and woods!) allow you to really dive into the game and create a unique atmosphere. This is the first game since Oblivion to give me those certain feelings. I don't really even know what to say. You kinda start getting sense of pride on your skills after a while. Next time you remember not to rush it, and after fierce combat that's more than just clicking a mouse, you emerge victorious! Alchemy is done by hand, literally, and requires you to follow instructions. Your actions do have some effect on certain things. Also you can kill a lot of folks that are important for some quests, automatically forfeitting those quests. That's not always a bad thing, for example, you can kill certain person and save yourself a lot of time that you would have to spend on detective work. 

My 159 hours have 3 playthroughs: 
First time I tried to be nice and played almost all additional quests, it was probably the longest and took what 80 hours.
Second time I had watched Helical's playthrough and left Skalitz as a level 12 murdering maniac. 
Third was Hardcore Henry run (with all negative perks) and it was easily the best run. I absolutely encourage you to try it, without abusing birdcages. Half the fun is in the "now where the hell am I now?"! Although if you do Hardcore Henry run, I recommend preparing for it with some cows on Skalitz, it makes the rest of the run much more enjoyable!

Bonus: When you return to your father in Skalitz, drink yourself to oblivion before returning the items! Next task is much more interesting done drunk :D

145268108.review:
Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a game that leaves much to be desired for those seeking an enjoyable gaming experience. As someone with diverse hobbies like gaming, manga, anime, and 3D modelling, my expectations for an engaging and immersive experience were not met.

One of the most notable drawbacks of Kingdom Come: Deliverance is its length and tedium. The game's extensive game-play can easily become overwhelming, making it difficult to stay engaged. Furthermore, the limited saving mechanics, which require the use of Savior schnapps, add an unnecessary layer of frustration. This restriction on saving progress seems counter-intuitive, often leading to undue stress and repetitive tasks.

Aiming the bow is another aspect that detracts from the enjoyment of the game. As someone who appreciates the intricacies of digital worlds, I found the bow mechanics to be needlessly challenging. This design choice can easily deter players from fully enjoying the archery aspect of the game.

In comparison to titles like Elder Scrolls Online, Kingdom Come: Deliverance falls short in delivering a captivating and immersive experience. Elder Scrolls Online manages to strike a better balance between engaging game-play and a rich open-world environment.

In conclusion, Kingdom Come: Deliverance might not be the ideal choice for gamers seeking an enjoyable and immersive experience. The game's length, limited saving mechanics, including the use of Savior schnapps, and challenging bow aiming mechanics contribute to a less-than-stellar gaming experience. Players searching for a more satisfying and well-rounded adventure might find alternatives such as Elder Scrolls Online to be a more suitable choice.

145236154.review:
This game aims to be as realistic as possible and does a fantastic job with it's historical accuracy. It's not perfect but I find the discrepancies to be minor. My first play through was a disaster because I fell for the impression everything is time dependant and rushed from one quest to the next. The save system, needing to drink an expensive potion, coupled with the number of bugs was also an issue.

My second play through has been a joy so far due to two key changes on my part. First, I grabbed a list of quest names that actually do have a timed component so I know when I can take a break and just explore. Right after the prologue I ended up leaving Radzig hanging and just did some side quests, poaching, herb gathering, alchemy and cow tipping (just punch cows when nobody is looking to level up strength). Practice makes perfect and Henry's stats are really bad at the outset. Getting him skilled up and making some Groshen at the same time makes a world of difference. Of course combat is nigh on impossible in the beginning so get your strength up and murder bandits in their sleep or run away. Combat gets easier with good stats and gear, train with Robard!

The second thing was alchemy. I knew the recipe for Saviour Schnapps (the save potion) from my first play through and you don't need to be able to read to make it. Add the components from your inventory and make it. There is a great patch of Belladonna west of the mill, over the river near a bandit camp. Good hunting too. Get your strength up and sneak into the camp at 1am, stealth take downs and finish them off. Don't forget the chest. You now have a little poachers camp. Making a stack of potions is profitable, ranks up herbalism, alchemy and, if you have the "leg day" perk, strength. It also makes saving the game trivial.

145201417.review:
I'm probably not done forever with this game, but after a couple of restarts and a whole lot of reloads due to janky game behavior, ambiguous quest instructions that led to failures, and unexpected murder ambushes as soon as the confidence level got too high to save often, I've finally finished the main quest and a small chunk of side action. So I'm bidding KC:D farewell for now.

The sentiment I just expressed in that first paragraph really encapsulates my overall thoughts on the game as a whole. At times it's brilliant, and there really isn't anything quite like it if you want to fully immerse yourself in a medieval world. Without a doubt, to fully experience everything, including the DLC, this is hundreds of hours of gameplay, and probably at least two or three different character styles. There are so many things this game does well, and that's worth something. But it's also exhausting, both in its sometimes accidental difficulty and its commitment to realism, and at a certain point the quest formulas become very repetitive. By the end, I found myself barreling through forests on my horse at top speed, not caring if it was the right route per se, but because it was the direction I needed to go and all I could think about was getting there and being done.

I stand by my recommendation. You should definitely play this game if you enjoy open world RPGs of any kind, or if you have a fondness for medieval history. If you fall in both categories, you may have one of your very favorite games of all time here. For me, it's good but falls short of greatness. I could see myself coming back with a totally different character in the future, and I'm almost reluctant to step away for a while instead of give that a try right now. But then I remember all the parts that tested my patience as much as many game I've ever played, and I think maybe it's better to quit while I'm ahead. Jesus Christ be praised.

145160570.review:
There's a good game idea in there somewhere, but this is not it.

Warhorse made something special - the writing is decent, the world is nicely built, the game is sorta-kinda pretty. The immersion is there, and so are the rewards... up until about 1/2 into the game progression.

And then it just falls off of a cliff. Every single quest becomes a FedEx one (though there is a lot of that before as well), you're rocking the best items in the game so rewards are meaningless, and some of the main storyline quests become just incredibly tedious. I rarely give up on a game, but this is it for me.

A lot of people mention combat. It's a mess, but it's also original and rewarding if you get it right. But it is an absolute mess and should be reworked. But really, the main issue is that the game just gets incredibly boring and that it does not respect your time. There are loading screens everywhere, half of the gameplay is just staring at the fast travel or sleep screen.

I have very high hopes for a sequel however. It's clear that Warhorse did something interesting, novel, and special here. It's just that they failed at making the core gameplay good, engaging and rewarding as the story and character progress. In a way this feels like the first Witcher game - rough, sometimes quite boring, but also full of good fresh ideas. I hope they get this right with the next one. In the meantime, there are so many better games to spend your time on.

145019174.review:
Arguably groundbreaking as a video game that is more medieval and nothing like power fantasy gaming. It pulled me away from Elden Ring and Witcher (still great games mind you). You start as a worthless good for nothing punk kid named Henry who can't fight his way out of a paper bag. Deal with it and learn to get better. Sort of like real life.

Combat matches Dark Souls so train or run away. BTW, that is 40% of the game. The rest is exploring amazing landscapes, investigations, talking, etc.

The cut scene of debauchery with the priest and two women gives a realistic take about the good parts of medieval life. Most stories make it seem that it was depressing 100% of the time.

Great focus on History with learning documentation that you can skip if you don't care. 

Gritty examples of why I love this game: 

(1) I casually went up and down a ladder and fell because I wasn't paying attention. I was bleeding and didn't have enough bandages. I spent an hour trying to buy/find bandages and was lacking in just one more bandage to plug it all up. After 15 minutes of gaming I bled out and died lol 

(2) After some training I figured I could beat the Captain of the Guard. In most games I would have beaten him. In this game he beat me down to a crying whelp

(3) You have to be careful where you sell stolen goods or you get called on it and even jailed.

(4) Speaking of jail I spent a week in jail and all of  my fresh food spoiled. When did that last happen in a video game?
Oh, and to further punch me in the face something bad happened and then a fire started in the jailhouse and I died. I mean, once was awesome to see that grittiness so I'm okay with dying like that.

(5) Saving is possible but not easy like in most games. They want you to live with your choices which I appreciate.

(6) Murder hobos will flip the table. Button mashers will weep in frustration.

(7) You need patience and perseverance for this game. Unlike most games victories are huge highs in this game especially for combat.

(8) The narrative and characters in this game are good to amazing. Minority of mediocre characters and cut scenes.

(9) There are achievements for becoming a drunk, staying a virgin and becoming a monk. 

(10) Some homes are private and people kick you out. They might even attack you. Reminds me of Gothic 1 and 2. Oh, and just like Gothic 1 and 2 if you do bad things the NPCs remember and punish you for it.

145012706.review:
Pros: 
-Immersive and engaging. 
-Beautiful world with nice details, castles and fiefdoms are bustling and active. 
-Graphics that stand out amongst games in 2023 let alone on its 2018 release. 
-Harsh, but thrilling combat that doesn't hold your hand or make you feel like a superhero, just an average peasant boy with not talent. 
-Interesting characters and story development. 
-Lots of places to explore and visit. 

Cons:
-Some characters that aren't so interesting.
-Lots of annoying fetch quests, or "Follow the slow-walking NPC on a 3KM hike while they exposition dump" kind of quests.
-Combat is very harsh and takes some practice, which is fine for me but maybe not for you. You will, even with experience, get absolutely dunked on if you misjudge your opponent.
-Some things are a little bit... janky. Lots of clipping, broken animations, ragdolls bugging out or models exploding is rare but definitely present, weird NPC behaviours... People in cutscenes have very bland emotional range in their faces and animations, however *most* of the voice acting is genuinely pretty good with some exceptions. Good few weird glitches that broke quests, but the quest itself was still fixable by reaching waypoint so no fuss there. Nothing game-breaking as of yet.
-The game has guards like in Oblivion that run up and start shouting at you outta nowhere because you punched a chicken in a farm in the middle of absolutely nowhere a month ago and you returned to the area. 
-Historical accuracy is pretty good, but there are a few creative liberties with that accuracy here and there, which is acceptable but I would have liked to have a little more of a hardcore history simulator.
-Bows are absolutely awful to use, which is great actually for realism, but REALLY bad for gameplay.
-You can't buy or store polearms like a Halberd.

Its a 9/10. The cons don't detract much from the experience, and some of the glitches are pretty damn funny. If you wanna go for a walk in a European forest, accidentally get into an immesive 1v6 swordfight with Cuman mercenaries, and get your balls fed to you while they scream at you in a language you don't understand, this is the game for you.

Save system sucks donkey balls though. Absolutely disgustingly poor save system.

144859072.review:
I had wanted to play this for a long time but never felt super inclined to do it as I felt it might be a bit slow for my tastes (I used to absolutely love story rich games, but as I got older and have kids there simply is not the time to spend on those types of games...until I got a Steam Deck :P...but I digress).

I couple of weeks ago I did feel inclined to try it out and boy had I been missing out this whole time. I was hooked from the first moment of the game. Even though some of the controls were a tad cumbersome (nothing too serious I want to add), the level of immersion I got from the story, the characters, voice acting and simply the attention to detail, it was all simply something I have not felt when playing a game for a really long time, if ever.

This is not your typical RPG or modern game. This became apparent rather quickly as you could move forward in the story in a number of different ways. Also how your character is affected just deepens the immersion. In a scene quite early in the game you are forced to flee. Just as I am used to being able to do in most games is simply run and then take a shortcut through smaller slopes with rocks etc. In Kingdom Come my character instead sprained his ankle and got caught.

With all this said, I think that Kingdom Come manages to put all these things at the perfect level. They are there to be felt and needed to be managed, but it never becomes so that this is the entire game just trying to micro manage stuff, which is otherwise often the case with games trying to add these types of mechanics.

What sets this game apart from most other RPG's is that this is also a historical/realistic story and setting.

This game has brought back my love for RPG's for sure and I can wholeheartedly recommend this game to any RPG fan.
It is definitely an experience.

144849365.review:
I got hooked from the beginning looking at the viewpoint of the unskilled son of a blacksmith working your way up the ladder, the first 30 hours of sidequesting was nice and you can tackle missions in more ways. NPCs are decently written but their AIs are dumb af. Halfway of the plot and sidequest is just a drag and I just want it over with [spoiler] You don't even get to finish the other main quest you've had from the beginning, the main motivation for Henry, it was just so unsatisfying, the sequel hook didn't make me look forward to kcd 2 [/spoiler]

Now for the combat, don't listen to people when they say it's hard and you just have to learn along henry, no you're just hard capped until you unlock the master strikes. You have 4 weapon types, sword, axes, maces and bow. Clearly only the sword was favored since the mace/axe only has 3 skills compared to it. But in the end those skills are useless because mid game the enemies will block/parry you or get gangbanged before you can even finish a skill most of the time and the best weapon is the bow anyway [spoiler] and mace because midlate game are weak to blunt [/spoiler]

Graphics is good no doubt, and I would have enjoyed travelling more if not for the bushes and trees, god I hate the bushes and trees

This game is also littered with bugs here and there but nothing game-breaking fortunately, some are funny at best. But the worst is getting those occasional crashes, in a game where saves are limited

All in all it's a slow grind realism which is done half baked that the realism factor just feels like artificial difficulty/padding. Now if you're into that, I'd recommended it to you, but only worth on discount

Kingdom Come: Delivery Boy 7/10

144810472.review:
The closest and most realistic way to experience the dark age, a real medieval life simulator. Sadly I can only recommend this game to people who are fans of the medieval times because as simulators are: it's not for everybody. 

Overall 7/10

pros:
+gorgeous landscapes
+extremely well researched and detailed world. Be it history, culture, combat, politics: gamers who are into medieval history will have everything they wanted
+interesting story and good quests
+a very good "medieval life" simulator, you'll have to eat, sleep, repair your armor and wash yourself regulary (so people don't think that you're a bandit)

neutral:
o VERY realistic and unforgiving combatwise. When you start the game, you are nothing and you will just like that die in almost all combats. You will have to train and get better gear to survive and, at least in the first few hours, try to avoid ambushs

cons:
- the player dives deep into the life of that time, which means there's plenty of complex politics involved. For people who don't know anything about that era it may become confusing and boring pretty fast
- you can only save by sleeping, finishing an important quest, drinking an expensive beverage or quitting the game, which will sooner or later force you to replay bigger chunks of a mission because you forgot to save or simply couldnt
- the beginning is pretty slow and can be tedious for some

and now to the biggest flaw: the combat. THE COMBAT IS AWFUL, thanks to two absolutely terrible mechanics:
- Fights against crowds are hell. You can always only focus one enemy and fight against him and that's okay in a duel, but a nightmare once you fight against multiple enemies. Keep in mind that this game strives for realism, that means that enemies wont attack you one by one, they will instead always try to gank you and that will often be your death. "But that's alright, its realistic!" you might say, but even in real life you can handle multiple enemies WAY better than here because if somebody attacks you from the side you can look to the side and block. In the game though, youll have to focus him first and then act, which is pretty much always too late already. Games like f.e. Mount&Blade or Mordhau handle this way better
- Master Strikes. Why the hell did they implement Master Strikes. It's basically a countermove, you block an incoming strike completely and at the same time strike back. But the thing is: IT'S UNBLOCKABLE.
So no matter how good you are, npc enemies will always here and there land hits on you that you can't block, ever. The more often you hit them, the more often they get the chance to master strike you. And you know what? The game WANTS you to hit them often because there's a combo system! Yes, there's different attack directions and if you manage to land a combo, you get a special attack! Sounds cool right? Well bad luck, these combos only work like 20% of the time because enemies can either a) perfect block (doesnt make you loose stamina) them and interrupt the combo or b) master strike you and interrupt the combo. So whats left to do? Master Strikes. That's right. Once you've found out how they work that's all you do for the rest of the game: wait until the enemy strikes, master strike him with your unblockable attack, repeat. This way you kill him and since you never attack he'll never get a chance to master strike you. Good job Warhorse, you built a complex combat system based on true, historical sword fight with a dodge, counter and combo system and you destroy it with one ridiculously op mechanic.

So can I recommend this game? 
To people who are absolute fans of the medieval era or medieval history: yes. 
To everybody else who just wants some cool medieval game: no.

Great game, but only something for dark age enthusiasts

144692547.review:
Pretty good game, the graphics are great still 5 years after release and the story is solid enough, although it falls off a bit in the last third or so. It is quite long and there is one quest in particular where you are in a monastery and it could very easily scare off people from finishing the game with how tedious it can feel. However, there is a ton of side quest content to be found and most of it is high quality and interesting. There is however a clear quality over quantity approach, as the world is not particularly huge but it does feel full and fleshed out in spite of that. It is also a purely historical setting, so being able to get a view back into the late middle ages is great for those who love history. There is also a relatively small set of main characters, but they all feel like they get the appropriate screen time and none of them feel unnecessary or uninteresting. 

There are some flaws. It is very performance intensive even on high end hardware and FPS also noticeably drops as you play, requiring periodic restarts. The skill tree also has a lot of useless skill point picks, and some skills, such as speech, lockpicking, warfare, maintenance and herbalism, take absurd amounts of time to level. Other skills like hunting and drinking have little practical use. There are also some timed quests that lack any real indication they are time limited. In terms of bugs, I have never encountered anything gamebreaking, but there are some small immersion breaking things like armor clipping through clothes. The animations and dialogue system can also feel very janky and unpolished at times, and voice lines from the same character are often clearly recorded on different microphones, with audio levels all over the place.

Of course you can't mention this game without talking about the combat system. When I first played KCD I had a tough time with it, as it really requires you to put in time to train up your skills with Captain Bernard before you go off into the world to slay bandits and Cumans. You absolutely need to learn the perfect block and master strike or you will have a bad time. However, it is not without flaw, as group fights tend to be a nightmare, and not in the sense of "this is difficult", which would be realistic, but rather the combat system just isn't designed for group fights. Switching between targets is clunky and trying to get away just ends up with you getting vacuumed into the enemy group by janky grab animations. You can absolutely win every group fight, but it is frustrating and worth avoiding when possible. You will inevitably end up stun locked out of making your own attacks, as getting hit cancels swings, so the only way to win is by backing up and repeatedly master striking for minutes until victory, all while your armor durability evaporates. Another issue is peasants wearing rags tend to somehow be master swordsmen who can parry and master strike even a max level Henry. However, in one on one fights, such as tournaments, the combat system shines really well.

I'd strongly recommend grabbing the game on sale, but not setting your expectations amazingly high. I didn't truly appreciate the game until a second playthrough, but even then I cannot say it is for everyone.

144553847.review:
The game that killed my hype for any game release, first game ever I had to use cheat engine to fix broken quests and other issues, the game I hated and wanted to totally abandon and forgot at some point... only to come back after years having one of best "openworld" medieval RPG experience ever.

Since first trailer I was totally hyped, as long years Warband and RPG player that is interested in medieval history (in particular of my own country and this era) this game was clear choice so i bought it at release with little hesitation.. which was.. bad. 

I swear this had to be one of most broken releases ever (only F:NV or Gothic 3 comes to mind as comparable). Many technical issues and bugs, broken physics like falling through world (or in opposite fly  above), being stuck in arenas or doors, not spawned quest items, quest NPC that can not be interacted... First time I was really forced find and use cheat console to try fix something  as possible, but together with limited save system i kept losing progress and constant repeating of whole game days (and real hours) exhausted me totally.. Came back at Woman lot release and it was similar experience.. alltogether I had like 150 hours in the game I could mark as "wasted" and if there would be any chance for refund I would use it. All Game director boasting that hugely criticized Skyrim for bugs (and many game small issues that btw Kingdom come repeat and the same) sounded to me like arrogant joke and bubbling (and frankly it is to some degree but nvm)

Luckily I tend to forget the bad things so now in 2023 I gave the game another chance... and so glad I did. Is the game totally bugfree? Hell no. But everything major was polished enough it is like different game completely. Sure there are still some bugs and glitches but if blocking progress I always googled sufficient  workaround in short time. Only things that troubled me were FPS drops and few crashes - guessing the game  optimalization is still not perfect and cant be fixed now.

So beside technical shape what the game has to offer, what is good and bad in it?

I start with the good points. Game has unprecedented amount of historical accuracy and immersion for an  PC game. I was slightly annoyed it take very nationalist description of events (in particular in Sigismund person), but you can not force anyone to take one historian over other and the dedication dev team made is astonishing. This include various game activities, people behaviour and location reconstruction. I have wandered  the land and visited all castles (or their ruins) in real and it is really amazing how close they came, really can imagine things were like this (or close to it)

The writing of the quests and story is among top in RPG genre. I already praise very high good written stories but the difference here is it dont exactly make deep philosophical speeches or Ideas, complicated plot and twists or major decisions... but instead all stay more real, "human", sometime simple, sometime hilarious but above all it has sense of realism, things people would really say, how they act, what was their interest and issues at the time.

I like most game mechanics, like thievery/crime, picklock, or stealing, hunt, alchemy, reading, overall the skill and character progress and learning curve... I have some caveat with economy and combination with random encounters - those spawn at predefined spots all over the map and if you dont rely on fast travel (i almsot ignored it - it take like 3x more game time to reach the destination this way) you will recognize those spots by heart in time (not to mention bandit groups tend to put some obstacle in the way which make it more clear) - what is bad those spots are reseted immediately without any timer so more than once you find new encounter at place you fought different few mins ago - I and even situation where I rode horse bit far away from pursuing bandits, step down with the bow and decision to come back - only to found the cell reseted and they were gone, but new different group on their place. Often there are group fights eg. between bandits and guardsmen too. This system work pretty much against the rest of the game - sole amount of encounters and enemies I killed this way is nonsense (it would make more than real population of game villages together) and their spawning and disappearing from/into void dont make any good. Connected with loot it make whole game economy irrelevant though - you get top tier equipment like nothing and have abundant things to sell, with actually very little to use the profit (as you can ignore buying any gear - either get it from encounters or quest rewards). Similar one has to ask why people in game are begging for few groschen if traders pay good money for ordinary flowers like nettles that can be found everywhere. Also hunted animals are quite overvalued with one boar meat worth like plate armor piece if not more (in theory it is illegal in game but there are not any active huntsmens to stop you and meat lose mark of stolen goods in no time)
 
What stay probably worst as game mechanic goes is melee combat. In my eyes it has very little with realism beside very accurate animations. The problem is that all combos and tactic comes into vain due perfect block/master strike mechanic which is simple QTE that is vastly abused by most enemies and player alike. So one has to ask where those looters that took weapons to hand for first time  learn such things? Basically it means regular attacks and combos are punished because of this as it make very easy defensive damage and kill any opponents (or the player.. so if you go against enemies with swings and combos you are punished for that and eg. in arena the right way is stay on passive defense and just succeed in master strikers.. or keep running into enemy for clinch following by free attack). It is simply bad and break any immersion one have initially from combat.

Group combat making most of the game is even worse with terrible messy camera focus, target locks, enemies coming over each other.. it feels very junky and glitchy. 

Also armor is quite irrelvant in stamina system - out of stamina = you take major damage from any weapon (hence that few villagers quickly beats you with their blunt home made because every hit take you stamina and once you are at zero you lose all health in short time too).

Actually I had no issue deal with most groups in the game after a while but I am far away from consider the combat system any good. I enjoyed some duels until all came down to master strikes from both sides but overall it failed to be fun - quite sad in game that has combat as major part of gameplay.

Luckily the rest of game stands for it and I enjoyed it a lot, even considering hardcore replay. 

Solid 8/10 game in 2023 but I will be way more careful prior rush buy KCD2 (that will be hopefully announced soon) - though if the devs took their lessons it can be nice surprise.

the game is pretty good in my opinion

the game has a lot of details and features that i really like, for example you have a higher chance of persuading a noble if you are wearing fancy clothes and a lower chance of persuading a peasant with the same clothes. and unlike other games, speech is a very useful skill you will use alot. i also really like the leveling system, none of the skills are useless and it takes some time and effort to level them up so its very rewarding when you get a skill point. almost all the perks you can unlock have a lot of use so none of them are a waste of a skill point. they also dont have a skill tree so you dont need to unlock one perk to get another. the story is also very detailed and makes you feel for the characters.

this game does have a good sum of downsides that i must mention
the combat system is very difficult and if your fighting multiple people it seems impossible. but the combat system also isnt impossible, and luckily there is training very early on in the game so you can eventually get used to it and have a chance of fighting enemies. there is also very little rewards for completing quests, and if there is a reward its usually just some coin. theres no special armor you get or cool weapon like in other medieval games, which i guess adds realism but it also makes quests a lot less rewarding and really impacts the will to complete more quests. speaking of quests, there is a lot where you go to a town and just talk to people which can be boring sometimes. there is a lack of customization aswell, a lot of the armor and clothing cannot be bought and you have to murder some random town guard if you want a simple helmet to complete your look. the manual saving system also kind of sucks in my opinion, you have to buy a drink to save your game witch also makes you drunk, the drink is also very expensive so if you want to save your game manually you have to spend half of your earnings from a quest to purchase a drink.

i know i said a lot of negatives but this game still is very good and even if the combat system is hard it still is rewarding when you get your kill. get this game if you like challenging objectives and rpg's.

This game has a good story and a new take on combat and stealth. It's very detailed and I have found myself playing it for hours may times. (I have played it on PS4 and logged thousands of hours there playing since release)
Combat: this can take some getting use to because YOU the player need to practice as much as the protagonist does. Particularly if doing hardcore mode. This game uses a format I have not encountered before and can take some getting use to. Use Bernard! And pick off foes until you have one left to mess with and work on your combat as you get better you can push it more.  I do like this format though.
Stealth/ crime: This is easy enough to level and there are several perks to assist with stealth effectiveness but not to the level of crouching in combat to hide. Stealth tactics will necessitate you to plan some of your heists or other covert activities.  If you are caught there is a chance to surrender and penalties vary based on the crime - you also can flee and return when the law forgets. However the guy you mugged is likely to hate you and either run from you or attack you going forward
Player choice: I feel there is a lot of choice for this game,  and that the choices matter (see above). You can impact you relationship with NPCs / if a vendor will talk to you and if you pay attention to the clues or NPC lines in a quest you can find a new path in the quest not marked by a quest marker. 

Is there anything I would change ask for?  Yes. The sequel please!  I look forward to seeing the next chapter with all the time they've had to refine their work and build on what they made with KCD. I also want to continue with Henry's story

Form a more critical point I would like the sort-of-quest with Antonia's spouse to be finished! It feels like there should have been another option or at least dialogue line... Also there are no quest markers for it. You need to do it. I would also like Henry to be a little less obsessed with the sword at the end of the game.  

I would also say the game in general runs much better on PC than console. Far more stable and much quicker loading

Unfortunately, having completed the game and a good amount of side content in some 200 hours, I have to discourage against buying it.

There are two main reasons for this: first, the infuriating amount of bugged quests and NPC interactions. Some would not complete, others jump across steps, others yet have you stuck until you randomly stumble upon a misplaced clue. We are not talking one or two bugged side quests here - a good quarter of quests are bugged to at least a noticeable degree, including two chapters of the main quest.

The second reason not to play this is the amount of anti-game mechanisms forced down the player's throat. Open doors that lead to restricted areas withotu the player knowing, and subsequently getting slapped by guards. Your dog getting in the way of every herb you want to pick up, already a painful task without the stupid dog because of how small herb hitboxes are. Inaccurate bows, no matter how much you level archery. People noticing your crimes when nobody could physically notice them (on the other hand, the crime system can be exploited to Morrowind-levels of ridiculousness if you are into free money). Limited saves materialized by potions that take up space in your limited inventory. Impractical fast travel. And the worst of all, random encounters where half a dozen bandits suddenly jump you, during impractical fast travel, when your last save potion was already spent one hour ago.

There are of course qualities to the game, such as its historical setting, some side quests that dig quite deep in life at that period of time, and the primary quest that is quite well thought out when it does not lose itself in bugs. I just do not believe they are worth the effort in the end.

143869656.review:
On the surface a decent, generic RPG with "realism".

Sadly, there's A LOT wrong with it.

One infuriating thing is that your camera is glued to the model, for which there is no reason what so ever, no benefit what so ever that could justify the cost of being jerked around by the shitty model animations and ragdolls with those terrible moments of loss of user input.

Another is target aquisition. If you are fighting with more than 1 opponent, which is ALWAYS, switching between them is a nightmare. It is so garbage that when you try to turn around and run, the game twists your neck, breaking your spine, forcing you to face them again leading to absolute chaos made worse by the aforementioned camera nonsense.

As usual with such RPG's, there's a plethora of "what the fuck are you doing?" NPC moments, usually revolving around guards who attack you for no reason, because for example you were in a private space, then left it, but the NPC's brain didn't register that. One time I got locked inside of a room by the guy I went to talk to... I had to wait for him to wake up because they say "fuck off, let me sleep!" if you try to interact with them... And then I had to glitch through the door as he was going through it because otherwise he'd lock me there with no way out for another day.

The "savior schnaps" ninkompup nonsense is one of the many reasons why mods are absolutely vital to fix essential issues with the intentional game design. Not only is it disrespectful to the player, it also does a lot to ruin the immersion to find "save" potions littered around, or having to buy them.

I recommend getting unlimited inventory mod while you are at it. It is a far more pleasant, seamless experience - something that Gothic did right. If a game wants a "realistic" mechanic, it better make damn sure it's realistic enough to justify it, as in give me a squire with a wagon that I can send off on an errand to sell all the junk I just looted from that bandit camp.

The game also features the most infuriating archery imaginable. Even as a total newb irl you'd NEVER shoot this poorly, and this infuriatingly slowly, with this atrocious horizontal slide. The arrow should point at the target the moment you nook it, and stay straight until you release it, which should take the least amount of time necessary, not this slow, labored actions that feels like you are ripping a tendon out of the entire length of your arm.

Overall, it is entirely too slow and junky to really enjoy it. For patient history enthusiasts only.

I really liked The Woman's Lot DLC though. I wish someone made a game where you play as a woman in a medieval society with all of what that entails.

The dog is also infuriating, btw. Constantly gets in the way. Every time you loot or pick herbs he jumps at your feet, and since his hitbox is so huge you'll enjoy unintentionally opening and then closing dialog with your dog hundreds of times.
Really wish the dog's actions were tied to keybinds with no dialog, and that he only did what you told him to, that there was a whistle to make him go to where you point, that he could distract people to help with thieving or to lure them away from a camp.

Also, make sure to get the 'first person herb picking' mod. For a game that irrationaly disallows third person camera despite literally having the entire model in first person, it is realy annoying how they've done the herb picking animation.

It's also a little disappointing how many things that should have been animated are just black screens, and also how some characters that are named in spoken dialogue and quest descriptions... do not have names given in the game. For some reason. o.0

143830087.review:
I just finished the main story line and am totally blown away. This is a superb story peppered with detailed and intriguing history. They managed to balance perfectly all the facets of great storytelling: action, humor, romance and more.

The combat feels a bit clunky at first. There is a steep learning curve with becoming a great warrior and the developer chose to make it feel real with this intentionally difficult combat early on. Stick with it, and once you and your character learn and practice (I recommend the Rattay Tourney and talking to Bernard), your investment will pay off and combat becomes incredibly fun. This game has created the ultimate combat system, my favorite of any game I've played. 

Dialogue is engaging, well-acted, and concise enough to keep me interested. I often find myself impatiently skipping dialogue in games but not this one. I loved the writing and its delivery all the way through and actually became invested in the characters and story which is pretty rare for me in a video game.

The quests are plentiful, diverse, and unpredictable. The music is just right. There is a ton to do in this open world of Bohemia. The list of pros really goes on an on.

The only cons for me were occasional extra-long load times and some of the dialogue scenes weren't cued up with the audio which was hard to watch time to time. However, that may have been an issue with my PC because I played this game previously on XBOX and it was fine. Either way, the pros of this game are so vast that these minor issues are greatly overshadowed. 

I highly recommend this beautiful masterpiece and strongly feel that those who choose not to play it are missing out on what I believe to be one of the greatest games of all time. I humbly thank the developers and everyone who played a role for producing such fine work and I look forward to more (trilogy please!).

143806590.review:
One of the greatest games I have ever played. No game comes close to simulating medieval life as Kingdom Come: Deliverance and it feels incredibly authentic.

Good:
+ The setting is fascinating, and the way the lore and codex are managed in the game teaches you about the period.
+ The main quest is engaging and interesting, and the side quests are enjoyable, even the ones that appear mundane.
+ The characters feel real and well written, their conversations are natural and they have their flaws which makes them seem very 'human'.
+ The music is fantastic, the best score I've heard for a medieval game.

Bad:
- The voice acting varies. Henry the main character has a brilliant voice actor but often the characters in the game are voiced poorly. Often they are voiced by Americans, or Americans trying (and failing) to do an English accent. Why the devs didn't just have an all-British voice cast is beyond me, American accents in a medieval game really kill the immersion for me.
- There are bugs, I fortunately didn't encounter anything too severe but there were quite a few bizarre cases of characters disappearing in cutscenes.
- The pace at which you progress in the game seems all over the place. Combat is incredibly difficult early on, but after a while you can easily get the best armour in the game and still have most of the main quest to do. 

Overall I would recommend the game to everyone, it really is an incredible experience.

143793367.review:
I wish steam had a "neutral" option for whether or not I'd recommend it. It's a fun game, albeit deeply flawed in a lot of ways. To keep it short, the game goes for realism, even in situations where that realism makes for a significantly worse gaming experience. 

Baring complaints about realism, there's also a lot of jank in the game; you'll get stuck in objects and difficult terrain, I fell through the world once or twice, movement and combat can be inconsistent depending on what the game feels like doing at that moment, and the auto-locking camera for combat is genuinely the worst one I've ever experienced in a game. It's not uncommon that you'll try to run away from an unwinnable encounter only to have the camera aggressively whip around 180* because it locked on to an enemy who's chasing you. I've died to the terrible camera and general jank many times. 

I'm not willing to give it a not-recommended rating because it's a fun and objectively good game, but it's also a game for a very specific kind of person. This isn't a casual RPG to the tune of an Elder Scrolls title, this is a "hardcore" historical game that doesn't hold your hand in any capacity. Do with that what you will.

143743837.review:
I'm just shy of four hours in, and I feel like I've given it a fair shake.

I'm about to start my fifth main-story mission, and it's still a tutorial. Apparently these tutorials stretch through mission seven, and there are only 16 missions in the game. From what I can tell and have read, most of my remaining time in the game would be spent grinding through side-quests to up my skills in order to complete those remaining non-tutorial main missions.

Which would be fine, but I haven't really done anything of note in these first four hours. All I've *really* done so far is:

- Walked around a town and grabbed some stuff from people
- I took a horse and rode it somewhere
- I've slept and ate things a few times
- I attempted to dig a hole
- I dug up a hole
- I watched a lot of cutscenes
- I opened some boxes and found things such as pretzels and cloth, as well as some gear (though the game would only tell me I wasn't skilled enough to use said gear until two hours later)
- I had two sword fights with bandits that lasted all of 10 seconds
- I did a heck of a lot of walking

I'm not really *doing* anything. I'm just sort of wandering here and there, as the story dictates me to, and the world is this very empty and very barren place. I walk to a place, a cutscene plays out....and off I go to walk to the next place and cutscene. Nothing's compelling me to explore, and because of the grounded nature of the game, I know I'm likely not going to find anything remarkably interesting in the world.

Even then, the grounded nature is this weird half-step. I need to do realistic things like eat and sleep, or else I'll presumably die. I can't save all the time for...reasons? I haven't found it to be an issue, but it is what it is. 

But, even though the game is grounded in these specific ways, I have a magical chest next to every bed that contains all the items I've ever dumped into it and I can always access said chest and items in any inn in the world. And the twon guards magically possess the ability to identify stolen goods I carry, even though I stole those goods far far away in a different castle that would take days to walk to.

It's not a bad game. In fact, I find it a somewhat interesting game. It's just not giving me a reason to keep playing it.

143735325.review:
Muy buen juego. Lo único malo es que se termina (y no parece haber una segunda parte en el horizonte).

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
* La historia es buena. Quizá no es demasiado destacable, pero es sumamente atrapante.
* El combate es lo suficientemente complejo como para no aburrir y lo suficientemente simple como para no frustrar. Al principio es díficil ganar peleas, y realmente es mejor intentar evitarlas. Con el tiempo se vuelve imposible ser derrotado.
* El mundo se siente lleno y fiel a la realidad bohemia del año 1403.

[h1] Contras: [/h1]
* Bastantes bugs y glitches, como todos comentan por acá. Una vez tuve que cargar un guardado previo porque quedé atrapado en el caballo en el establo de Talmberg.
* Hay personajes con los que se podría tener relaciones más profundas y sin embargo están "incompletos" ([spoiler] el Padre Godwin, o el romance con Theresa [/spoiler], por ejemplo).
* El final se siente precipitado.

[h1] Sobre los DLC: [/h1]
* A Woman's Lot me aburrió [spoiler] en la parte de la mina de Skalitz, jugando como Theresa [/spoiler]  y no lo terminé.
* Band of Bastards es divertido. [spoiler] Poder jugar un par de misiones con otros guerreros para cortar con la soledad de cabalgar solo con Mutt (el perro) al lado está bueno. Sin embargo, al igual que con el juego principal, ciertos personajes se sienten incompletos y el final es precipitado. Recomiendo jugarlo antes de Vranik. [/spoiler]
* Amorous Adventures es moralmente polémico (?) y muy divertido. Es casi necesario jugarlo, para que tenga sentido el resto del juego. [spoiler] También es mejor antes de Vranik [/spoiler].
* From the Ashes es un poco rutinario, aunque el resultado final probablemente lo vale. No recomiendo dejarlo para el final como hice yo, porque se puede tornar frustrante por falta de fondos y aburrido.

Considerando todo, es un muy buen juego. Me hubiera gustado que ciertos personajes tengan más desarrollo y que el combate sea un poco más desafiante; incluso habiendo dominado totalmente la técnica de espada. Necesito más juegos así.

143730695.review:
A glitch-ridden mess that was promised to be a grand story with incredible combat. Unfortunately, the devs lacked the skill or character to follow through on those promises, leaving the game unfinished and unpolished with loads of missing and removed content. They focused more on removing exploits and player-discovered cheats than actually finishing the story.

Henry begins as a peasant and is pretty useless at everything, so player skill actually does not matter until Henry"s skill levels rise, making combat rather annoying until it becomes really easy. Glitches in combat can result in Henry freezing or not landing a hit, which leaves him vulnerable to attack. Common bandits are formally trained experts who take on bizarre stances that only the extremely wealthy who had master trainers would ever use, and even then they were for duels and not open combat.

It is a shame that the game had such promise but is filled with game-breaking bugs. For example, a current runthrough of mine had a character going to bed as a quest started, so rather than him ever head to the quest area, he just sleeps. I had to fail the first part of the quest so he would leave the area, but now he has never arrived at the second location even though I am supposed to meet him there. Bugs like this are common and lots of saving is required, though saving in the game is its own annoyance because you cannot just save a lot. You need to use an item and your amount of slave slots is limited.

Mods are vital to fix certain issues, which is lazy on the part of the devs and annoying at the best of times.

The story is incomplete and not what was promised. Originally on their Kickstarter, Warhorse promised multiple acts, plus some DLC. While the DLC materialized, these were things that should have been in the base game. The second act of the game never happens, so Henry's personal quest is NEVER resolved, though it was clearly supposed to. Now, Warhorse has been bought out and the devs keep teasing that a sequel is on the way. Instead of them ever finishing the first game, they want more money to sell a new game that just finishes the plot of a game that should have been done in 2018. It's just a con at this point.

Don't waste your time on the game. I have sunk entirely too much into it, and the only reason I keep wasting my time is a stubborn refusal to have wasted money buying something and not getting my money's worth.

143687061.review:
[b]TL:DR: 
Kingdom Come Deliverance is an "alright game”; however, it is NOT a great nor outstanding game to play to me because it fails far short in its game design, combat mechanics, and overall immersion realism impression. [/b] 

[b][u] Game Design [/u] [/b]
First off, the design of the game save function and implementation is very obnoxious and can ruin your progression.  The game is designed to use multiple save files such as auto-saves, permanent saves, exit saves, and manual saves. It automatically performs these at different times while you are playing the game. It does not overwrite the previous save per type, but continually adds new save files to the game save folder which can grow the number of save files on your hard drive to a maximum of 300 separate files. When the max number is reached the game fails to save any further progress unless you manually open the save folder and delete prior save files. This becomes a micro-management task in order to avoid losing game progression. If you do not manually babysit the save file, you can lose many hours of game progression. 
👎

[b][u] Graphics [/u] [/b]
I played the game on Ultra video settings. It looks and performed great without any problems. This is a very strong point for game immersion and realism despite the awkward combat mechanics..  👍

[b][u] Difficulty [/u] [/b]
Nominal. Nothing to remark on except for the ever-increasing numbers of enemies against you as you progress through the game. Combat can become a real hardship if you don't put in many hours to learn the basics. 

[b][u] Game Bugs / Oddities, etc.   [/u] [/b]
There is existing collision detection with some shrubs in-game which can be break game immersion and become annoying especially when during combat. The only way around it is to use a game modification script to remove the collision.  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯


[b][u] Price / Worth Buying  [/u] [/b]  
I paid a total of 8.3 Euros for the game and all DLC combined which equates to an investment of 0.08 Euros per game hour spent. If you can find a similar sales discount offer for the game at 85% off or higher from its standard sales price and you know for certain that  you’d enjoy it, then by all means buy it. 👍

I do NOT recommend buying the game or its DLC at regular price – but ONLY BUY AT A DEEP DISCOUNT PRICE because its  well quite old at the time of writing this review.  Its no longer being updated or patched, so if you have a problem that needs fixed, then your only recourse for fix the problem is through using a modification file script from sites like Nexus mods, etc.    I rate the game as mediocre quality due to the severity in grinding. You been officially warned. 😠

Good luck on your journey.

My account, at this time, shows a mere 5 hours of playtime, but I played this game for 19 hours according to my Sony account. Let me say that this game is very well done; I'm truly impressed with the effort that the developers have placed into this gem of a game. The gameplay is slightly slower than some other RPG's, but the story more than makes up for the somewhat gimmicky walking mechanics, strange wall-phasing glitches, and frightening camera angles that are shown in the cutscenes. Those are the only downsides to a game that boasts of heavy amounts of historical research and unique game mechanics that make the combat and inventory somewhat foreign, but quite enjoyable as well (especially the combat! At first, it's incredibly difficult to even face a minor brawl, but once you get the hang of the basics, you can learn the rest quite feasibly). 

Definitely pick this up! The story is one of the richest and riveting that I've ever had in a video game (and I haven't even completed the story yet), the graphics are spectacular, gameplay is marvelous, and the characters are memorable. I promise you'll enjoy it!
