143657011.review:
[h1]TL;DR:[/h1] Looks pretty, don't buy if you wanna act like a would-be-Sauron -knight, possible fun for fans of QTEs.

Looks fantastic but combat and thus half of the game is painful for all the wrong reasons. You're a blacksmith's boy who doesn't know anything about anything beyond your home village, you start with zero experience on almost everything and you must practice to get good at anything. Yes, I get that. But when the combat system punishes you for trying to combat people, you know it's gonna be bad. 

To elaborate, if you try to attack an enemy and 80% of the time you're rewarded with a perfect counter on your face, there's no point in being an active participant. Just wait for your enemy to attack you, press Q at the right time and perform a counter on them instead. That's what the combat boils down to on higher levels. Or if you're against an enemy that's basically as useless as you are at the start of the game, they're probably gonna die in one or two hits. Fun.

Using stealth is also a bit of a pain at the start as you're not actually as stealthy as you think. If you sneak up on a couple of sleeping people and stealth kill one of them while your stealth skill is relatively low, you're 100% gonna wake up everyone around you. Come back later with maxed out stealth and would you look at that, the exact same animations with the exact same sounds at the exact same volumes play but now you're completely fine.

Diplomacy is also an option but the best it can do is skip a few combat sections, you're still stuck on the narrative train tracks laid before you but that's understandable in a game where your decisions have no actual impact on the story.

The graphics are great though quite resource intensive. But boy howdy did I appreciate being able to see the light of a bandit's torch through a tent's fabric as I was trying to sneak through and away from said bandits.

The DLCs offer some extra spice but not much new to what you'll see in the base game, except for rebuilding a certain town. Some of the cutscenes and interactions quests in general were hilarious as well. But I still want to punch Capon in the face myself.

Yeah, I did enjoy some of my time with this game, about 30%, but most of the time was more about farming for XP and doing what to me felt more like a chore, 50% and the rest of the time was just frustration. Sure was fun to lose 5 hours of progress on Hardcore mode because I died from fall damage as I got off my horse while I didn't expect to die anytime soon as I didn't want to sleep in a bed half a map away, get nightmares (stat debuff on Hardcore mode), wait around for it to go away and then ride back to a mission while also not being able to use Savior Schnapps (yes, an actual consumable item you need to have in order to save without a bed) because I didn't want to level up my drinking skill too much in order to get sh*tfaced in one single quest I didn't essentially fail in my previous playthroughs. If that sentence feels like a chore to go through then you are [b]not [/b] prepared to complete Kingdom Come.

I'm sorry, there's some really good stuff like history, graphics, even actual real places (Warhorse even got the actual river by Rattay right) but man, half of what I can remember of this game are just all the grinding for levels but not the actual rewards.

143575430.review:
A great potential that ended up a great failure.

This game started off with a pretty interesting fighting system that allowed for flashy combos that felt good and looked good, but devs decided to completely eliminate any fun from the fights by making enemies master strike your every move. No matter how staggered they are, even a lowly peasant can master strike you out of any combo. Not only that, they will often get 3-5 hits on you that you can't block, but when you master strike that does not happen. People cope that Henry was a peasant not a knight so he starts off as a bad fighter, but since even the dumbest, weakest enemies can perfectly master strike you, that's a moot point.

The "realism" part of the game is, as with most games that attempt to be ""realistic"", purely an inconvenience and is not done in an interesting way. A mod for manual saving is a necessity given how jank and unstable the game can get. In general this game is hard to make bearable even with mods that try to combat the fake realism the game is selling.

It's hard to point out many positives in this game. The graphics can look quite nice at times, but they are glitchy and the game is extremely unoptimised, so even with tweaks and mods you tend to sacrifice a lot of the graphics to make the game playable. The random lag can make the already horrendous combat even worse. The dialogues can be good, although in some cases I wanted to reach through the screen and knock some sense into Henry after he said some dumb shit.

Overall, wouldn't recommend the game. There is a lot of people coping that the fighting system is realistic and Henry is meant to start off week, but as someone who maxed out all stats and also tried some anti-master strike mods afterwards (they don't really work), the combat never gets better. It's not hard, but it's tedious. You can cheese the game with a bow, or spend 10 minutes waiting to master strike the enemy 50 times or walk away while preparing a feint. Don't bother.

143561651.review:
I bought this with several DLCs at $9.99.  After 5 hours I've already gotten my money's worth - this is my go-to game for playing Farkle (a dice gambling game).  The game has gotten varied responses, but from what I could tell before buying it, it reminded me enough of Mount and Blade that I figured I really had nothing to lose giving it a try.

This is an RPG.  But it's historically based, and other than alchemy, doesn't have any of the common RPG elements.  There aren't any mages or orcs - there is a lot of real-world history though.

I got fair warning from one review that the first 7 hours of the game is very linear - you really cannot stray from the path the game holds you in at first.  So I'm still in this sort of "tutorial" or "cinematic" mode, which can also be very challenging and cliff-hanger in places.  I have no regrets, I've enjoyed the ride thus far.

I'm hoping to get far enough in the plot to say "okay I think I get it" and then switch the whole game into German, to give my ear some good exercise at hearing German again.  The game is historically not so accurate - but as I am and never have been much of a student of history, I'm happy just to learn about some historical figures, even if the game doesn't get things completely right.  As far as the day-to-day medieval lifestyle depiction, this does a good job, as far as I can tell.

But is it fun?  Well so far, yes.  It was very satisfying to, after getting my ass kicked by one of the first people I had to fight, to replay the game and first raise some money playing Farkle, and then buy a butchers knife with which I was able to go back and give him quite the lashing until he begged for mercy.  Yeah... I think I could enjoy this!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3016242267

My biggest complaint is that the camera does tend to make me feel sick, especially if I try picking herbs and the animation jerks the camera around, or just walking or running.  I think they attached the camera to the player's head and the head is bobbing around - which is a bit TOO realistic, because that little extra camera bobbing just gives me a headache.  This even happens if I watch videos of other people playing.  So I find myself closing the game often because I can't stand getting a headache.  I've tried slowing down the mouse sensitivity to a very low setting, and widening the FOV as wide as it goes, and turning the motion blur off, but still this is a problem for me.

I have also noticed the game does introduce occasional drops in frame-rate regardless how low I set the screen resolution.  At 640x480 I still see these drops, and I attribute them to the game loading different map areas inefficiently.  Admittedly I don't have a screaming fast system, and I'm running from a relatively slow physical media hard-drive, so your mileage may vary.

A lot of time is spent in cut-scenes, and the game starts very slowly, which can create a bit of a drag.  There are also tons of Easter eggs which motivates me to try to talk to everybody as much as possible.  If you're in a big hurry, this game is probably not for you.  If you're very picky that everything be "just so" - nope, not for you.  But I get the feeling that if you, like me, are open to letting the game tell its own story, there is something here that is going to pay off.  As I spend more time and let the story unfold in front of me, I'm willing to give the game this chance.

143558590.review: The combat in this game is God awful. Actual 0 effort put into making combat work well

143556024.review:
So... if I could, I would put an asterisk next to the positive review. Let me start out by saying this game is good. I enjoyed it. BUT! It has so, so many problems. Some of them can be alleviated but maaaan this game is really rough around the edges. I wouldn't say it is cyberpunk bad, but it is pretty bad.

Most of the game's problems come down to game design. They have attached saving to a consumable item. Once you get late in the game this becomes a non-issue, but for the ENTIRE first half of the game it (probably) is a huuuuge issue. The hard-core community of this game defends this mechanic TO THE DEATH. To which I can only respond: This game sold 5 million copies, and 1.1 million people downloaded the mod to remove that mechanic off of Nexusmods. 20% of the players of this game disagree with those people. It is a horrible mechanic and when I downloaded the mod it became a lot easier.

The other problem this game suffers from is NPCs that are too difficult. If anyone has played For Honor against the hardest difficulty enemies knows exactly what I'm talking about. Doesn't matter how fast you are, or if you feint attacks, the enemies can read your button inputs and react accordingly. The same problem exists in this game. The game has feints, and tells you to use them. But they're completely useless and should never be used. Primarily because blocking attacks is a radius and feinting does literally nothing. 

The game also has another issue: It tries to make the game realistic in the worst way possible. You need to eat and sleep, which is fine. Not really an issue, but you have fast travel. It tries to make archery realistic by removing your damn crosshair. This is a stupid mechanic and I recommend using the console command wh_pl_showfirecursor 1 to enable it. Makes the game 10,000,000 times less frustrating. If the enemies can hit their shots every time, I should be able to as well. F*ck you. 

Overall, the game is fun, the story is good, and it gives real historical facts about the area and period. It's amazing! And handles it well! When the game goes on sale, buy it. It's good. But be ready for a lot of issues, and don't forget to download the mod which removes the consumable saving mechanic. There's a reason why only 10% of people have actually beaten the game. 


TLDR; Game is good, mechanics range from bad to frustrating. Download the mod to remove consumable-tied saving and use the wh_pl_showfirecursor 1 command to make archery usable. Buy it when on sale as it is not worth full price.

143546692.review:
A really beautiful medieval world with a newfangled ugly combat system without a guide.

During my first gaming experience years ago and after a few hours I gave up in frustration because I didn't like the combat system. Recently got back to the game and after a thorough read up I have no more problems. What is missing here is a game manual. No, not this incomplete ingame frustration. If you come up with something completely new, then maybe you should let the target group know about it? Even if I win every fight, it is still not clear what this or that push of a button or multiple pushes of a button does. Precisely because there is so much animation taking place in which you have an influence with the press - or not - I don't know! Time windows for a targeted press simply cannot be found and a wild clicker ensues. Intention? No idea! The combat system is still shit.

For people who depend on a controller, hardcore should be unplayable. In normal mode, for example, it is still displayed when an opponent attacks outside of the field of view and you have to block. That's not the case in hardcore. Switching opponents in a targeted manner to keep track of things is impossible with the controller.

143386647.review:
It's a weird feeling to not recommend a game that I have played for 60 hours, but honestly, unless you are desperate for a medieval RPG, it's not worth it. It is fantastically immersive, in the sense that, starting as a peasant boy, you can do absolutely nothing. You can't fight, you can't steal, you can't read, you can barely even talk!

Once you've sunk some serious time in and have built up enough skill and strength to armour up properly, there are hints of fun now and again, but the game is ridden with inflexible missions and impossible-to-predict consequences. This is all good for an RPG, as it makes it feel real, but combined with the frequent game-breaking bugs, it is also incredibly frustrating. I won't even get into problems like how you can't pick a lock on a controller but have to switch to M+K just to do so.

I have had fun playing the game, but the frustrating and boring parts far outweigh it. As I write this I have begun a main quest that I can't get out of which is very tedious (not to mention difficult). When things go well, it's a beautiful game that has nuanced and outstanding gameplay, but when things go badly it's infuriatingly difficult, tedious, and, at times, outright bugged. Only buy it if it's cheap and/or you know for sure that you don't mind it being like this.

143351227.review:
Don't get me wrong, this game is a great game, but I would not recommend it to most people. The game is very grounded, and I mean VERY grounded in realism. If you are looking for a realistic immersive story told in medieval times then this game is perfect for you, but if you're just looking for a fun medieval rpg this game can be infuriating.

As the son of a blacksmith you aren't exactly the strength of a witcher, dragonslayer, or even a basic knight and the game makes sure you feel that. Combat, like the rest of the game, is entirely in first person and enemies can easily spin you around which can feel disorienting. All of your skills combat and otherwise need to be developed through usage similar to games like Skyrim. Which because of the grounded combat, you can expect to get your butt handed to you at the beginning of the game. And you'll need to care for those injuries asap because the less health you have the less stamina you can use making it so as you get injured in combat it becomes increasingly harder to fight back and stay alive.

You need to sleep, eat, and bathe in this game in order to survive (not bathing won't kill you but it does effect how others treat you). But be careful: if you eat too much it will negatively effect you. In terms of immersive mechanics the game even goes as far as to require you to teach Henry to read if you want to actually read whats in books in this game. The game has no crosshair when aiming a bow, which is ironic considering there is one when you're not using a bow. And the only way to save the game is through drinking saviour schnapps or sleeping (this choice felt odd to me because while it makes sense as a difficulty option, there is no such thing as a realistic save system apart from permadeath I guess. And forcing this save system means that even on the easiest difficulty you could get set back 30+ minutes because a bandit attacked you on your way to a bathhouse).

However, as you build up Henry's skills, it does get easier. Hell by the end of the game you're a nearly unstoppable force in heavy armor. Or at least that's what I've heard, I have yet to get that far. I've heard that one of the easiest ways to get op fast is by repeatedly training with Bernard but I found that rather tedious and I personally do enjoy the grounded realistic struggle Henry is facing. The world has plenty of side quests but also infinitely repeatable side activities that are randomized. While its open world isn't anything special it does compliment the game's overall themes and general vibe really well. The world is pretty empty, not that it is devoid of life but rather in a way that is realistic. Just like real life a hike in the woods isn't going to guarantee that you see anything of interest, but there are just enough things scattered around the world that makes exploration worth it.

So is this game a good game? Yes. Is this game fun? Yes. Would I recommend it to the general audience? Hell no.

143346005.review:
*Not a controller game*

This game was really fun for the first 10 or 20 hours however the more I played it with a controller, the more I realized this game is not meant for controller and the controller support or design is really subpar.

The good: The world itself seems very full of life with many NPCs offering unique quests or just in general being very fun to explore as there are many hidden treasures afoot. The weapon repairing system seems a little strange at first but becomes quite fun and satisfying once you get the hang of it and even becomes a fun way to make some extra money. The alchemy system is fun to do for maybe the first 5 hours and then gets a little tedious after that however I still enjoyed it past that as long as I spaced out when I did it.    

The bad:  The trading system is a little awkward but not too bad however needing to do it constantly when you don't need the money just for relationships/ better prices in the future gets annoying after a little while. The lock picking controls for *controller* are super awkward at best and really obnoxious at worst compared to mouse and keyboard where its simple and enjoyable. Take this with a grain of salt because I never finished it but, the main story has a lot of bumps and its writing is honestly just awkward a lot of the time. I had to take a lot of breaks from the main story because of how bland it felt. A lot of the characters just weren't redeemable or enjoyable to interact with from what I played. The dialogue just felt bland and it wasn't really compelling for me to continue the story it however it wasn't the reason I dropped the game or had to mod it just to try and enjoy it.

The ugly: The combat goes from awkward to just extremely tedious and it feels like there is somewhat of an input lag or something when trying to do combos on controller compared to mouse and keyboard. The scaling from early to "late" game doesn't help that at all. When fighting more than one person on controller you have to up your sensitivity super high or else any time an enemy tries to run around you your camera wont be able to keep up because of how the camera will snap back to targets. There is no easy way to switch targets with controller. You also cannot run away with controller because your camera will constantly do 180 degree spins to re-engage which keeps slowing you down so the enemy can tackle you or just get in free pot shots so you simply have to reload however far back and just avoid any fights with more than 2 people who are armored or difficult for you to fight. I tried to mod the combat to make it more enjoyable by removing some aspects that just don't work on controller like the master strikes but with how much frustration I experienced when I didn't want to constantly be doing combat but would get forced into so often made it harder to go back and test things out to see how they were re-balanced with the mods I installed to make things more enjoyable. The master strikes definitely killed the game for me as when enemies got more armored the fights got dragged out more and then you could constantly get master strike'd so you couldn't even do any fun combos anymore and for some reason (I'm unsure if this is a controller only issue but it seems like it possibly is) half the time a prompt came up to master strike or deflect it just wouldn't happen no matter how I tried to change my approach. All of that plus the enemies being super armored and taking 9 years to fight, the camera snapping constantly when trying to back off, and then multiple of the master swordsmen being in one place just ruined it for me. 

Overall I would give what I played of this game a 6/10 and say I enjoyed about 40 out of the 68 hours I played of this game. I would recommend this to people who prefer or are able to play on mouse and keyboard unlike myself at the time I played this, but do not recommend this to people who can only play on controller or heavily prefer controller for games like these.

143221517.review:
My initial review was: "This is such a bad game, don't even buy it when it's on sale. If you don't believe me, read up on the save system which is absolute bonkers. This combined with a million bugs and clunky gameplay makes for an absolutely horrible experience."

After spending some more hours on it, I can give a more nuanced review: I think this game is a casual player's idea of a hardcore game, which explains all the positive reviews. My personal opinion: The game pretends to be deep and difficult, but playing it feels very shallow, with no options to make meaningful decisions when skilling your character, painfully boring fights (just bonk them on the head) and almost every quest being boring fetch/kill stuff.

The developers tried to introduce some unique mechanics, but these mostly turned out horrible. The save system is the best example for what I feel is just bad game design.

However, the game has two strengths: atmosphere and dialogue. If you are looking for an atmospheric medieval game, maybe it's worth overlooking the game's weaknesses and giving it a try.

143219113.review:
This is nice game, once you accept its flaws.
This is definitely unique experience - to have open world game set in medieval times is rarity. Kingom Come is doing great job of being very immersive on every level. Detailed animations, along with basic needs like sleep, eat and maintaining your equipment allows to just enjoy the life in medieval times. There are plenty of great characters and it's always great to listen to conversations.
But, as mentioned before, this game has also a lot of flaws. Combat, while crazy demanding, which is really fun, also tends to just not work with larger groups of enemies. Game is trying to be realistic, which comes with bunch of unpolished gameplay aspects that can irritate - like unrewarding perks for leveling up, unbalanced weapons and overall clunkiness of many mechanics can be tiring, and please don't make me start about archery.
As for the story - it's good. 3/4 of the game is really interesting, but starts to unnecessarily drag at the end. Side quests and DLCs are either hit or miss, beacuse they tend to be repetetive in the end.
But overall I can recommend it for still being enjoyable and unique experience, despite its flaws - because what game is perfect.

143192188.review:
KC:D is what I would consider an amazing RPG that hits most of the itches that I have when I want to play an RPG. The start, of you as a 'nobody' going on to rise through the ranks and become proficient in any field you choose, is one that is not explored much in many other RPGs. The skill progression system is interesting, and the earlygame perks some thought put into them. (For example, you can only choose one of two perks if they are incompatible with each other, such as having a fast but small stamina meter or a slow but large one). The story is compelling although it does fall under the usual trope of 'Revenge'.

The main, and perhaps only peeve I have with the game is that combat is terrible when facing more than 2-3 opponents at the same time. While fighting and focusing on one enemy, the others can take potshots at you out of your FOV and there's not much you can do to mitigate that. If the game restricted the combat encounters to a max of around 3 opponents, the game would rise greatly in my personal ranking. 

All that put together, I would rate the game a solid 8/10. It's not for everyone, but those who like it will REALLY like it. 143095174.review:
A Medieval Gem Worth Experiencing!

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4 out of 5 stars)

Kingdom Come: Deliverance is an extraordinary medieval RPG that captivated me from the very beginning. Immerse yourself in a realistic world where your choices truly matter, and the journey is as thrilling as the destination. This game is an incredible adventure that is undoubtedly worth experiencing at least once.

The attention to historical accuracy and detail in Kingdom Come: Deliverance is commendable. The landscapes, architecture, and character designs transport you to 15th-century Bohemia, making the world feel alive and vibrant. The gripping storyline, inspired by real historical events, kept me engrossed and invested in the fate of the protagonist.

The game's open-world nature offers unprecedented freedom, allowing you to shape your character's destiny through your actions and decisions. From stealthy infiltration to full-blown combat, the gameplay options are diverse and satisfying. The skill-based progression system feels rewarding, as you witness your character evolve with every challenge conquered.

Despite its brilliance, I must admit that there are some minor bugs and glitches that occasionally crop up. However, the game runs quite smoothly. These occasional annoyances didn't detract significantly from my overall enjoyment.

In conclusion, Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a masterpiece that transports players to a bygone era, offering an unforgettable and immersive experience. The small bugs, though present, should not overshadow the sheer beauty and depth of this game. If you have a passion for rich storytelling, historical accuracy, and immersive RPG gameplay, do yourself a favor and embark on this epic journey. It's a game that will leave a lasting impression and keep you yearning for more.

143006656.review:
I will start off by saying my lack of enjoyment for this game was partially my own fault. Obviously there is a lot of love for this game, and I absolutely get why. The world, the aesthetic, the politics - I loved everything about the idea of this game. The setting was so interesting, and so refreshingly different from anything I have played before. I kept waiting for the gameplay to sink its hooks in me, but it just never did.

I downloaded this game for a long flight thinking it would be the perfect game to pass the time (this game is impressively Steam Deck compatible). As I said above, I was immediately intrigued by the setting, characters, and plot of this world. The gameplay was clunky but again, I loved the idea of starting as a “nobody” and working my way up - a game path more games need to try (how many “you are the chosen one” game types do we have already). But the starting “commoner” gameplay is CLUNKY. You quite literally start from zero. I did a number of tutorials and did my best to practice them all - introduction to fighting, lockpicking, bartering/selling - all of these systems are incredibly in depth and hard to master. I made my way through chunks of the intro until I got to a point where I had to lockpick a lock to get some necessary equipment to advance a quest. Only, as I stated before, the lockpicking is incredibly difficult in this game (if you google it you can see how controversial the difficulty is for yourself) and I couldn't get the chest open with my one lockpick. So I effectively softlocked myself at the start of my plane ride, and I swapped out games and put Kingdom Come aside for a little bit. A few weeks later I researched lockpicking a bit more and decided to give it another chance - I discovered there was an “easier lockpick” option baked into the actual game settings itself, which I didn’t feel too bad about using as it is still incredibly difficult. I managed to get that chest unlocked, and progressed through that section and moved the plot along incrementally.

This allowed me to get a little bit farther at which point I was offered a quest to do one of the side DLC missions that  sort of showed the start of the game again from a different perspective. Given I had taken a few weeks off from playing it I thought this would be a good idea. It was not. If you are reading this DO NOT do the DLC’s early on in this game, it messes with the pacing horribly. I did the first half of “a Woman’s Lot” DLC which I have no doubt is a fine DLC on its own, but better off being played after the main game (or at least a good chunk of the main game). In the game’s defence, it absolutely tells you “hey you are about to start a side DLC here, are you sure you want to proceed” but I chose to go this route thinking it would catch me back up to speed. 

Well yes, you do replay the intro as another character so it was a nice plot refresher, but this DLC you play as a character that, rather than progresses slowly, does not progress at ALL (speaking in terms of skills/abilities). Once again the character you play as is a commoner and you go on a variety of quests that get decently hard, but your character never really adapts to the increasing difficulty. Which led to a complaint of mine about the next controversial topic: the save system.

Kingdom Come wants you to avoid save scumming so it uses a system by which you have to use a potion to manually save the game (with an auto save system in place as well). So no quick save/quick load here. I loved the concept of this: the game wants you to live with your decisions, but unfortunately the gameplay is way too clunky for a system like this. In the DLC mission you are given a stealth-instant-kill option which the quests are very much designed around. You are not good with a sword, so you are going to  lose a sword fight. But jittery movement and  spotty target locks make the instant-kill feel almost RNG. Several times I lost 20-30 minute chunks of gameplay because the bad guy I was meant to instant-kill twitched out, saw I was behind him and of course killed me easily. I lost another 20 minute chunk of gameplay because I started walking too far down a path taking a wide berth from enemies, but the game did not intend for me to take this path yet, so it instant-killed me. Replaying these chunks of the game because of the game being janky, and not at all due to my own shortcomings or misplays, was incredibly frustrating.

But I proceeded on with the promise of an intriguing story and large battles ahead. I finished the DLC and returned to the main game, did a few more quests and got to a point where only again my character was “defeated” and the plot sort of restarted with me back at almost-zero again. More tutorials and more practice fighting and ok - now I learned the perfect-parry mechanic, and the game makes you practice this mechanic in a fight right away. Let me tell you I was laser focused and did my absolute best to try and win this fight - blocking, parrying, attacking - I was determined to understand this game. But after several minutes of being unable to land a swing, I am pretty sure it is impossible to win this fight so I put the controller down and let the enemy beat me - yep a scripted fight that I was supposed to lose. 

At this point I had a sad thought: “How long have I been playing this game?” Well the answer to that was 12.5 hours. Yes, a good chunk of this was the DLC you should absolutely bypass in the beginning. But 12.5 hours and I was barely past the intro, still didn’t really know how to fight (and I don’t mean advanced fighting, I mean beginner fighting). My lockpicking had not improved so that was still going to be hard, and I didn’t even have my own weapon. I haven’t even heard whispers of how to brew this manual-save potion yet. I hate tapping out of games but my backlog is WAY too long to be slogging through 12.5 hours of gameplay waiting for the game to get fun. The incredible potential of this game still has me thinking maybe I will return to it one day, but for now it has to be a pass.

142995751.review:
I absolutely fiend over this game, but I just can't recommend it to most people.

Let me start with what I love:

The combat system is where you'll be dedicating a lot of your time in-game, and is one of the most challenging and entertaining experiences I've ever had in a video game.  It plays much like MORDHAU, where swordplay isn't just button mashing but involves the use of combat zones and HEAVILY focuses on your footwork. The combat tutorials greatly highlight these two areas, and you should expect some punishment if you can't pick it up.  Just keep moving, and let your opponent make the first move. Combos, ripostes, and clinches are your friend here. It can be quite challenging at times, so I can understand that's not everyone's cup of tea.

Kingdom Come: Deliverance also nails realism very well.

You play as the young son of a blacksmith, so there are areas where you're going to be lacking, and the game is great at elucidating these aspects and telling you how to progress. This involves learning how to read, hunt, forage, fight, and so much more. You're not a one-man army. Multiple-enemy battles often involve some stealth, crafty sabotage, good positioning, or a solid combination of everything.

But on the other hand, realism can be taken too far to the point where the gameplay becomes tedious. The challenge the game presents while delivering an 'authentic' medieval experience often forces you into just a few or only one playstyle to progress quickly - or worse, breaking the game altogether.

This is by far my biggest gripe of the game and where I just can't recommend it to most. Unless you're an actual sword-fighting god, you're going to have to use sabotage/stealth for every single enemy camp, and since looting NPCs is one of the only methods to accrue a meaningful amount of capital, you should prepare to steal A LOT of stuff from the poor citizens of Bohemia. You'll progress, sure, but what's the point in offering an open world experience with only a few viable options?

142940868.review:
THE BEST GAME I'VE EVER PLAYED. 

I never expected to love this game as much as I did. It isn't my favourite genre, I'm not especially interested in medieval times (well, I wasn't before this game) and I couldn't stand Henry's face (reminded me too much of an ex). I'm lazy with games so the combat initially felt like too much effort (but take time to practice with Bernard if you're anything like me because it's a fantastically fun combat system / game element once you get used to it). It's a little rough around the edges, some parts are a bit buggy....and yet, I can easily say it's the best game I've ever played. I can't even settle into another game since completing it - all I want is more Henry :(  

The story is fantastic and the whole cast of characters are amazing and so well developed / scripted / acted. I miss them now, especially Hanush and Hans. I even ended up loving Henry, despite the face (which I was able to change a little thanks to the modding options). 

The overall experience is incredibly immersive and there are some fantastic little additions such as the dice game and some basic management/building-type stuff, later in the game. There's so much attention to detail and if you're into the history or geography, you definitely won't be disappointed. I even reached a point where my game-laze vanished and I really wanted the game to be hard and loved that some of it was (it actually becomes a bit too easy once you get the hang of the combat), because it definitely added to the immersion and fun.

The only negative is that it ended too soon. I'm praying fervently that Warhorse really are making number 2 and that it's released very soon!

142813535.review:
Just Some Guy™ Simulator 1403
Great Role playing with surprising depth of a medieval country.
If you play it like you are a Video Game Protagonist, you will get wrecked by bandits.
If you play it like you are Some Guy you will do much better.
The combat is hard, and you will suck for a while. It works out nicely that just as you get a hang of the directional strangeness and timing, your stats catch up so you can actually land blows.
The peasants will comment on your level of filth covering, and on how ragged or shiny your clothes look which I find funny. The world carries on with or without you, but you do feel like a part of it.
The game is sprinkled with these neat little touches and quirks that just suck you in and beg you to explore and dig around in all the side quests.
It's a bit ambiguous what quests are timed, what quests aren't and what quests will transport you to the next day as you do them. Beware saying 'yes' to literally everything.

Solid 9/10. Got that open world RPG jank but boy do I love it.

The game is pretty involving. You might find it quite difficult at the beginning, especially the combat system, but with the time passing and your playing hours counter increasing you will get accustomed to it and feel yourself comfortable fighting your foes.
The story line is interesting as well, it suggests you pretty divers quests, and if you are getting tired of the main story line, you also can run side quests parallel developing the main character.
The game provides a list of skill brunches, but it does not really give you a diverse choice how to develop your character, like other games in this genre do. You can become either a heavy knight or light one, which will affect only your choice of armor and combat style. But it is completely understandable, since game is focused on realism and takes place in the real medieval era of Central Europe, in Bohemia, to be more precise; so I don't think back the days there were any wizards and other magic stuff that we are used to see in other RPG games alike, for example, The Witcher.

Closely to the end of the game, I got pretty tired of it though. Since the character got quite developed and the combats became easy, I just was looking for the final scene and the curtains. It also worthy of mention that I am not a big fan of RPG and there were some other games to play in my queue, so these factors also played a role in my rush to finish the game quickly. After finishing the main story line I still had many side quests to do and even a few different DLC's to play. Unfortunately, I have not played any of the DLC's although I bore them in mind during my playthrough. but at the end I gave up that idea due to the reasons I mentioned above.

Anyways the game was interesting and really funny. The world is open and you are able to do whatever you want.

It's glitchy. Combat system tries to be deep and immersive and fails at that, forcing you to cheesing your way through enemies.

But there is a lot to love about this game.

Though a bit technologically dated (HDR? DLSS? I would love that), graphics of this open world medieval adventure still look great. The scenery and forests, towns, houses, churches, peoples clothing, its a pleasure to look at.

You work yourself from weak nobody into a reliable knight who can stand his ground against most of obstacles. Arguably some perks need rebalancing, or replacing with something useful, you will have fun building your Henry.

You will do ,any activities consisting mostly of average fetch quests (which is not bad on it's own, it's servicable padding). There is also plenty of fun and interesting actual side quests. And the grand overlapping campaign. The Kingdom of Bohemia is brewing and Europe is about to learn what is it like to live in Interesting Times. To understand context at least a bit there is quite well written codex of historical facts, also interesting bits about lives of society and people themselves.

And with Czech dub, you can finally "Pochválen buď Pán Ježíš Kristus" properly

Also runs surprisingly well on Steam Deck. With some compromises you can stay locked at 40fps which is very playable for this genre, and still get two hours of it before battery forfeits. I can only imagine how well this would perform with better optimalization and DLSS helping with frames, but that's now probably impossible dream.

Gave it four hours to impress me. Pretty graphics, but so many scripted losses and scripted binds and other stuff that it just gets tedious. Typical parents gruesomely murdered rolling-in-the-pathos vengeance plotline. Decided I wanted to shortcut the quest and go beat the dude that gave me the scripted loss, looked up where he is and it turns out the game has no satisfying conclusion to the arc. It's 'one of those' games.

Overall it's a game for if you enjoy rolling your eyes at yet another scripted loss or scripted failure in an 'open world' RPG, with what's apparently a dismal 'no hope' story. At least for the four hours I put into it. It's reminiscent of Far Cry in the tone I got in the time I played it. Complete with survival mechanics just to add extra obnoxiousness to it.

Whatever it ended up being storywise, I'm bailing. Between the scripted losses and the finnicky combat system it hits a 0/5 stars for me. This may be some peoples' ice cream, but it's my expired fermented fish. There are certainly some folks who'll vibe with the combat, Souls-like players will enjoy the timed blocks and the timed attacks, but this approximation was not fun to me...since I detest souls-like gameplay due to the compromises it makes. It feels frustratingly slow and convoluted compared to the drills that I do as a HEMA nerd swinging around a greatsword as my daily exercise. That would be okay and I'd probably learn to enjoy it...if the game's tone and storyline wasn't so dismally bleak with so many scripted losses to set up the plot.

Hard pass.

142698598.review:
This game is not recommended not because it's not good. But because the devs gave up. 

The game has almost everything I'd want in such a medieval simulation. But the lack of polish is so evident in every single thing you do in the game that it completely destroys not only the immersion, but any hope of getting a satisfying experience. 

Everything from terrible controls, collision boxes, broken ai, constant (and I mean constant) loading screens that even on PC (high end) take far too much out of your day just make this game a chore to play despite all the good stuff in it. 

In addition to these problems, the game also suffers greatly from a lack of creativity in design decisions. There's countless items named "hoods" in the game, except none of them are actually hoods nor can they be used as hoods. 

There is no real dialogue with NPCs and for most of the game you won't be able to talk to anyone except traders and activity givers. There are no interesting characters in the game save for 3 that I can name. The inability to change your brightness in game is traumatizing. Some monitors are darker than others and some people are more sensitive to blue light than others, however the devs are selfish enough to want to put accuracy at the expanse of playability. 

Combat is god awful. Was I extremely delighted to see enemies using actual combat maneuvers and stances that are not only accurate but some obscure enough that you can tell a lot of research was put in? ABSOLUTELY. But it was destroyed because of one shitty design decision. The player has a physical body outside out of cutsences that gets in the way of everything and makes fighting so damn clunky it becomes insanely difficult to fight on certain terrains. If there's so much as an inch of height difference, expect to get slaughtered. Enemies will clip thorugh things, their animations will spazz out (causing them to t-pose and DBZ you into submission) perfect block works only 30% of the time and master strikes barely ever work even when performed expertly. I spent 3 hours testing this with Captain Bernard. 

I honestly applaud the devs and creators of this game for the work they put into researching and creating this authentic experience. This is hands down one of the most accurate medieval sims I've ever played. However, with many updates, DLCs and numerous updated versions of the game, the lack of polish simply becomes unforgivable for me. 

I love this game. But I am also incredibly frustrated by it. It could have been the GOAT but it chose to be a donkey. 

I sincerely hope a sequel is coming that will iron out all of the issues and get the polish it deserves. But despite the fact I love the game so much I simply can't recommend it the way it is. I've spent more time being frustrated from the game than I did enjoying playing it.

Suggestions - 
1. remove the player's body and keep it first person. 
2. Make it possible to cancel fast travel mid way.
3. Make it so save cancelling sleep saves the game. Better yet, make it so you can save the game whenever you want without getting drunk.
4. Fix the loading times. Not every time I wash myself in a trough or eat from a pot needs a loading screen.
5. Make the world feel more alive than just having NPCs to pickpocket.
6. Make proper tutorials for everything. 90% of the gameplay isn't explained in any meaningful tutorial (including combat, inventory, archery, etc)
7. Also fix Archery. I shoot better drunk with little experience than my Henry who has mastered it shoots sober. It makes archery completely unviable and is a terrible design decision to not include a reticule ONLY for archery. If it exists at every other point of the game, it should exist when you use a bow.

142675027.review:
A+ RPG

Kingdom Come: Deliverance is a well written, well paced, excellently executed game. The Royal Edition when on sale is an absolute steal. This review comes many years after release and for that, I'm pretty happy. Often times games can be so buggy at release that the rest of the experience gets soured. 

If you want an SP RPG to sink some hours into, enjoy a medieval theme, and appreciate an immersive environment, KC:D is a choice pick.

I appreciate that it's a very colorful game without saturation just being blown out. Fields, Meadows, and clothing that can 'at-a-glance' tell you how well to do townsfolk are. The freeroam and skill climb are both very fun. You can be an upstanding Man-At-Arms by day, and be a dick-ass-thief by night. 

The engine still holds up, looking impressive and sharp. The Free HD Audio Packs definitely add to the ambiance in creating a very 'alive' feeling environment. 

This is definitely worth playing. The humor can be both subtle and unexpected. If you get the Royal Edition, the DLCs will give you nearly endless things to do so long as you're not just speedrunning the main quest. There isn't a wrong way to play KC:D, but if you don't become addicted to the dice game 'Farkle'- you haven't really played the game to its fullest.

Rags to Riches, evolving Henry as a Blacksmiths son to fancyman is a super memorable gaming experience.

142635774.review:
suppose, if this review required a title, it would be:

Realism vs Believability

I always dreamt of a massive RPG that tried to realistically emulate real life aspects of late Medieval/early Renaissance times – and here it is in the flesh.

But realism is just a word, right?Even the most realistic game – and Kingdom Come is definitely the most realistic 3D game I’ve ever played – is choke-full of conditionality. You heal slower than in most games, but you still heal overnight. You can get lost in a vast forest on hardcore difficulty where there are no markers, but it’s still only five minutes across on foot. You can fence with all the shaky camera immersion, but you are still not in control of your entire body.

But it doesn’t matter. Because any artform is smoke and mirrors in the end. It’s not about realism – it’s about whether it’s believable. The player has to believe it’s like real life. And when it comes to believability, this game has no peer.
Look at the landscapes of modern RPGs. You can see a few landmarks from each point of the map. Colors are vibrant, everything is set so that the player doesn’t get bored on the journey (the journey he’s likely to never take or take only once because of fast travel, but that’s besides the point). Kingdom Come is green during the day, grey during the rain and black during the night. It has paths that look the same, it has fields that roll across the horizon, it has streams that murmur gently and samely, and… It’s real. It’s actually not, because it’s so small you can’t really talk about a big world of any kind, but it feels real. Where in any other game a bandit camp would be marked by all sorts of signs like Shrek’s swamp, here it’s just a few small oddly twisted twigs on tree trunks along the path. In reality it would be like hanging up a neon sign: “HERE BE MERRY MEN”. By videogame standards it’s almost unnoticeable.
Or take the protagonist. A countryside simpleton – unrefined and dumb. Not stupid, not dim – just dumb. The game goes out of its way to show how much of a child he still is. As the plot progresses he slowly turns into his lord’s very own “human can-opener”©, a pragmatic down-to-the-ground problem-solver, not cruel by nature but not averse to using violence as a tool. In real life such transitions last years if not decades. Here it only takes a few weeks. But we see this process, it unfolds before our very eyes, and so we believe in it. And Henry’s reaction to the plot twist. No spoilers here. People say: “he should be angry, why isn’t he?!” But would he be – in real life? That’s the thing: he could be, and he could be not. But by not being angry he looks far more believable than he would otherwise.
Take the plot. Assassin's creed taught us that historical games are those where you meet at least a dozen prominent figures of the depicted period and get involved into the biggest of events. Nope - says Kingdom Come - a historical game is the one where you get immersed. And immersion is far more than just meeting cool people. Apart from Sigismund, there's pretty much no-one of international renown that Henry encounters. That's believable. I can only assume they are going to continue the story into proto-Reformational Hussite wars, so I suppose, historical events will be far more present and big in the next few installments, but still.

But then there is combat. And – believe it or not – combat in Kingdom Come is not believable. It’s realistic. Let me explain.

Now, local combat system got a lot of flak from the uninitiated and the uncaring, but not only from them, and the reasons to this aforementioned flak are more complex than it might seem. I would describe my relationship with it as consisting of four phases: first, I didn’t understand it, then I loved it while being bad at it, then I hated it while thinking I got good at it, and finally I accepted it for what it was and thus truly learnt it.

Phase one. Being the village oaf that you are, you can’t fight anything, and it’s only through a lot of trial and error that you begin to present even a fraction of a threat to a desperate armed peasant. Here is where people not keen on putting themselves in drop off, claiming that combat is awful.
Phase two. Soon enough, you discover that captain Bernard is the best man in all of Bohemia. Because he can teach you combat. Every day. All day. You can spar, and through sparring you will actually level up your fighting skills! You know, like in real life? I cannot stress enough, how good this design decision is! You can literally lose yourself in the sparring arena for days, advancing your weapon mastery, kicking captain’s buttock and getting your buttock kicked, learning combos, feeling proud if you managed to pull off one of those on your ultraskilled teacher. And then…
Phase three. You start getting into fights. And that’s where all of your knowledge about combat that Bernard taught you washes away. Because this game’s system is built for duels, and even two versus one is already a problem. Enemies have no honor. They will spam left mouse button on you if they flank you with no hesitation. You will be lucky if you manage to pull a single combo at the beginning of the fight – before you have to feverishly block, reposition and chop out of harm’s way with little rhyme or reason. It’s utterly frustrating. And even when you get to fight actual duels with a skilled opponent, they can interrupt your fancy combos at any given time with master strikes. Woe… Utter woe… @#%$ this game!
Phase four. And then it hits you. It’s not a tournament we’re talking about. It’s a dirty, nasty fight to the death! So put your opponent between yourself and his archer friend! Pincushion them with arrows from afar! Take advantage of your horse and fight from the saddle! Sneak on them and do terrible things to them from the shadows! Reenact that scene from Pasolini’s Oedipus Rex! Pretend to give up and attack suddenly! Buy the Woman’s Lot DLC and let slip the dog of war! Combo-loving posers don’t live long. Win by clinch. Win by feints. Win by treachery. Win by brains. For better or worse, Kingdom Come’s combat is not believable, it’s literally like real life. All is fair, and no quarter will be given.
I suspect there is a phase five where you discover a meta, but I probably won’t get to that, neither do I care.
This progression – from an absolute zero – to an eager beginner – to a cocky graduate – to a cocky graduate who’s been handed his bottom line to – to a fully functional man of war – is the best thing this game has to offer. And trust me – everything else it offers is very good, because every system here is designed to be unique, believable and fully synergetic with other systems.

Kingdom Come is the game I love for its flaws. And that’s because where its design principle is believability, its biggest flaw is actual realism. I think I applaud.

PS
That English translation of characters' names though... Jindřich turning into a generic Henry... Right...

PPS
Also, if approached really slowly, this game gives off a certain feeling. I don't rightly know how best to describe it. I suppose, I only really had it one other time in my gaming experience - when I was playing Gothic as a child, so maybe it's just a personal thing and shows how much I am fond of this game. I would call it a "surrogate Heideggerian Feldweg feeling". As in: not quite the real deal, but as close as a game can take us. I don't know, maybe any massive RPG can evoke this feeling, but I love The Witcher 3, and it didn't give me that, nor did Oblivion, which was my first TES game, and those who know, know how much a first TES game can mean to a person- no matter which one it is. I don't know. It's probably personal. I thought it might be a curious observation anyway.
Was this review helpful? 
Yes
 
No

142565826.review:
Highly atmospheric and with great writing. Characters are good and the narrative unfolds in a very pleasant and novel-like way. You really feel like you're f*cking around in the middle ages - whether it's good or bad.

It's a VERY hardcore and punishing game, and may not be for everyone because of that. It tries too much to be realistic, and while some things work, others simply ruin the fun. Pretty much everything in this game can kill or hurt you: even running in a hill can be enough to result in a deadly fall, for instance. 

The combat is slow and feels terrible on mouse+keyboard, so I highly recommend playing with a controler. The stealth is very inconsistent, and I also wouldn't trust it for your first playthrough.

In the end, it's a clunky and buggy experience, and maybe too ambitious for the small team behind it, but still worth checking out for its art, storytelling and atmosphere. It's similar to the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series in this regard. If you like this kind of unpolished but highly atmospheric open world game, it's worth a shot.

However, despite all this, I cannot recommend it to most people - unless it's at least 70% off. If you want some medieval fun, get Mount & Blade instead. It's a lot more accessible and easier to get into (although still difficult in its own way).

TLDR: Decent atmospheric game but not for everyone due to its learning curve. Combat feels clunky. Play with a controller. Get on discount.

noble caballero o dama! Permitid que os ofrezca mi más elocuente opinión sobre este maravilloso juego medieval que Observáis.

Verdaderamente, es un deleite sin igual sumergirse en las bondades de este juego de época. Sus gráficos son tan exquisitos como los tapices tejidos por las manos más hábiles de los artesanos medievales. Cada detalle, desde los majestuosos castillos hasta los intrincados trajes de los caballeros y doncellas, nos transporta a un mundo lleno de esplendor y misterio.

Las mecánicas de combate son una danza magistral de destreza y habilidad, que despiertan en el jugador un sentimiento de valentía y emoción en cada enfrentamiento. Cada espada chocando, cada flecha volando y cada estrategia trazada con maestría nos recuerda la valentía de los antiguos guerreros y sus lides por el honor y la gloria.

Y qué decir de la banda sonora, ¡una auténtica sinfonía que transporta nuestros corazones a lo más profundo de la Edad Media! Sus melodías llenan nuestras almas de emoción, llevándonos a través de campos de batalla, celebraciones en las cortes y emocionantes hazañas en busca de aventuras.

El juego, además, destaca por su cuidado y fiel ambiente histórico. Cada rincón está meticulosamente ambientado en la época medieval, haciendo que la experiencia sea no solo entretenida, sino también educativa, permitiéndonos sumergirnos en una época que dejó huella en la historia de la humanidad.

En resumen, este juego medieval es una auténtica joya, un tesoro que nos permite viajar en el tiempo y experimentar la grandeza de la Edad Media con todos nuestros sentidos. Os aseguro, noble señor o dama, que no podéis dejar pasar la oportunidad de vivir esta experiencia única y apasionante. ¡Preparaos para una aventura sin igual!

142376120.review:
Most likely the game with the most realistic depiction of medieval combat and i'd even go as far as to say its the most realistic depiction of medieval Europe found in a video game. 
Its not for rookie players, even thought mods can make it easier (unlimited saves mainly) combat is hard to pick up at first but incredibly rewarding when you do.

Gameplay wise its some sort of Ultra realistic survival RPG, its kinda unique so let me break it down. Basically you have quests and dialogues like in regular rpgs but there is a need system that force you to rest and eat in an inn once in a while or you'll suffer from some nasty effects that can severely impact your combat performance. Also there is no manual saving, its done by sleeping, scripted quests or with a savior schnaps so if you find yourself in a combat you can't win its better to either surrender or run.

Story is pretty nice, without spoiling anything its a pretty simple story about the hero looking for revenge. You don't save the world, you aren't the chosen one and most of the time you aren't even the most important man in the room. It feel grounded and believable. I also really loved the inclusion of cutscenes and scripted quests (as in more than go to X get object Y and come back) which is something you rarely see in RPG's.
The ending was a bit disapointing thought, it doesn't feel like a conclusion but rather like a cliffhanger. The ending cutscene make up for it thought as it is truly wonderful but i still feel like there could have been a bit more to it.

Soundtrack is a work of art, its undoubtly one of the most well done part of the game and everyone can universaly agree that its incredible. Wandering the hills of Bohemia while listening to the OST is a memorable experience.


TLDR : If you like the medieval era and immersive games get this now.

142371637.review:
I had my reservations about this game when it initially came out in 2018 I saw it and was like "Hmm this game looks interesting" and sat on it for years. Saw a few YouTube videos about it over the years most prominently Nodes 2 videos showing off the pure difficulty of the game. I finally picked up the game since it was $7 with all the DLC, and boy was that the right choice. 

now while I'm not completely through the game at the time of writing this review I am having an absolute blast. This game is exciting, gritty, and most importantly hard and I mean HARD. I decided for my first play-through to play the game in hardcore mode and I'm still deciding if that was a good or bad idea. Without the weapon compass thingy in combat, it makes the combat just more challenging. The enemies doing the same amount of damage as you make fights more real and make duels last and feel frustrating yet fun, because one slight mistake and cause ur enemy to get a big combo and can cause u to die a painful death, and without the autosaves from quests that mistake can cause you hours of progress. 

for the story, it is something I am 100% certain that it is one of the few games where your decisions matter. for example, I had to go to a trader to pay off debt and I saw a dialog option to learn to read I was intrigued and that decision led me to another town, and spent 3 in-game days not only learning English but Latin. I didn't think much of it but then a few hours later I was doing a quest where I got this letter that had important information and because I went out of my way to learn how to read I was able to save myself probably an hour of riding across the map to get it read to me. while this may be a minuet thing it made me appreciate how much my choices matter in this game. 

This game is visually stunning. I have a pretty beefy pc so I am running on complete max settings and wow the game is beautiful. Since I'm playing in hardcore mode I can't fast travel and being forced to ride everywhere u get to see the true natural beauty of this game. ya ill admit the animation isn't flawless the facial expressions are pretty ugly at times sometimes ill ride past someone and half of their body will be invisible and cut scenes will not be at the right perspective and I can't see anything. 

talking about pure combat which is the bread and butter of this game which I briefly mentioned earlier is rewarding that's the only way I can put it. having to think about what position ur going to strike from or if it's even worth fighting in the first place is something that this game does great. one of the biggest things I love about the combat is the armor. if your opponent is wearing something light like chain or padded then a short sword will do the job just fine but once you start fighting heavily armored opponents with plate armor when that sword might not cut it and funny enough just smashing their head in with a hammer will turn the insides of that armor to jelly. 

This game is a 10/10 from me it's fun, frustrating, and rewarding if you like medieval games but like a challenge give this game a shot it's probably the most fun I've had with a story game in a long time.
